('85', 0, 6, 10, 344) 2. INTERVIEW TO “ THE HINDU”
('85', 0, 7, 11, 373) October 2, 1944
('85', 0, 8, 12, 389) When I approached him this morning and asked him whether he had any particular message to give to the country on this auspicious day, Gandhiji said: I am not accustomed to giving messages on such occasions.
('85', 0, 9, 13, 596) Gandhiji amidst laughter added: I want life for 125 years.
('85', 0, 9, 14, 655) But Malaviyaji cut it down by 25 years when he wired to me in Poona at Parnakuti that I must live for a hundred years.
('85', 0, 10, 15, 774) Bernard Shaw’s message arrived here today .
('85', 0, 10, 16, 818) that he would not send birthday messages to Gandhiji.
('85', 0, 10, 17, 872) Gandhiji laughed aloud and said: There you are.
('85', 0, 10, 18, 920) I did not know until a few years ago that I have a birthday.
('85', 0, 11, 19, 981) The Hindu, 4 10 1944
('85', 1, 0, 1, 1002) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 1, 1, 2, 1042) 3. SPEECH AT KASTURBA MEMORIAL TRUST MEETING 1
('85', 1, 2, 3, 1089) SEVAGRAM, October 2, 1944 Gandhiji reminded them that the day’s gathering was not a public meeting.
('85', 1, 2, 4, 1189) There was an order prohibiting general meetings without previous Government permission throughout the Wardha district.
('85', 1, 2, 5, 1308) They all knew that he was a confirmed civil resister.
('85', 1, 2, 6, 1362) But this was not the occasion for civil disobedience.
('85', 1, 2, 7, 1416) Disobedience to be civil implies a certain procedure.
('85', 1, 2, 8, 1470) This was a meeting of the trustees and collectors of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund for presentation of the collection.
('85', 1, 2, 9, 1602) Referring to the large number of people from Wardha and outside that had gathered there, he remarked that the reason for their presence on that occasion was that, for years, people all over India had got into the habit of celebrating his birthday according to both the Indian and the Christian calendar.
('85', 1, 2, 10, 1906) The intervening period between the two dates was also included in the observance.
('85', 1, 2, 11, 1988) This time, it had become known long before that he intended coming to Sevagram for receiving the purse on October 2. The Secretary, in his report, had told them how the idea of the Fund had originated.
('85', 1, 2, 12, 2190) They might like to know how he had come to be the President of the Trust.
('85', 1, 2, 13, 2264) The collections were started when he was in jail.
('85', 1, 2, 14, 2314) The trustees had asked for his consent to nominate him as their President.
('85', 1, 2, 15, 2389) After his accidental release 2, owing to illness, they were able to consult him and he had become President for the purpose of guiding the trustees as to how the money collected should be spent in a manner befitting the memory of the late Smt.
('85', 1, 2, 16, 2633) Kasturba.
('85', 1, 2, 17, 2643) The responsibility primarily rested on the trustees, but it rested on him most of all.
('85', 1, 2, 18, 2730) The money had to be spent in villages, which were not part of the cities.
('85', 1, 2, 19, 2804) The poorer and farther away from the cities, the better.
('85', 1, 2, 20, 2861) The Fund had to be spent for education and welfare of women and children only.
('85', 1, 2, 21, 2940) At first, the age limit for male children had been fixed at twelve years.
('85', 1, 2, 22, 3014) He himself had thought of raising it to sixteen.
('85', 1, 2, 23, 3063) But it was pointed out to him that in that case boys would get a disproportionate share, leaving the girls at a disadvantage and so their age limit was reduced to seven years.
('85', 1, 2, 24, 3239) As he had already remarked, the money was to be spent for education of women and children.
('85', 1, 2, 25, 3330) So long as he had any voice in the matter, the education would be of the basic education type.
('85', 1, 2, 26, 3425) The scope of basic education included the education of the entire society, beginning with the children and going up to adults and old men and women.
('85', 1, 2, 27, 3574) It had to be imparted through the practice of handicrafts, village sanitation and medical relief, preventive and curative, especially with regard to deficiency diseases.
('85', 1, 3, 28, 3744) 1 Gandhiji addressed the trustees and collectors of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund in Hindustani.
('85', 1, 3, 29, 3854) On behalf of the trustees Sarojini Naidu presented him a purse of Rs. 80 lakhs, This report of the speech was issued to the Press by Pyarelal.
('85', 1, 3, 30, 3997) 2 On May 6, 1944
('85', 2, 0, 1, 4014) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 3
('85', 2, 1, 2, 4055) It was a tremendous work to carry out these reforms in the seven lakhs of India’s villages.
('85', 2, 1, 3, 4147) A sum of rupees seventy five lakhs or even of rupees one crore was a trifle, compared to the vastness of the task.
('85', 2, 1, 4, 4262) Seventy five per cent of the money collected from a particular area would be spent in that area, not being towns or cities, and the remaining twenty five per cent would go to the Central Fund.
('85', 2, 1, 5, 4455) But the money collected from big cities would all go to the Central Fund and nothing out of it would be spent in the cities.
('85', 2, 1, 6, 4580) In place of collection committees new committees would have to be formed to ensure proper spending of the money.
('85', 2, 1, 7, 4693) These committees might include some members of the collecting committees, but new names should be added.
('85', 2, 1, 8, 4798) If in any place ways and means of spending the money satisfactorily in accordance with the aims and objects of the Fund could not be found, the money would remain with the Central Fund.
('85', 2, 1, 9, 4984) On the other hand, if in any place suitable workers in adequate number could be found to carry out bigger plans satisfactorily, they would be given more money.
('85', 2, 2, 10, 5144) It was his wish that, as far as possible, money should be spent through the agency of women workers.
('85', 2, 2, 11, 5245) It was a matter of regret that women workers with suitable qualifications were not forthcoming in sufficient numbers.
('85', 2, 2, 12, 5363) The fault lay with the men who had kept the women enslaved in domestic drudgery.
('85', 2, 2, 13, 5444) They had to draw them out and push them to the fore.
('85', 2, 2, 14, 5497) After all men were not born efficient as a special creation.
('85', 2, 2, 15, 5558) It rested on them to produce more and efficient women workers.
('85', 2, 2, 16, 5621) Men, before they became efficient workers, were prone to make mistakes.
('85', 2, 2, 17, 5693) Therefore, they must not expect efficiency from women without giving them responsible work.
('85', 2, 2, 18, 5785) The Fund was collected in commemoration of an old illiterate village minded woman.
('85', 2, 2, 19, 5868) It would give peace to her departed soul if women, and especially old women, took a leading part in the execution of the object of the Memorial.
('85', 2, 2, 20, 6013) The collection had been made out of an overflow of enthusiasm and affection towards the memory of the departed soul.
('85', 2, 2, 21, 6130) He wanted them to see that it was spent in a way commensurate with that sentiment.
('85', 2, 2, 22, 6213) That was not a task merely for the twenty six trustees; hundreds of workers would be needed for it.
('85', 2, 2, 23, 6313) He had already said that to spend money properly was much more difficult than to collect it, unless they showed as much aptness in the former, as they had done in the latter.
('85', 2, 2, 24, 6488) So long as he was with them in the flesh, he would, of course, argue with them and fight with them, but it was for them to see that their work was so carried on as to give to the departed soul no cause for dissatisfaction.
('85', 2, 3, 25, 6711) The Hindu, 4 10 1944
('85', 2, 4, 26, 6732) 1 At one of the meetings of the Trust the question of Kasturba’s outlook on life was raised during the discussion.
('85', 2, 4, 27, 6847) Gandhiji was reported to have said: “Kasturba’s outlook on life means the outlook represented by Kasturba Gandhi, not Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi.”

('85', 8, 6, 13, 13267) 17. LETTER TO J. R. D. TATA
('85', 8, 7, 14, 13295) SEVAGRAM , October 7, 1944
('85', 8, 8, 15, 13322) DEAR JEHANGIRJI, In order that I may be understood by you as fully as possible I write this in English, though I should love to write to you in Gujarati.
('85', 8, 8, 16, 13476) For similar reason this will be typed.
('85', 8, 8, 17, 13515) Thank you for your cordial letter of greetings.
('85', 8, 8, 18, 13563) I would like you to make the cordiality concrete by attending the next meeting of the Trustees 1 to be held at Wardha on Saturday the 4th November.
('85', 8, 8, 19, 13711) Saturday has been specially chosen in order to enable the original Trustees to attend with minimum of inconvenience.
('85', 8, 8, 20, 13828) That you have already accepted the additional names proposed by me for the Board of Trustees and for the small Executive ought not to bear the meaning that the original trustees are to be sleeping members.
('85', 8, 9, 21, 14034) 1 Of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund 2 Vide “A Circular”, 21 9 1944.
('85', 9, 0, 1, 14114) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 9, 1, 2, 14155) I know I am guilty of having given currency to the thought that the administration of trust funds should in practice be left to the Trustees of my choice.
('85', 9, 1, 3, 14310) I discovered my mistake before any mischief was done.
('85', 9, 1, 4, 14364) The more I think about it, the more I feel the narrowness underlying such a conception.
('85', 9, 1, 5, 14452) The whole board is a very happy combination and if most of the Trustees take an active interest in the administration of the Fund, we may expect even unthought of beneficial results.
('85', 9, 1, 6, 14635) An active combination and co operation of top city men and simple village minded men and women is not an everyday experience.
('85', 9, 1, 7, 14761) I trust therefore that you will make it convenient to attend the forthcoming meeting and even persuade the Trustees to do likewise, if indeed they need any persuading.
('85', 9, 2, 8, 14929) M. K. GANDHI J. R. D. TATA BOMBAY
('85', 9, 3, 9, 14963) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('85', 9, 4, 11, 15012) 18. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU 1
('85', 9, 5, 12, 15054) October 7, 1944
('85', 9, 6, 13, 15070) At the outset Jajuji read out the resolution submitted by Gandhiji before the workers of the A. I. S. A. in the September meeting.
('85', 9, 6, 14, 15201) There was a suggestion in that draft 2 that the A. I. V. I. A. and the Hindustani Talimi Sangh be also consulted while drawing the future plan of work of the A. I. S. A.
('85', 9, 7, 15, 15371) J. Should the Harijan Sevak Sangh, Goseva Sangh and Kasturba Trust be also included in this list?
('85', 9, 8, 16, 15469) G. Of course, inasmuch as they are as intimately connected with the programme of village reconstruction as the A. I. S. A., and have an economic background and outlook, not a political one.
('85', 9, 8, 17, 15659) The idea behind the merging of the Sanghs is only that of co orclinated service of the villages.
('85', 9, 8, 18, 15756) But the Kasturba Trust may well be kept out.
('85', 9, 9, 19, 15801) J. Keeping the Trust out would mean paralysing an organ of the united body.
('85', 9, 9, 20, 15877) Out of the six Sanghs we can easily form a united executive of one or more representatives from each Sangh.
('85', 9, 10, 21, 15985) 1 This and the subsequent discussions in Hindi with Shrikrishnadas Jaju, Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, were reported by Swami Anand.
('85', 9, 10, 22, 16132) This translation is reproduced with alterations to bring it into conformity with the Hindi version appearing in Charkha Sanghka Navasamskaran.
('85', 9, 10, 23, 16275) 2 Vide “Speech at A.I.S.A. Meeting II”, 2 9 1944.
('85', 10, 0, 1, 16325) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 11
('85', 10, 1, 2, 16367) G. We can get our work done through the institutions of the Kasturba Trust, for their work is not anything different from village service.
('85', 10, 1, 3, 16506) Yet we should not include the Trust in it.
('85', 10, 1, 4, 16549) When I placed that resolution before the Charkha Sangh the Kasturba Trust was not in my mind.
('85', 10, 1, 5, 16643) I had only the A.I.V.I.A. and the Hindustani Talimi Sangh in view.
('85', 10, 1, 6, 16710) My idea was that the heads of these Sanghs should meet together and co ordinate their activities from the point of view of all round village service, and influence one another morally without any of them disturbing any of the others in its day to day work.
('85', 10, 1, 7, 16967) The only work of the Central Office of the A. I. S. A. should be to watch and give moral guidance.
('85', 10, 1, 8, 17066) It is quite possible that like Euclid’s point we might not be able to reach the ideal.
('85', 10, 1, 9, 17153) Decentra lization consists in bothering little about the practical details of the various centres but regulating the over all work on moral lines.
('85', 10, 1, 10, 17300) I know that I may not be able to get the Goseva Sangh, the Harijan Sevak Sangh and others to carry out this policy of decentralization.
('85', 10, 1, 11, 17436) But as service and total uplift of villages is the basis of all their activity I hope and trust the heads and workers of these Sanghs would of their own accord meet and think jointly how best to organize their work.
('85', 10, 1, 12, 17652) They would also have to consider, for example, why the work of the A. I. S.A. had to be arrested or modified.
('85', 10, 1, 13, 17762) One may argue that the work had not been arrested in any way.
('85', 10, 1, 14, 17824) The Sangh’s work had expanded to cover 15,000 villages; 4_ crores of rupees had been distributed among the poor.
('85', 10, 1, 15, 17937) All this is no doubt true but we should not rest content with only this much.
('85', 10, 1, 16, 18015) Rather it should be a matter of regret for us that we have as yet accomplished only a hundredth part of our task.
('85', 10, 1, 17, 18129) A worker of the A. I. S. A. would hereafter not confine himself to khadi work alone but regard himself as well a representative of the A.I.V.I.A., the Goseva Sangh, etc., in the larger sense of the term.
('85', 10, 1, 18, 18333) And in so doing the worker should not feel that all this other work was beyond his sphere and that a new burden was being imposed upon him.
('85', 10, 1, 19, 18473) If he did so, it would mean that our policy and outlook were not really based on non violence.
('85', 10, 1, 20, 18568) Our worker should be able to identify himself with all that requires to be done in the village, that is, with the entire life of the village and yet feel as light as ever.
('85', 10, 2, 21, 18740) J. Like the A. I. S. A., should institutions such as the Goseva Sangh, the A. I. V. I. A. and the Hindustani Talimi Sangh also depute such workers to the villages?
('85', 11, 0, 1, 18904) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 11, 1, 2, 18945) G. Exactly so.
('85', 11, 1, 3, 18960) This is the real meaning of the merging of the Sanghs and of their having a united policy.
('85', 11, 1, 4, 19051) It does not mean any regimentation of work but it simply connotes working with the united moral strength of all and with a wholesome integrated outlook.
('85', 11, 2, 5, 19204) J. Will the A.I.S.A. have to run commercial and welfare departments separately?
('85', 11, 2, 6, 19284) I feel that to run all village activities with an all round outlook and to give general guidance to the workers will be the special function of the joint body of all the Sanghs.
('85', 11, 3, 7, 19462) G. I do not think so.
('85', 11, 3, 8, 19484) The joint body of the various Sanghs can once for all lay down administrative policies.
('85', 11, 3, 9, 19572) The arrangements so made must be honoured by all the Sanghs, which would greatly facilitate their managerial work.
('85', 11, 3, 10, 19687) My idea of the united body is that its work will expand like the mighty Krishna river, which starts as a tiny tickle of ten to twenty drops of water and ends as one vast Krishnasagar.
('85', 11, 3, 11, 19871) So also should flow the ceaseless stream of all sided work.
('85', 11, 3, 12, 19931) Such is my conception of the joint body.
('85', 11, 4, 13, 19972) J. The real problem is to obtain suitable workers.
('85', 11, 4, 14, 20023) You suggest various activities, but we cannot undertake them for want of workers.
('85', 11, 4, 15, 20105) Then again you insist that we should reach the seven lakhs of villages.
('85', 11, 5, 16, 20177) G. Of course, I do.
('85', 11, 5, 17, 20197) But when you fail I am there all along with you to share with you the blame.
('85', 11, 6, 18, 20274) J. So we are to take it that good workers are to be trained.
('85', 11, 6, 19, 20335) For the present we cannot hope to get thoroughly capable first grade workers.
('85', 11, 6, 20, 20413) We shall have to get on with second grade workers.
('85', 11, 6, 21, 20464) From among them we shall obtain first grade ones later.
('85', 11, 7, 22, 20520) G. Does the A.I.S.A. have about 2,000 workers?
('85', 11, 8, 23, 20567) J. About 3,000.
('85', 11, 9, 24, 20583) G. Well, then use them.
('85', 11, 9, 25, 20607) Place upon them the responsibility for this new type of work.
('85', 11, 9, 26, 20669) Also allow them greater freedom in their work.
('85', 11, 9, 27, 20716) We shall have to decentralize even at some risk.
('85', 11, 10, 28, 20765) J. I do not quite understand what you mean by decentralization.
('85', 11, 11, 29, 20829) G. We shall have to expand the work so that it covers every village.
('85', 11, 11, 30, 20898) This cannot be done by imposition from without.
('85', 11, 11, 31, 20946) The workers will have to be allowed to carry on the work themselves, more or less free of regulation by a central authority.
('85', 11, 11, 32, 21071) Were they to refuse to bear this much burden and wish to leave us we shall let them go ungrudgingly.
('85', 11, 11, 33, 21172) But we are not going to turn anybody out.
('85', 11, 11, 34, 21214) I like your idea of giving khadi cloth in exchange for hanks in Maharashtra.
('85', 11, 11, 35, 21291) This is not yet much in vogue.
('85', 11, 11, 36, 21322) But it is being done through workers already on our staff.
('85', 11, 11, 37, 21381) This is the way work will go on
('85', 12, 0, 1, 21413) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 13
('85', 12, 1, 2, 21455) and develop.
('85', 12, 1, 3, 21468) But workers who create obstructions will have to go.
('85', 12, 1, 4, 21521) I will have no hesitation in removing them.
('85', 12, 1, 5, 21565) If they disobey the policy of the A. I. S. A. they will have to quit.
('85', 12, 1, 6, 21635) And the Sangh is authorized to change its policy from time to time.
('85', 12, 1, 7, 21703) The plea of the workers that they were not aware of such changes will not be accepted.
('85', 12, 1, 8, 21790) Compulsory wearing of khadi, provident fund contributions, etc., were introduced in the course of the running of the Association and they were made applicable to all.
('85', 12, 1, 9, 21957) Those who could not accept them had to go.
('85', 12, 1, 10, 22000) Workers may leave us in this manner.

('85', 12, 1, 14, 22310) Not for a moment did I think that we would have to disband the existing set of workers and start on a clean slate.

('85', 12, 1, 16, 22734) This is decentralization.

('85', 14, 1, 2, 24930) 21. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU
('85', 14, 2, 3, 24970) October 8, 1944
('85', 14, 3, 4, 24986) J. Please explain what should be the equipment and qualifications of workers.
('85', 14, 4, 5, 25064) G. For the present I shall not deal with other institutions but answer your question keeping in view the worker of the A. I. S. A. alone.
('85', 14, 4, 6, 25202) First, he should know, besides his mother tongue, the language of the province in which he is working as also the national language.
('85', 14, 4, 7, 25335) I do not feel that knowledge of English is essential.
('85', 14, 4, 8, 25389) He should know about the economic, social and political condition of the country and also something about the condition of the world.
('85', 14, 4, 9, 25523) This is rather difficult, it is true, but essential.
('85', 14, 4, 10, 25576) Unless he knows what is happening in other countries, their political set up, etc., how can he understand the relative conditions in India and where we are bound for?
('85', 14, 4, 11, 25743) He must have especially detailed knowledge of the conditions prevailing in and about his place of work.
('85', 14, 4, 12, 25847) So much in regard to his general preparation which is only a preliminary part of his equipment.
('85', 14, 4, 13, 25943) In regard to khadi, he should not only have thorough knowledge of the charkha, but he must also be well acquainted with the takli.
('85', 14, 4, 14, 26074) Spinning alone will not do.
('85', 14, 4, 15, 26102) He must know the entire science of khadi, i.e., evaluating the count, carding, identifying the variety of cotton, the kind of cotton required for a specific type of carding, spinning, etc.
('85', 14, 4, 16, 26291) He must be in touch with the history of improvements in technique, viz., how carding reached its present stage, the various improvements effected in the charkha.
('85', 14, 4, 17, 26453) He must also be able to repair and put the charkha in order.
('85', 14, 4, 18, 26514) It was in Yeravda that I systematically learnt spinning, repairing of the charkha, etc., and I had no one to help me either.
('85', 14, 4, 19, 26639) It means that the worker must know the elements of carpentry as well, for if he is not able to set right the damaged charkhas of the villagers, spinning will stop in the village and the cause will suffer.
('85', 14, 4, 20, 26844) I have dwelt upon the charkha so much because I regard it as the centre of village uplift.
('85', 14, 4, 21, 26935) In addition, the worker will have to see what other village crafts can prosper in his village.
('85', 14, 4, 22, 27030) The first in order among these crafts will be the bullock oil press.
('85', 14, 4, 23, 27099) Our worker would have to know its technique which has now been scientifically improved at Maganwadi under the supervision of Jhaverbhai Patel.
('85', 15, 0, 1, 27242) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 15, 1, 2, 27283) Another industry which may be introduced is hand made paper.
('85', 15, 1, 3, 27344) This has to be learnt not with the view of supplying paper to the whole country but in order to make the village self sufficient and capable of earning a little income.
('85', 15, 2, 4, 27513) J. If the work of hand made paper develops it will be like running a small factory.
('85', 15, 3, 5, 27597) G. I am only giving its outline.
('85', 15, 3, 6, 27630) Next to oil and hand made paper we must revive the handchakki (grinding stone)—a vital thing in every village.
('85', 15, 3, 7, 27741) Otherwise flour mills which have been a source of anxiety to me for several years will be our fate.
('85', 15, 3, 8, 27841) Similarly in regard to rice.
('85', 15, 3, 9, 27870) Unless we inculcate among the villagers the habit of eating whole rice we shall not be able to solve the problem of food.
('85', 15, 3, 10, 27992) We must get our people in the villages to take to hand pounding of rice or handchakkis for husking paddy, for it is a well established fact that the white polished rice put out by mills and white sugar are harmful to health.
('85', 15, 3, 11, 28217) All the top experts are agreed upon it.
('85', 15, 3, 12, 28257) We do get enough literature on these subjects from America.
('85', 15, 3, 13, 28317) There brown, that is, yellow sugar has come in vogue.
('85', 15, 3, 14, 28371) So much so that traders sell the white polished sugar after colouring it with harmful colours.
('85', 15, 3, 15, 28466) Next take agriculture.
('85', 15, 3, 16, 28489) Our villagers depend on agriculture and cattle for ploughing.
('85', 15, 3, 17, 28551) I am rather ignorant in this respect for I have no personal experience.
('85', 15, 3, 18, 28623) But there is not a single village where we have no agriculture or cattle.
('85', 15, 3, 19, 28697) There is the buffalo, but except in Konkan and a few other places it is not much used for agriculture.
('85', 15, 3, 20, 28800) Even then it is not as if we have boycotted the buffalo.
('85', 15, 3, 21, 28857) Our worker will have to keep a careful eye on the cattle wealth of his village.
('85', 15, 3, 22, 28937) If we cannot use this wealth properly India is doomed to disaster and we also shall perish.
('85', 15, 3, 23, 29029) For these animals will then, as in the West, become an economic burden to us and we shall have no option before us save killing them.
('85', 15, 3, 24, 29163) Our worker, therefore, would have to acquire some knowledge at any rate about these things, and discover a non violent way of solving them.
('85', 15, 3, 25, 29303) Therein lies the solution to our problem of increasing population.
('85', 15, 3, 26, 29370) I do not know whether our non violent way will succeed or fail.
('85', 15, 3, 27, 29434) If it fails it will be our fault, not that of non violence.
('85', 15, 3, 28, 29494) It means that our sacrifice and efforts were insufficient.
('85', 15, 3, 29, 29553) Nevertheless all of us will have to make some effort.
('85', 15, 3, 30, 29607) Again, in the sphere of agriculture chaos reigns supreme.
('85', 15, 3, 31, 29665) In regard to agriculture, we must do our utmost to prevent further fragmentation of land, and to encourage people to take to co operative farming.
('85', 15, 3, 32, 29812) The village worker will fully examine
('85', 16, 0, 1, 29850) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 17
('85', 16, 1, 2, 29892) the circumstances prevailing in his village and induce the villagers to take up co operative farming.
('85', 16, 1, 3, 29994) Next to land is the question of water, not for agriculture but for drinking.
('85', 16, 1, 4, 30071) The worker will go and examine all the wells in the village.
('85', 16, 1, 5, 30132) It will be his duty to clean them both inside and around.
('85', 16, 1, 6, 30190) He will see how many wells of the village are fit for drinking water, whether the surroundings are clean, and whether there are any public urinals and latrines near them.
('85', 16, 1, 7, 30361) If they are near the wells, he will explain to the people the dangers involved in having them so near.
('85', 16, 1, 8, 30464) He will seek their co operation in having them removed to a distance.
('85', 16, 1, 9, 30534) He will thus attend to the cleanliness of the entire village.
('85', 16, 1, 10, 30596) Now we know about a worker’s field of activity.
('85', 16, 1, 11, 30644) He should have a thorough knowledge of village sanitation and efficient compost making.
('85', 16, 1, 12, 30732) He should convert this knowledge into practice.
('85', 16, 1, 13, 30780) Of course there will be division of work but it should not be like that of the railway porter showing the green signal or like the woman worker making soles in a leather factory.
('85', 16, 1, 14, 30959) Such people are incapable of doing any other work save their own.
('85', 16, 1, 15, 31025) This extreme division of work is degrading.
('85', 16, 1, 16, 31069) The village worker should acquire all round knowledge about building up the whole village.
('85', 16, 1, 17, 31160) There will be some sewing work in the village, smithy, carpentry, leather work, agriculture, etc.
('85', 16, 1, 18, 31258) The village worker should seek to bring about co operation among the workers in these various occupations so as to make them serve as harmonious parts of one whole and thus organize the villages.
('85', 16, 1, 19, 31454) All these activities appear to be too numerous but in fact they are not.
('85', 16, 1, 20, 31527) This should not be too difficult for a worker resolved to employ his body and mind fully.
('85', 16, 1, 21, 31617) Now for my last point.
('85', 16, 1, 22, 31640) If the worker going to the village has no faith in non violence, our work must fail.
('85', 16, 1, 23, 31725) If he concerns himself with economics alone and disregards ethics and morality, all our efforts are of no avail.
('85', 16, 1, 24, 31838) Non violence is the basis on which our work is to be built.
('85', 16, 1, 25, 31898) It will not do to ignore it.
('85', 16, 1, 26, 31927) In the initial stages people might achieve something even without it but ultimately the edifice of swaraj will not be raised without the foundation of ahimsa.
('85', 16, 1, 27, 32086) Workers must demonstrate non violence in everything they do.
('85', 16, 1, 28, 32147) They must be living embodiments of non violence.
('85', 16, 1, 29, 32196) If they cannot do this, their work will be but a showy nothing.
('85', 16, 1, 30, 32260) Our history is full of such instances.
('85', 16, 1, 31, 32299) Merely holding classes on non violence is of little use.
('85', 16, 2, 32, 32356) J. Would it not be better to have two workers instead of one in a village?
('85', 16, 2, 33, 32431) They could then divide the work between them and one could supplement the other.
('85', 17, 0, 1, 32512) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 17, 1, 2, 32553) G. Many people have asked me this question.
('85', 17, 1, 3, 32597) I am not going to lay down any definite rules in this regard.
('85', 17, 1, 4, 32659) I would prefer a worker to go alone.
('85', 17, 1, 5, 32696) He should tackle the situation single handed and become fearless in the process.
('85', 17, 1, 6, 32777) But if one is not enough you may send two.
('85', 17, 1, 7, 32820) We shall consider the position if lack of finances comes in the way.
('85', 17, 1, 8, 32889) But so far as I am concerned, I am prepared to go to the length of regarding one worker, if married, as two when both husband and wife serve in the village.
('85', 17, 2, 9, 33046) J. Experience often proves the contrary.
('85', 17, 2, 10, 33087) The wife of a worker is more a handicap to him than a support.
('85', 17, 3, 11, 33150) G. That is why I am not going to frame any rules or regulations about it.
('85', 17, 3, 12, 33224) Do you know that Rajaji insists on workers being married?
('85', 17, 4, 13, 33282) J. Some workers will be of higher calibre than others.
('85', 17, 4, 14, 33337) How do you like the idea of putting under one good worker five or six ordinary workers working in adjoining villages?
('85', 17, 5, 15, 33455) G. I have had talks about it with several friends.
('85', 17, 5, 16, 33506) It will not always be feasible.
('85', 17, 5, 17, 33538) I asked Timappa Naik to train a large number of workers as otherwise his work was likely to suffer.
('85', 17, 5, 18, 33638) He is a very capable and efficient worker of Karnataka.
('85', 17, 5, 19, 33694) He maintains himself on about six rupees.
('85', 17, 5, 20, 33736) He feels that only local workers could be trained at small expense.
('85', 17, 5, 21, 33804) He has trained such and they are working with him.
('85', 17, 6, 22, 33855) J. How much should we spend on a worker?
('85', 17, 7, 23, 33896) G. These are days of war made dearness.
('85', 17, 7, 24, 33936) I am afraid it may last for a fairly long time.
('85', 17, 7, 25, 33984) I am prepared to spend rupees fifty on a worker or even a hundred.
('85', 17, 8, 26, 34051) J. Besides food for the worker there is the burden of his family, of the education of his children, etc.
('85', 17, 9, 27, 34156) G. We shall take the middle way.
('85', 17, 9, 28, 34189) We shall leave out those with many burdens.
('85', 17, 9, 29, 34233) We shall confine ourselves to a family of four, husband, wife and two children, or at the most five.
('85', 17, 9, 30, 34334) I think it would be better not to take a bigger unit.
('85', 17, 10, 31, 34388) J. Many workers argue that they have the responsibility of maintaining their parents, brothers and sisters or other relatives.
('85', 17, 11, 32, 34515) G. We cannot take them.
('85', 17, 12, 33, 34539) J. While fixing the allowance of a worker, which was to be considered as of greater importance, his capacity or his family responsibilities?
('85', 17, 13, 34, 34680) G. To Vallabhswami I would give only five, not hundred.
('85', 17, 13, 35, 34736) But I would pay the maximum to one with a big family rather than let him go.
('85', 17, 13, 36, 34813) That is to say, both should live and neither should be envious of the other.
('85', 17, 13, 37, 34890) Nor should any entertain false hopes.
('85', 18, 0, 1, 34928) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 19
('85', 18, 1, 2, 34970) J. How much response should our workers expect from the villagers?
('85', 18, 1, 3, 35037) Would it be proper to impose some conditions on villages at the time of selection of our place of work?
('85', 18, 1, 4, 35141) The situation today is that workers who go to the villages are regarded as moneyed people and villagers think that they should extract from them as much benefit as possible.
('85', 18, 1, 5, 35315) Consequently the whole work is reduced to nought when the worker leaves the village after working for two years.
('85', 18, 2, 6, 35428) G. I think we should not impose any conditions.
('85', 18, 2, 7, 35476) For example, if we go and settle down for service among the aborigines, what terms can we lay down for them?
('85', 18, 2, 8, 35585) If we settle down and work resolutely in places where we have already gained some experience, our work will grow and prosper.
('85', 18, 2, 9, 35711) In the end everything depends on the worker himself.
('85', 18, 2, 10, 35764) If he wins the hearts of the villagers he will be able to get them to work with him.
('85', 18, 3, 11, 35849) J. How long may it take for a worker to become self sufficient?
('85', 18, 3, 12, 35913) Five years?
('85', 18, 4, 13, 35925) G. You yourself say five years.
('85', 18, 4, 14, 35957) The worker will go to the village with one month’s allowance in his pocket.
('85', 18, 4, 15, 36033) He will ask for a piece of land from the villagers and build his hut on it.
('85', 18, 4, 16, 36109) In case he obtains a vacant house he will occupy it.
('85', 18, 4, 17, 36162) Taking out the takli from his pocket he will sit under a tree and spin.
('85', 18, 4, 18, 36234) If the villagers have their spinning wheels he will repair them and spin along with them.
('85', 18, 4, 19, 36324) He will also gather the children of the village, play with them, tell them stories, teach them songs and do village cleaning.
('85', 18, 4, 20, 36450) Apart from his salary I am not going to give him a pie by way of capital to start an industry or anything else.
('85', 18, 4, 21, 36562) He will have to set up things by dint of his resourcefulness and love.
('85', 18, 4, 22, 36633) This will put to trial his passion for service and his ability.
('85', 18, 5, 23, 36697) J. It is a very hard test.
('85', 18, 6, 24, 36724) G. Yes.
('85', 18, 6, 25, 36732) We don’t have to take up a sword, have we?
('85', 18, 6, 26, 36775) The way of love and service shown by me is the only way.
('85', 18, 6, 27, 36832) If we have to achieve swaraj by non violent means I have no other way.
('85', 18, 7, 28, 36903) Khadi: Why and How, pp.
('85', 18, 8, 29, 36927) 22. LETTER TO K. M. MUNSHI
('85', 18, 9, 30, 36954) SEVAGRAM, October 9, 1944
('85', 18, 10, 31, 36980) BHAI MUNSHI, I was glad you sent your reply so soon.
('85', 18, 10, 32, 37033) It has served the purpose.
('85', 18, 10, 33, 37060) But can that prohibitory order be defended from the point

('85', 22, 3, 4, 42220) This is for Manudi 1 or Sushilabehn.
('85', 22, 3, 5, 42257) A six week course in First Aid.
('85', 22, 3, 6, 42289) 1. General anatomy, including description of the internal sub division in the stomach, the prominent bones, the arteries and the veins.
('85', 22, 3, 7, 42425) 2. Descriptions of the ordinary wounds such as are sustained on the battlefield and the various types of bandages for them: on the skull, the abdomen, the fingers, the legs and so on.
('85', 22, 3, 8, 42609) 3. Tourniquet, for arresting bleeding, as part of curriculum and also extra curricular improvised techniques, such as with a pebble.
('85', 22, 3, 9, 42742) 4. The method of treatment in the absence of medical apparatus, e.g., warm ashes in the absence of boiled water, paper and cotton ashes; newspaper, etc., that one carries for reading in the absence of dry cloth or flannel.
('85', 22, 3, 10, 42965) 5. ‘Primitive’ remedies in the absence of medical aid for drowning, snake bite and scorpion sting.
('85', 22, 3, 11, 43064) 6. Stretcher drill for carrying the wounded or sick persons and making an emergency stretcher with a gun or a stick and a jacket.
('85', 22, 3, 12, 43194) 7. Marching by thousands in regular formations and marching drill according to the rules.
('85', 22, 3, 13, 43284) Erecting tents on a battlefield within a few minutes, rules about the use of water, how and when to construct latrines, kitchens, etc.
('85', 22, 3, 14, 43419) It may be that something is being omitted.
('85', 22, 3, 15, 43462) Most of it is covered by the book written by Kettle.
('85', 22, 3, 16, 43515) Many things are also to be found in “St. John’s Ambulance”.
('85', 22, 3, 17, 43575) We did have all these books.
('85', 22, 3, 18, 43604) Had I been talking I could not have said more.
('85', 22, 3, 19, 43651) So, you have not lost much.

('85', 24, 6, 13, 45417) 31. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU
('85', 24, 7, 14, 45457) October 10, 1944
('85', 24, 8, 15, 45474) J. How will the workers become self supporting?
('85', 24, 8, 16, 45522) Villagers can either give them money or grain, or give them employment.
('85', 24, 8, 17, 45594) Or they may run an industry and support the worker with a percentage of the profit.
('85', 24, 9, 18, 45678) G. Both courses may be adopted.
('85', 24, 9, 19, 45710) We shall surely pay the workers.
('85', 24, 9, 20, 45743) But apart from it the villagers or the worker himself can take up a craft for the sake of the village.
('85', 24, 9, 21, 45846) It may be possible for a good intelligent worker to work in the village and meet his own expenses as also those of his entire activities by his own intellectual work and take nothing from friends.
('85', 24, 9, 22, 46043) But earning money thus by the use of intellect alone is, as I have often said, a misuse of the intellect.
('85', 24, 9, 23, 46149) All such income must go to the country.
('85', 24, 10, 24, 46189) J. If our worker were to live on khadi production alone, it would not be possible for him to become self sufficient.
('85', 24, 10, 25, 46306) He would have to produce commercial khadi; and to earn profit, he must sell it, send it outside and do various other things.
('85', 24, 11, 26, 46431) G. This is not what I had visualized in my scheme.
('85', 24, 11, 27, 46482) I agree of course that if a village has to be made self supporting through the production of khadi alone, the surplus will have to be sent outside.
('85', 24, 11, 28, 46630) Once somebody explained that if we did not produce, in addition to self sufficient khadi, some amount of other khadi also, and our villagers had no other means of subsistence like land, etc., self sufficient khadi alone would not suffice to provide all their needs.
('85', 24, 11, 29, 46896) My idea of self sufficiency is that villages must be self sufficient in
('85', 25, 0, 1, 46968) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 25, 1, 2, 47009) regard to food, cloth and other basic necessities.
('85', 25, 1, 3, 47060) But even this can be overdone.
('85', 25, 1, 4, 47091) Therefore you must grasp my idea properly.
('85', 25, 1, 5, 47134) Self sufficiency does not mean narrowness.
('85', 25, 1, 6, 47177) To be self sufficient is not to be altogether self contained.
('85', 25, 1, 7, 47239) In no circumstances would we be able to produce all the things we need nor do we aim at doing so.
('85', 25, 1, 8, 47337) So though our aim is complete self sufficiency, we shall have to get from outside the village what we cannot produce in the village; we shall have to produce more of what we can in order thereby to obtain in exchange what we are unable to produce.
('85', 25, 1, 9, 47585) Only nothing of our extra produce would be sent to Bombay or far off cities.
('85', 25, 1, 10, 47662) Nor would we produce things with an eye to export to those cities.
('85', 25, 1, 11, 47729) That would run counter to my conception of swadeshi.
('85', 25, 1, 12, 47782) Swadeshi means serving my immediate neighbour rather than those far away.
('85', 25, 1, 13, 47856) Our outlook must be that we would serve the village first, then the neighbourhood, then the district and thereafter the province.
('85', 25, 1, 14, 47986) Working on these lines the A.I.S.A. must function only as the central protector of this policy.
('85', 25, 1, 15, 48082) We should not get involved in all sorts of complications.
('85', 25, 1, 16, 48140) We have three thousand workers and a large number of sales depots.
('85', 25, 1, 17, 48207) We shall not do away with them today.
('85', 25, 1, 18, 48245) But I am simply telling you of our new line of approach.
('85', 25, 2, 19, 48302) J. What should be the extent of a worker’s field of work?
('85', 25, 2, 20, 48360) Should it be an area of about five miles around his centre?
('85', 25, 3, 21, 48420) G. Yes, sometimes even less.
('85', 25, 3, 22, 48449) In Bengal and Bihar an area of five miles around the centre would cover many villages.
('85', 25, 4, 23, 48536) J. Why should we not define his field of activity as the area which he can cover if he left his centre in the morning, and returned to it after having a round by the evening?
('85', 25, 5, 24, 48711) G. Yes, we can do so.
('85', 25, 6, 25, 48733) J. Would the A.I.S.A. have to take up this work first?
('85', 25, 7, 26, 48788) G. Certainly, because the charkha is the sun round which other industries revolve like planets.
('85', 25, 7, 27, 48884) They would revolve rightly only when the sun’s movements are all right.
('85', 25, 7, 28, 48956) Today the village industries are behaving like comets.
('85', 25, 8, 29, 49011) J. The work against untouchability sometimes involves the worker in all kinds of difficulties.
('85', 25, 8, 30, 49106) How far may our worker entangle himself in them?
('85', 25, 9, 31, 49155) G. He should not involve himself in such troubles as would stop his work.
('85', 25, 9, 32, 49229) But there should be no place at all for untouchability in his personal life.
('85', 25, 9, 33, 49306) Our worker will draw water from the same well which the Harijans use.
('85', 25, 9, 34, 49376) He will clean up their wells and take all sanitary steps possible for proper drainage.
('85', 26, 0, 1, 49463) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 27
('85', 26, 1, 2, 49505) J. Then there is the political issue.
('85', 26, 1, 3, 49543) Suppose my self respect is wounded in the course of performance of my duties or my freedom is restricted, would it then be proper for me to offer civil disobedience?
('85', 26, 1, 4, 49709) It may be that I may keep aloof from other political disturbances, but in case of a general civil disobedience movement the worker cannot remain unconcerned.
('85', 26, 1, 5, 49867) What should he do under such circumstances?
('85', 26, 2, 6, 49911) G. General civil disobedience means a sort of anarchy in which everybody is a leader.
('85', 26, 2, 7, 49997) People start talking in terms of fighting.
('85', 26, 2, 8, 50040) But ordinarily we must follow the orders of the chief or the commander in charge of that movement.
('85', 26, 2, 9, 50139) Surely none can remain unconcerned in a movement of that nature.
('85', 26, 2, 10, 50204) Yet the worker would have to explain his position to the President of the A. I. S. A. who would give his opinion after taking all the pros and cons into consideration.
('85', 26, 2, 11, 50372) However, I am not thinking of general civil disobedience today.
('85', 26, 3, 12, 50436) Khadi: Why and How, pp.

('85', 27, 11, 18, 51714) 36. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU
('85', 27, 12, 19, 51754) October 11, 1944
('85', 27, 13, 20, 51771) J. I could not quite follow your views about decentralization.
('85', 27, 13, 21, 51834) Will you kindly throw more light on it?
('85', 27, 14, 22, 51874) G. My view is that we should let as many provinces as wish to be free to develop their work as they desire.
('85', 27, 14, 23, 51982) I would very much like them to take the entire responsibility on their own shoulders and recognize our authority only in the moral realm.
('85', 27, 14, 24, 52120) I would allow them to work with complete freedom if they follow my lines, are personally of sparkling character, and are prepared to take risk in honestly implementing our policy.
('85', 27, 14, 25, 52300) My only condition will be that they should sell all the khadi they produce in the villages near about the centre of production, the tehsil, the district or at the most the province.
('85', 28, 0, 1, 52482) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 29
('85', 28, 1, 2, 52524) should not, like the people of Chicacole, produce everything for Bombay and use nothing at home.
('85', 28, 2, 3, 52621) J. Chicacole is an exception, and is the only production centre in the country for fine khadi.
('85', 28, 3, 4, 52716) G. Yes, even in that case I would ask the producers and sellers to wear what they produce or sell.
('85', 28, 3, 5, 52815) They may send their articles outside but they must also wear them.
('85', 28, 3, 6, 52882) In case they go on producing fine khadi for Bombay but use only mill cloth themselves, their centre must cease to be run by the A. I. S. A. I would even insist that it be closed altogether.
('85', 28, 4, 7, 53072) J. Deducting something from the income of the craftsmen or women towards supply of khadi to them, we do make them wear some khadi.
('85', 28, 4, 8, 53203) But this seems to be a sort of imposition.
('85', 28, 4, 9, 53246) They do not take to it voluntarily.
('85', 28, 5, 10, 53282) G. I may put up with such a situation for a short period.
('85', 28, 5, 11, 53340) I do not expect people to take to khadi immediately and to accept non violence.
('85', 28, 5, 12, 53420) We must educate them in true economics and in non violence.
('85', 28, 5, 13, 53480) If we succeed in doveloping a true economic outlook in them, they would ultimately understand non violence as well.
('85', 28, 5, 14, 53596) An economics which runs counter to morality cannot be called true economics.
('85', 28, 5, 15, 53673) Our workers can develop an outlook of true economics in the villages only if they work under the inspiration of non violence and morality.
('85', 28, 5, 16, 53812) Their personal conduct should be of the purest nature and they should not be a party to any exploitation of the people.
('85', 28, 5, 17, 53932) If we try to cover India with khadi but ignore the miseries of the craftsmen, do not pay them living wages, do not share their weal and woe, or worry little if they are drunkards, it will not do at all.
('85', 28, 5, 18, 54135) It is better to burn all khadi to ashes than to pretend to work for the good of the country in this manner.
('85', 28, 5, 19, 54243) I would keep the drunkard and give him work, but I would befriend him and sweetly urge upon him daily to abstain from drink.
('85', 28, 5, 20, 54368) My aim is not to do the work of khadi only but to enter into the entire life of the villager.
('85', 28, 5, 21, 54462) I know that Chicacole khadi is very popular and that it fetches a good sale in far off provinces; but this pains me very much.
('85', 28, 5, 22, 54589) If we want to do khadi work successfully on the new lines in any province, district, taluk or village, we must not make one district lean on any other, or enter into competition with it.
('85', 28, 5, 23, 54776) All districts must meet their requirements themselves.
('85', 28, 5, 24, 54831) This would relieve us of our worries about sales.
('85', 28, 5, 25, 54881) It is quite possible that implementation of this new policy may
('85', 29, 0, 1, 54945) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 29, 1, 2, 54986) for the present reduce a centre to zero.

('85', 36, 9, 23, 71611) 44. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU October 12, 1944
('85', 36, 10, 24, 71668) J. Before discussing the idea of decentralization further, I would like to place before you the present position of khadi work.
('85', 36, 10, 25, 71796) It will help us in our discourse.
('85', 36, 10, 26, 71830) Khadi work has been carried on along two lines:
('85', 36, 11, 27, 71878) (i) Production and sale of commercial khadi to the utmost extent.
('85', 36, 12, 28, 71944) (ii) Extending cloth self sufficiency as much as possible.
('85', 36, 12, 29, 72003) Today the A.I.S.A. is blamed for not discharging fully its responsibilities in both these respects.
('85', 36, 13, 30, 72103) G. May I interrupt?
('85', 36, 13, 31, 72123) Have we carried on sufficient research in regard to the self sufficiency programme to be able to prove that self sufficient khadi is cheaper than mill cloth?
('85', 36, 13, 32, 72281) In case we are not able to prove it, our villagers will not take to self sufficiency and the workers will have to face despair.
('85', 36, 13, 33, 72409) Now you may proceed.
('85', 37, 0, 1, 72430) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 37, 1, 2, 72471) J. There will be no cause for despair if we once grasp properly the limitations under which khadi work has to be carried on, whether it is commercial khadi or self sufficient khadi.
('85', 37, 1, 3, 72653) For instance, in spite of having made great progress as regards commercial khadi, it cannot be speeded up all of a sudden, for so long as there are textile mills khadi can develop only on public goodwill.
('85', 37, 1, 4, 72858) Besides, there are other difficulties.
('85', 37, 1, 5, 72897) Today, for instance, we produce one crore rupees worth of khadi.
('85', 37, 1, 6, 72962) Last year we discussed a scheme to increase it to five crores.
('85', 37, 1, 7, 73025) This meant that ignoring all other considerations, we had to make use of whatever workers were available, irrespective of their quality in order to push through our programme.
('85', 37, 1, 8, 73201) After careful calculation we reached the conclusion that even after our utmost efforts we shall not be able to produce more than one and a half times our maximum production, and that it would be quite impossible to increase production to two to four times.
('85', 37, 1, 9, 73458) Besides, there are other dangers in so recklessly increasing the work.
('85', 37, 1, 10, 73529) For then we shall have to recruit all sorts of workers who are neither conversant with khadi work nor observe truth and non violence.
('85', 37, 1, 11, 73663) This will not only injure the basic policy of the A.I.S.A. but also bring a bad name to it since the behaviour of the new workers may not always be becoming and clean.
('85', 37, 1, 12, 73831) I am, therefore, not in favour of developing work on such lines.
('85', 37, 2, 13, 73896) So also there are limitations in regard to cloth self sufficiency.
('85', 37, 2, 14, 73963) Even if the various processes from cotton cultivation to ginning, carding and spinning are carried out by the villagers in their own homes, weaving charges are so high that their net saving as compared with the price of mill cloth is very little, so little that the villager is not easily inclined to put himself to all the trouble involved.
('85', 37, 2, 15, 74305) Besides, mill cloth seems more attractive to him than khadi.
('85', 37, 3, 16, 74366) Moreover the reasons underlying our self sufficiency programme require to be explained to the villagers in a manner which will appeal to them.
('85', 37, 3, 17, 74509) They must see that only through working for self sufficiency the entire money of the village will remain in the village, that they can control the factors that make for their well being, that idle time will be profitably utilized and that the people of the village will become industrious.
('85', 37, 3, 18, 74799) In other words, self sufficiency khadi work can begin to have permanent effect only when carried out as part and parcel of the wider programme of non violent village uplift or village reconstruction.
('85', 37, 3, 19, 74999) A programme, which aims at making a certain number of villages self sufficient in cloth within a specific period, does not appeal to me.
('85', 37, 3, 20, 75136) We can succeed only to the extent to which we learn to work intelligently and with the backing of educated public opinion.
('85', 37, 3, 21, 75259) Work based on momentary sentiment or emotion does not endure.
('85', 37, 4, 22, 75321) The same is true about other village industries as well.
('85', 37, 4, 23, 75378) For the present the bullock oil press is running well in the countryside.
('85', 37, 4, 24, 75452) But there are serious misgivings as to whether it will continue always to do so.
('85', 37, 4, 25, 75533) The fact is that our village economic organization of which khadi, chakki and other village industries were the various main organs has collapsed.
('85', 37, 4, 26, 75680) Further, on account of mill competition, village made cloth, flour, rice, oil and everything else have become costlier.
('85', 37, 4, 27, 75800) Should we desire to reinstate them in their proper place, we should have to tackle the entire village economy and build it up anew.
('85', 37, 4, 28, 75932) Concentration and research on any single aspect will
('85', 38, 0, 1, 75985) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 39
('85', 38, 1, 2, 76027) be of little avail.
('85', 38, 1, 3, 76047) Inertia has seized our people.
('85', 38, 1, 4, 76078) Progress cannot be by leaps and bounds but very gradual.
('85', 38, 1, 5, 76135) The problem is very intricate indeed.

('85', 43, 5, 8, 87762) 48. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU
('85', 43, 6, 9, 87802) October 13, 1944
('85', 43, 7, 10, 87819) J. Today I would request you to throw more light on decentralization.
('85', 43, 7, 11, 87889) Narrowly viewed, there is even now decentralization in production because production centres are distributed all over the country.
('85', 43, 7, 12, 88020) But of course all capital is centralized in the Head Office.
('85', 43, 7, 13, 88081) I believe that the central control existing today is merely a control exercised by the A.I.S.A. in regard to policy.
('85', 43, 8, 14, 88198) Looking at the matter from the point of view of capital we must consider under whose initiative the work is to be carried on in the villages hereafter and who is to bear the profit or loss in the end.
('85', 43, 8, 15, 88399) Now there are three ways of doing this.
('85', 43, 9, 16, 88439) Our worker on the spot can carry on all the work.
('85', 43, 9, 17, 88489) Or, we may work through a committee of villagers interested in khadi work who may themselves raise shares, subscriptions, etc.
('85', 43, 9, 18, 88616) Or as a third course the artisans of khadi can form their own societies and carry on the work as their own.
('85', 43, 9, 19, 88724) If the worker remains solely in charge we shall have to hand over to him all the assets, money, property, etc.
('85', 43, 9, 20, 88835) Should he then be regarded as a trustee or should some condition be imposed upon him?
('85', 43, 9, 21, 88921) If the worker carries on his activities with an eye to personal profit there is every likelihood of undesirable developments.
('85', 43, 9, 22, 89047) I think the best way, therefore, would be to form co operative societies.
('85', 43, 9, 23, 89121) Selfish interests may lead to some mismanagement but this fear should not deter us.
('85', 43, 9, 24, 89205) We may have co operative societies not only for khadi but also for oil pressing, hand paper, etc.
('85', 43, 9, 25, 89303) In course of time these bodies in the various villages may, if necessary, merge into a union.
('85', 43, 10, 26, 89397) 1 A. Krishnaswami Iyer
('85', 44, 0, 1, 89420) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 45
('85', 44, 1, 2, 89462) G. I do not have much to say on this point.
('85', 44, 1, 3, 89506) Wherever we can get reliable workers work should be started.
('85', 44, 1, 4, 89567) There is no harm in beginning simultaneously the three types of experiments you have enumerated.
('85', 44, 1, 5, 89664) But, as we had discussed yesterday, we can get rid of many worries if we do not hold ourselves responsible for khadi sales.
('85', 44, 1, 6, 89788) So long as khadi remains a saleable commodity, these worries are bound to be there.
('85', 44, 1, 7, 89872) I also realize that we cannot entirely get rid of them today.
('85', 44, 1, 8, 89934) But so long as we believe that khadi, like bread, must be made at home and that we should not maintain ourselves on bazar made biscuits even if cheaper, we shall have to explain to the people that to use bazar made goods is to court disaster.
('85', 44, 1, 9, 90177) If the people grasp the idea, we shall have to devise an easy method of khadi manufacture at home.
('85', 44, 1, 10, 90276) Our slogan will be ‘cloth even like bread’.
('85', 44, 1, 11, 90320) All difficulties will then disappear.
('85', 44, 1, 12, 90358) The co operative bodies will then have their own shape and form which need not now be anticipated.
('85', 44, 1, 13, 90457) When you said that there was decentralization in khadi production, I was about to contradict you.
('85', 44, 1, 14, 90555) Even in Lancashire some cloth is made at home, not for the use of the home but for the use of the masters.
('85', 44, 1, 15, 90662) It would be outrageous to call this decentralization.
('85', 44, 1, 16, 90716) So also in Japan everything is made at home; but it is not for the use of the home; it is all for the Government which has centralized the whole business.
('85', 44, 1, 17, 90871) Though things are made at home, and made in a better manner than in England, yet the producers cannot keep any of it for their home consumption.
('85', 44, 1, 18, 91016) The work is done at the behest of the Government which supplies ships and does everything else to carry such goods to the different markets of the world and thus draw wealth from other countries.
('85', 44, 1, 19, 91212) The same is happening in Lancashire.
('85', 44, 1, 20, 91249) Though millions of dhotis are made there, yet not a single one is available to any purchaser on the spot.
('85', 44, 1, 21, 91355) They are exported to the country for which they are scheduled, be it India, Africa or any other.
('85', 44, 1, 22, 91452) I would certainly not call this decentralization.
('85', 44, 1, 23, 91502) So also with khadi.
('85', 44, 1, 24, 91522) Our artisans produce not for themselves but for the A. I. S. A. to which they give their finished material for wages paid.
('85', 44, 1, 25, 91645) They were happy when we raised their wages.
('85', 44, 1, 26, 91689) But this is not decentralization.
('85', 44, 1, 27, 91723) What I mean by decentralization is that the artisan must produce for his own or his neighbour’s use and not for sale.
('85', 44, 1, 28, 91841) When we realize that khadi is not a commodity for sale but for self consumption only then we shall have grasped the message of khadi and understood the scope of its potentialities.
('85', 44, 1, 29, 92022) We may be
('85', 45, 0, 1, 92032) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 45, 1, 2, 92073) expected to clothe the whole country with khadi after getting political power.
('85', 45, 1, 3, 92152) Should we not therefore make such an arrangement from today so that we may be able to make the country self sufficient in clothing in case the future government of free India were to provide the requisite facilities to the A. I. S. A. and ask it, as an expert body, to do this task?
('85', 45, 1, 4, 92435) But if the government of the day were to close all its mills, and to charge us with this responsibility, we are apt to fail as things are today.
('85', 45, 1, 5, 92580) We should, therefore, know the extent to which khadi can take us.
('85', 45, 1, 6, 92646) I myself cannot say that I know it for certain.
('85', 45, 1, 7, 92694) But what I am quite clear about is that khadi should not be for sale but for self consumption.
('85', 45, 1, 8, 92789) Hence the necessity of changing the present policy of khadi work.
('85', 45, 1, 9, 92855) We have before us the task of reconstructing our whole country, and in this khadi is an important item.
('85', 45, 1, 10, 92959) So also there are oil pressing and other industries.
('85', 45, 1, 11, 93012) It is only if we look at the problem from the point of view of production for use rather than for sale that the country has everything to gain by Our work, and we shall be able to meet the situation squarely without withdrawing a single step when we obtain control over the reins of Government.
('85', 45, 2, 12, 93307) J. I presume what you mean is that we should direct all our efforts towards cloth self sufficiency, i.e., towards spinning for one’s own consumption.
('85', 45, 3, 13, 93457) G. Exactly so.
('85', 45, 3, 14, 93472) But as I have no personal experience about it I cannot insist on it.
('85', 45, 3, 15, 93541) I first introduced khadi and only later studied its implications and experimented with it.
('85', 45, 3, 16, 93632) I find that I have been deceiving myself.
('85', 45, 3, 17, 93674) What I gave to the people was money in the form of wages and assured them that it contained swaraj.
('85', 45, 3, 18, 93774) People took me at my word and believed me, and continue to believe me.
('85', 45, 3, 19, 93845) But I have now my own misgivings as to how far such khadi can lead to swaraj.
('85', 45, 3, 20, 93923) I am afraid that khadi has no future if we continue it as today.
('85', 45, 4, 21, 93988) J. Do you visualize a stage in which the khadi bhandars running presently in the cities will be closed down?
('85', 45, 5, 22, 94097) G. Of course I do.
('85', 45, 6, 23, 94116) J. We shall then have to supply khadi to the people in lieu of yarn alone.
('85', 45, 7, 24, 94191) G. When we saw that we could not proceed without spinning we learnt spinning.
('85', 45, 7, 25, 94269) But we did not take to weaving.
('85', 45, 7, 26, 94301) However, now we feel that weavers will also have to be trained in the same manner.
('85', 45, 7, 27, 94384) Whatever changes we want to introduce we must introduce intelligently and with discrimination.
('85', 45, 7, 28, 94479) I may recall what we did about living wages in spinning.
('85', 45, 7, 29, 94536) We went along certain lines.
('85', 45, 7, 30, 94565) Slowly it dawned upon us that khadi so
('85', 46, 0, 1, 94604) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 47
('85', 46, 1, 2, 94646) produced was no philanthropy but an exploitation of spinners.
('85', 46, 1, 3, 94708) We then raised the wages.
('85', 46, 1, 4, 94734) I pleaded for eight annas.
('85', 46, 1, 5, 94761) The rest of you insisted on three annas.
('85', 46, 1, 6, 94802) I agreed to your three annas.
('85', 46, 1, 7, 94832) Then you raised it to four annas.
('85', 46, 1, 8, 94866) Similarly we may proceed in our new attempt.
('85', 46, 1, 9, 94911) First you must accept the principle, later we shall proceed in the light of our experience.

('85', 46, 1, 11, 95087) Think over them.
('85', 46, 1, 12, 95104) We have got our machinery in every province.
('85', 46, 1, 13, 95149) Provincial organizers are already there.
('85', 46, 1, 14, 95190) Call some of the workers and discuss the matter in detail with them.
('85', 46, 1, 15, 95259) True, it will mean some curtailment of our present work.

('85', 46, 2, 21, 95724) J. It means we shall have to stop the large scale sale of khadi in the cities and instead ask the people to take up spinning for themselves.

('85', 46, 4, 35, 96881) This is the situation.
('85', 46, 4, 36, 96904) I wonder how far the experiment you suggest can succeed under these circumstances.

('85', 46, 5, 38, 97108) None of us should harbour this idea.

('85', 46, 5, 40, 97224) The difference between khadi and mill cloth would then be that while a mill provides employment to a
('85', 47, 0, 1, 97325) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 47, 1, 2, 97366) few thousand people in a city, khadi brings a crore of rupees to those scattered about in fifteen thousand villages.
('85', 47, 1, 3, 97483) Both must then be classified as industries, and we would hardly be justified in asking anybody to put on khadi and boycott mill cloth.
('85', 47, 1, 4, 97618) Nor can such khadi claim to be the herald of swaraj.
('85', 47, 1, 5, 97671) On the other hand we have claimed that the real significance of khadi is that it is a means for uplifting the villages and thereby generating in the people the spontaneous strength for swaraj.
('85', 47, 1, 6, 97864) Such a claim cannot then be sustained.
('85', 47, 1, 7, 97903) It will not do to continue to help the villagers by appealing to the philanthropic sentiments of city dwellers.
('85', 47, 1, 8, 98015) What is required is that the villagers should be made strong to face life’s problems and march ahead.

('85', 48, 1, 2, 100112) J. But a closure of the sales would mean a suspension of spinning for wages.
('85', 48, 2, 3, 100189) G. Of course.

('85', 52, 1, 2, 106277) 55. DISCUSSION WITH SHRIKRISHNADAS JAJU
('85', 52, 2, 3, 106317) October 14, 1944
('85', 52, 3, 4, 106334) J. If your programme of village reconstruction as a whole is to be taken up, we must select and train efficient workers.
('85', 52, 4, 5, 106455) Then there will be the question of training workers for which we would have to start vidyalayas in every province and frame syllabi for them.
('85', 52, 4, 6, 106597) There is a great dearth of able teachers.
('85', 52, 4, 7, 106639) Our first grade workers have confined themselves to their particular areas—to their village, tehsil or district.
('85', 52, 5, 8, 106752) I do not quite see how the new work can be accomplished unless we divert some of these workers from their field to the training centres.
('85', 52, 5, 9, 106889) Who else can impart the right attitude and approach to village workers?
('85', 52, 6, 10, 106961) G. Khadi work started in the beginning from a single centre.
('85', 52, 6, 11, 107022) So also now we may begin with only one training centre.
('85', 52, 6, 12, 107078) We shall prepare graduates there and send them to other centres.
('85', 52, 6, 13, 107143) They will produce other workers who will start yet more centres.
('85', 52, 7, 14, 107208) J. It may involve a lot of time, from five to even ten years.
('85', 52, 8, 15, 107270) G. Possibly, but I do not think so.
('85', 52, 8, 16, 107306) Our first batch will consist of those who have already enough prior preparation, and so they will not take long to go out as full fledged workers.
('85', 52, 8, 17, 107453) Again, as soon as they have acquired a certain amount of efficiency we shall ask them to go out to the villages and add to their store of knowledge by dint of actual experience in the field.
('85', 52, 8, 18, 107644) I do not, therefore, feel that a large amount of time will have to be spent on training.
('85', 52, 8, 19, 107733) But even if it is, we should not worry.
('85', 52, 8, 20, 107773) If we do not get workers of the highest quality it does not matter.
('85', 52, 8, 21, 107841) We will try to obtain the finest material, but be ready to do with what we can get at present.
('85', 52, 9, 22, 107936) J. The workers we got in 1920 proved their worth.
('85', 52, 9, 23, 107986) Thereafter we did not secure that high type of workers in so large a measure.
('85', 52, 9, 24, 108064) Some did come indeed, and do come, but in very small numbers.
('85', 52, 10, 25, 108126) G. The fact is our method was defective and there was little in our programme to attract the better type.
('85', 52, 10, 26, 108232) There seemed to be little scope for intellectual development in our work.
('85', 52, 10, 27, 108306) Hence a large number of people did not feel attracted to it.
('85', 52, 10, 28, 108367) Besides the remunerative attraction present in other fields was not there.
('85', 52, 10, 29, 108442) But what was worse, a sort of ignorance and inertia characterized the khadi workers, which made others look down on them.
('85', 52, 10, 30, 108564) People felt that khadi workers did not dress properly, looked dirty and were quite often devoid of common sense.
('85', 52, 10, 31, 108677) The workers did not have adequate knowledge of the science of khadi and so did little to explain it to the people.
('85', 52, 10, 32, 108792) They were
('85', 53, 0, 1, 108802) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 53, 1, 2, 108843) often not in a position to answer the simple questions of those who wanted to know.
('85', 53, 1, 3, 108927) We did settle in the villages where we provided work to the villagers.
('85', 53, 1, 4, 108998) But the intellectual among us did not, to any large extent.
('85', 53, 1, 5, 109058) The few who worked did not have the attitude of an anxious and earnest devotee eager to explain his viewpoint to the people.
('85', 53, 1, 6, 109183) 1 If we had we would have become such experts in our work that we would have been in a position to declare before economists, “We know all that you know.
('85', 53, 1, 7, 109337) But you lack the practical knowledge that we have.
('85', 53, 1, 8, 109388) This you can learn from us.”
('85', 53, 2, 9, 109417) J. True.
('85', 53, 2, 10, 109426) Our knowledge is incomplete and we have very many defects.
('85', 53, 2, 11, 109485) But our scale of measuring values is also different.
('85', 53, 3, 12, 109538) G. May be, but we must have the capacity to tell them that their scale is not right.
('85', 53, 4, 13, 109623) J. But how to compare moral values with material values?
('85', 53, 5, 14, 109680) G. Then you could at least place those moral values before them and prove their worth.
('85', 53, 5, 15, 109767) If I come to realize today that khadi alone is not going to last I shall have to proclaim it to the world.
('85', 53, 5, 16, 109874) So far as the material value of khadi goes, even Government records show that there is a place for the spinning wheel as a means of relief, like stone breaking, road making, etc.
('85', 53, 5, 17, 110053) You also can establish this much that khadi has an invariable place as a relief measure.
('85', 53, 5, 18, 110142) But what we are required to prove above all is the need for khadi to establish a strong, non violent village economy.
('85', 53, 5, 19, 110260) We shall see what difficulties we come across in working the programme of self sufficiency.
('85', 53, 5, 20, 110352) Commercial khadi may continue for a time, but the essential programme of the A.I.S.A. hereafter must be that of self sufficiency, and workers should concentrate all their thought and energy on it.
('85', 53, 6, 21, 110549) Khadi: Why and How, pp.
('85', 53, 7, 22, 110573) 1 The Hindi here has: “But a sufficient number of intelligent workers did not come forward from amongst us to work in the villages and those who did so did not learn the art of explaining their viewpoint to an anxious or earnest enquirer.”

('85', 57, 0, 1, 114859) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 57, 1, 2, 114900) 62. FOREWORD
('85', 57, 2, 3, 114913) SEVAGRAM, October 16, 1944
('85', 57, 3, 4, 114940) Acharya Shriman Narayan Agrawal is one of those young men who have sacrificed a prosperous, perhaps even brilliant, career for the service of the Motherland.
('85', 57, 3, 5, 115098) Moreover, he happens to be in full sympathy with the way of life for which I stand.
('85', 57, 3, 6, 115182) This brochure is an attempt to interpret it in terms of modern political science.
('85', 57, 3, 7, 115264) Acharya Agrawal seems to have made an earnest study of modern literature on the subject.
('85', 57, 3, 8, 115353) I am sorry to have to say that I have not gone through the treatise with the attention it deserves.
('85', 57, 3, 9, 115453) Nevertheless I have read enough of it to be able to say that he has not misrepresented me in any place.
('85', 57, 3, 10, 115557) There is no pretence at an exhaustive presentation of the implications of the charkha economics.
('85', 57, 3, 11, 115654) It claims to be a comparative study of the charkha economics based on non violence and the industrial economics which to be paying must be based on violence, i.e., exploitation of the non industrialized countries.
('85', 57, 3, 12, 115868) Let me not anticipate the author’s argument.
('85', 57, 3, 13, 115913) I commend the treatise to the careful attention of every student of the present deplorable condition of the country.
('85', 57, 4, 14, 116030) The Gandhian Plan of Economic Development for India
('85', 57, 5, 15, 116082) 63. A FOREWORD
('85', 57, 6, 16, 116097) SEVAGRAM, October 16, 1944
('85', 57, 7, 17, 116124) Mrs. Vijayalaxmi Pandit has asked me to pen a few words about the late Ranjit Pandit’s unfinished rendering of Ritusanhar.
('85', 57, 7, 18, 116247) I consider myself wholly unfit to do justice to the author’s effort nor does Vijayalaxmi expect me to attempt the impossible.
('85', 57, 7, 19, 116373) But the touching circumstances under which Ranjit Pandit made the effort need emphasising.
('85', 57, 7, 20, 116464) It is remakable how much India owes to political imprisonments.
('85', 57, 7, 21, 116528) Lokmanya’s celebrated work on the Gita would not have seen the light of day but for his imprisonment nor Jawaharlal Nehru’s world known works.
('85', 57, 7, 22, 116671) Ranjit Pandit’s Rajtarangini and his labours on Ritusanhar might not have been but for his imprison ments.
('85', 57, 7, 23, 116778) And he was ailing in the prison.
('85', 57, 7, 24, 116811) His literary labours made him forget his pain.
('85', 57, 7, 25, 116858) Instead of a preface the author’s introductory notes
('85', 58, 0, 1, 116911) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 59
('85', 58, 1, 2, 116953) are deeply interesting and instructive.
('85', 58, 1, 3, 116993) It reveals to us Ranjit Pandit as a patriot and scholar.
('85', 58, 1, 4, 117050) Having known him intimately I know what talents he had.
('85', 58, 1, 5, 117106) It is a sad thought that such a son of India should have died in the prime of life.
('85', 58, 1, 6, 117190) I congratulate Vijayalaxmi on giving to India and the world her husband’s last labour of love.
('85', 58, 2, 7, 117285) M. K. GANDHI
('85', 58, 3, 8, 117298) From a copy : Pyarelal Papers.
('85', 58, 3, 9, 117329) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('85', 58, 3, 10, 117364) Courtesy: Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar

('85', 62, 1, 2, 122765) 72. LETTER TO SOHANLAL DWIVEDI
('85', 62, 2, 3, 122796) SEVAGRAM, October 16, 1944
('85', 62, 3, 4, 122823) BHAI SOHANLALJI, I have gone through both your letters.
('85', 62, 3, 5, 122879) I had a vague impression that you liked my idea.
('85', 62, 3, 6, 122928) It was this: It is a bad practice to over price a book to secure donations.
('85', 62, 3, 7, 123004) And associating a name with such a price rise is worse.
('85', 62, 3, 8, 123060) I have conveyed the same view to Ghanshyamdasji.
('85', 62, 4, 9, 123109) What shall I say about the merits and demerits of your work?
('85', 62, 4, 10, 123170) I have no capacity to judge poetry.
('85', 62, 4, 11, 123206) How can I speak about poems written in my own praise?
('85', 62, 4, 12, 123260) Of course I can say you have put in a lot of labour and no worthy labour is ever wasted.
('85', 62, 5, 13, 123349) If you sell your work at market price we would at least know its comparative value.
('85', 62, 5, 14, 123433) No special effort should be made to sponsor the sale.
('85', 62, 5, 15, 123487) Many books sell on their own merit without any effort.
('85', 62, 5, 16, 123542) You may realize your own expenses from the amount you have collected and, with the permission of the donors, send the balance to me for Harijan work or donate it for some altruistic work.
('85', 62, 5, 17, 123730) You can make public use of this letter.
('85', 62, 6, 18, 123770) Blessings from BAPU

('85', 65, 1, 2, 127124) 78. LETTER TO ARUNCHANDRA GUPTA
('85', 65, 2, 3, 127156) October 18, 1944
('85', 65, 3, 4, 127173) DEAR FRIEND,
('85', 65, 4, 5, 127186) Your letter of October 2nd as also your letter of 27 7 1944 have been duly received by Gandhiji.
('85', 65, 4, 6, 127283) Thanks for your good wishes.
('85', 65, 5, 7, 127312) What you say about Bengal is true.
('85', 65, 5, 8, 127347) The matter is deeply exercising Gandhiji’s mind.
('85', 65, 5, 9, 127396) But at present the scope for effective action seems to be very limited indeed.
('85', 65, 5, 10, 127475) He feels the handicap and the limitation galls him.
