('85', 75, 0, 1, 139071) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 75, 1, 2, 139112) 99. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('85', 75, 2, 3, 139139) SEVAGRAM, October 22, 1944
('85', 75, 3, 4, 139166) Congressmen should read without passion Dr. Mahmud’s letters to the Viceroy and his statement to the Press releasing those letters.
('85', 75, 3, 5, 139298) The motive in writing the letters was undoubtedly pure.
('85', 75, 3, 6, 139354) He did not want his release before that of his colleagues of the Working Committee and yet the Government could not, consistently with their declaration, detain Dr. Mahmud after his unequivocal dissociation from the very start with the civil resistance clause of the A. I. C. C. Resolution 1 of 8th August 1942. Where Dr. Mahmud erred was in not informing his fellow detenus of the letters.
('85', 75, 3, 7, 139745) If he suppressed himself for so long he could not, without consultation and without authority from them, write to the Government what his mind was at the time the Resolution was passed.
('85', 75, 3, 8, 139931) The practical question for Congressmen is whether they are to make use of Dr. Mahmud’s services or ostracize him for the ‘impropriety’ he admits having committed.
('85', 75, 3, 9, 140094) I have no doubt whatsoever that they should make the best use possible of the services for which his long and unbroken connection with the Congress makes him eminently fit.
('85', 75, 3, 10, 140267) For me, in spite of his indiscretion, he remains the same dear friend he has been since the Khilafat and before.
('85', 75, 3, 11, 140380) The public know my connection with the father in law, the late Maulana Mazharul Haque 2.
('85', 75, 4, 12, 140469) The Hindu, 24 10 1944
('85', 75, 5, 13, 140491) 1 Vide Appendix “Resolution passed by All India Congress Committee”, 8 8 1942. 2 A nationalist leader from Bihar; one of the founders and, later, President of the Muslim League.
('85', 75, 5, 14, 140669) He supported Gandhiji during the Champaran and Civil Disobedience movements.
('85', 76, 0, 1, 140746) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 77
('85', 76, 1, 2, 140788) 100. HINTS FOR CONSTRUCTIVE WORKERS 1
('85', 76, 2, 3, 140826) Workers should definitely realize that the constructive programme is the non violent and truthful way of winning purna swaraj.
('85', 76, 2, 4, 140953) Its wholesale fulfilment is complete independence.
('85', 76, 2, 5, 141004) Imagine all the forty crores of people engaged in the constructive programme which is designed to build up the nation from the very bottom upward.
('85', 76, 2, 6, 141151) Can anybody dispute the proposition that it must mean complete independence in every sense of the expression, including the ousting of foreign domination?
('85', 76, 2, 7, 141306) When the critics laugh at the proposition, what they mean is that forty crores of people will never co operate in the effort to fulfil the programme.
('85', 76, 2, 8, 141456) No doubt there is considerable truth in the scoff.
('85', 76, 2, 9, 141507) My answer is, it is worth the attempt.
('85', 76, 2, 10, 141546) Given an indomitable will on the part of a band of earnest workers, the programme is as workable as any other and more so than most.
('85', 76, 2, 11, 141679) Anyway, I have no substitute for it, if it is to be based on non violence.
('85', 76, 2, 12, 141754) Civil disobedience, mass or individual, is an aid to constructive effort and is a full substitute for armed revolt.
('85', 76, 2, 13, 141870) Just as military training is necessary for armed revolt, training in constructive effort is equally necessary for civil resistance.
('85', 76, 2, 14, 142002) And just as the use of arms becomes necessary only when an occasion demands it, even so is the use of civil resistance only occasional.
('85', 76, 2, 15, 142138) Therefore workers will never be on the look out for civil resistance.
('85', 76, 2, 16, 142208) They will hold themselves in readiness, if the constructive effort is sought to be defeated.
('85', 76, 2, 17, 142301) To take one or two illustrations, effort for communal friendship cannot be defeated, political pacts can.
('85', 76, 2, 18, 142407) But political pacts are required because of the previous lack of friendship.
('85', 76, 2, 19, 142484) Similarly khadi manufacture and its use cannot be defeated if both become fairly universal.
('85', 76, 2, 20, 142576) The manufacture and use are not to be brought about by imposing them upon the people, but they have to be intelligently accepted by them as some of the necessary items of the freedom movement, when it is worked from the villages as units.
('85', 76, 2, 21, 142815) Pioneers even in such programmes are likely to be obstructed.
('85', 76, 2, 22, 142877) They have had to go through the fire of suffering throughout the
('85', 76, 3, 23, 142942) 1 This was sent to the Workers’ Conference held in Bombay on October 28 and 29 under the presidentship of N. V. Gadgil.
('85', 76, 3, 24, 143062) Congressmen from Maharashtra, Gujarat and Karnataka also participated in the Conference.
('85', 77, 0, 1, 143151) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 77, 1, 2, 143192) There is no swaraj without suffering.
('85', 77, 1, 3, 143230) In violence truth is the greatest sufferer; in non violence truth is ever triumphant.
('85', 77, 1, 4, 143316) If this preliminary observation has gone home to the reader he will find the constructive programme to be full of deep interest.
('85', 77, 1, 5, 143445) It should prove as absorbing as politics so called and platform oratory.
('85', 77, 1, 6, 143518) The detailed constructive programme is to be found in my pamphlet 1 on it, and Dr. Rajendra Prasad’s 2 which is a running commentary on it.
('85', 77, 1, 7, 143658) It should be remembered that it is illustrative, not exhaustive.
('85', 77, 1, 8, 143723) Local circumstances may suggest many more items not touched in the printed programme.
('85', 77, 1, 9, 143809) These are beyond the scope of a treatise on an all India programme.
('85', 77, 1, 10, 143877) They are necessarily for local workers to find out and do the needful.
('85', 77, 1, 11, 143948) In these hints I have singled out some items for fuller emphasis in the light of experience gained since the publication of the programme.
('85', 77, 1, 12, 144087) The kisan or the peasant, whether as a landless labourer or a labouring proprietor, comes first.
('85', 77, 1, 13, 144184) He is the son of the soil which rightly belongs or should belong to him, not to the absentee landlord or zamindar.
('85', 77, 1, 14, 144299) But in the non violent way the labourer cannot forcibly eject the absentee landlord.
('85', 77, 1, 15, 144384) He has so to work as to make it impossible for the landlord to exploit him.
('85', 77, 1, 16, 144460) Closest co operation amongst the peasants is absolutely necessary.
('85', 77, 1, 17, 144527) To this end, special organizing bodies or committees should be formed where there are none and those already in existence should be reformed where necessary.
('85', 77, 1, 18, 144685) The kisans are for the most part illiterate.
('85', 77, 1, 19, 144730) Both adults and young persons of school going age should be educated.
('85', 77, 1, 20, 144800) This applies to men as well as women.
('85', 77, 1, 21, 144838) Where they are landless labourers their wages should be brought to a level that would ensure a decent living which should mean balanced food, dwelling houses and clothing, which should satisfy health requirements.
('85', 77, 1, 22, 145052) Land laws should be examined.
('85', 77, 1, 23, 145082) The peasant indebtedness offers a limitless field for research.
('85', 77, 1, 24, 145146) The problem of cattle too is an integral part of agriculture in India and therefore requires the attention of workers skilled in this very intricate and somewhat baffling problem.
('85', 77, 1, 25, 145326) Closely allied to the kisan work is labour.
('85', 77, 1, 26, 145370) Here labour means industrial labour and, therefore, concentrated and centralized and
('85', 77, 2, 27, 145455) 1 Vide “Constructive Programme: Its Meaning and Place;” 13 12 1941. 2 ibid
('85', 78, 0, 1, 145530) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 79
('85', 78, 1, 2, 145572) much more limited in scope.
('85', 78, 1, 3, 145600) Moreover, it lends itself readily to political handling; being necessarily confined to the cities it attracts workers more easily than kisan work.
('85', 78, 1, 4, 145747) As part of constructive programme its primary aim is elevation of labour to its deserved status.
('85', 78, 1, 5, 145844) Therefore a labour worker’s aim should be to raise the moral and intellectual height of labour and thus by sheer merit to make him or her capable not merely of bettering his or her material condition but making labour master of the means of production instead of being the slave that it is.
('85', 78, 1, 6, 146135) Capital should be labour’s servant, not its master.
('85', 78, 1, 7, 146187) Labour should be able to support itself during strikes.
('85', 78, 1, 8, 146243) (Labour should be taught the science of conducting a successful non violent Labour should be made conscious of its duty from whose performance rights follow as a matter of course.
('85', 78, 1, 9, 146423) In a concrete form: (a) Labour should have its own unions.
('85', 78, 1, 10, 146482) (b) Education, both general and scientific, of both men and women should be regularly undertaken through night schools.
('85', 78, 1, 11, 146602) (c) Children of labourers should be educated after the Basic Education style.
('85', 78, 1, 12, 146680) (d) There should be a hospital, a creche and a maternity home attached to every centre.
('85', 78, 1, 13, 146768) (e) Labour strike.) All the work I have mentioned could be only done through unions mentioned in (a).
('85', 78, 1, 14, 146870) To my knowledge the Ahmedabad Union is the best managed union.
('85', 78, 1, 15, 146933) This does not mean that it has reached my ideal.
('85', 78, 1, 16, 146982) It is trying to.
('85', 78, 1, 17, 146999) If all the unions worked in the same direction, the lot of labour would be infinitely better than it is today.
('85', 78, 1, 18, 147110) Labour united and morally and intellectually trained would any day be superior to capital.
('85', 78, 1, 19, 147201) 1 Next in importance is the student class above the age of 12. Indeed if we had enough workers of the right type, I would go so far as to say that we should work among them as soon as they begin learning as infants.

('85', 80, 11, 20, 150658) 104. TALK WITH FRIENDS [On or after October 22, 1944] 2
('85', 80, 12, 21, 150714) Friends and co workers tried to argue with him.
('85', 80, 12, 22, 150762) He had just presented to them his enlarged and revitalized programme of constructive work.
('85', 80, 12, 23, 150853) Would not the great wave of emotion, which his fast would set up, disturb the “peace and tranquillity” in which many of them were settling down to work?
('85', 80, 12, 24, 151006) Gandhiji replied: But that is just what I want.
('85', 80, 12, 25, 151054) I do not want you or anybody else “to settle down” to anything.
('85', 80, 12, 26, 151118) In the midst of this frightful triple do so because I know the joy of dying.
('85', 80, 12, 27, 151195) Because I know that joy and amazing thing is that I still survive and can feel the joy of living.
('85', 80, 12, 28, 151293) I can grief are the obverse and reverse of the same coin, I remain unaffected

('85', 81, 2, 3, 151635) Must you speak through the pangs of hunger?

('85', 81, 3, 11, 151958) But I would face that risk if the upshot of living a conscious life of truth and non violence for over half a century is that India, too, has to go through a blood bath.
('85', 81, 3, 12, 152128) “Why should you not in that case invite the risk of chaos in pursuit of non violence The slaughter of soldiers, civilians and truth, it is impossible to settle down to anything.
('85', 81, 3, 13, 152306) One has ceaselessly to be on the march body and soul.
('85', 81, 3, 14, 152360) My business is to stir up myself and my surroundings and shake us out of our complacency.
('85', 81, 4, 15, 152450) What reason had he to think that his fast would compel the people to think instead of paralysing their thinking?
('85', 81, 5, 16, 152563) While it might be presumptuous on the part of a puny individual like himself to think, he replied, that his fast would galvanize the people, it was his faith that he had not striven all those years in vain to live a life of truth and non violence, that gave him the right to speak through his fast.
('85', 81, 5, 17, 152862) Today millions are experiencing the pangs of hunger in passive helplessness.
('85', 81, 5, 18, 152939) Even a small fraction of this suffering undergone willingly and with knowledge could change the face of the situation.
('85', 81, 5, 19, 153058) How can I speak to these millions, or identify myself with them, without [under]taking this fast and knowing myself what pangs of hunger mean?
('85', 81, 6, 20, 153201) He could not point to any single thing in explanation of his urge to fast, he said, but the whole situation in its totality overwhelmed him.
('85', 81, 6, 21, 153342) The friends were not satisfied.

('85', 81, 6, 23, 153520) Because I do not want anarchy or chaos.
('85', 81, 6, 24, 153560) I must work for orderliness, not anarchy.
('85', 81, 6, 25, 153602) But if in that attempt anarchy comes in my way, I would not be deterred by it.
('85', 81, 6, 26, 153681) The world is thrilled by the reckless bravery of the Japanese.
('85', 81, 6, 27, 153744) Far greater courage and bravery are expected of non violence at this juncture if the law of the Jungle is to be replaced by the law of love.

('85', 82, 1, 2, 153979) 105. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('85', 82, 2, 3, 154007) WARDHA, October 23, 1944
('85', 82, 3, 4, 154032) Mr. Horniman 1 thoughtfully sent the following wire to Mr. Pyarelal on the 19th:
('85', 82, 4, 5, 154113) Can you confirm or deny the Allahabad report that Gandhiji is contemplating a fast to achieve communal unity?
('85', 82, 4, 6, 154223) Pyarelal sent the following reply:
('85', 82, 5, 7, 154258) Thanks.
('85', 82, 5, 8, 154266) Report without foundation.
('85', 82, 5, 9, 154293) The reply is accurate, in that I do not contemplate any fast to achieve communal unity or any particular end.
('85', 82, 5, 10, 154403) Yet the reply is not complete.
('85', 82, 5, 11, 154434) Ever since my premature discharge, I have been saying to myself and some friends that yet another fast is in store for me.
('85', 82, 5, 12, 154557) Of late what was vaguely felt has been taking a concrete shape, and so I have been sharing the feeling with a larger circle of friends.
('85', 82, 5, 13, 154693) The report has now crept into the Press.
('85', 82, 5, 14, 154734) It is as well for the public, therefore, to have a correct version of the talks I have been having with friends.
('85', 82, 5, 15, 154847) Fasting has a definite place in the scheme of satyagraha.
('85', 82, 5, 16, 154905) It is the last weapon in the armoury of non violence.
('85', 82, 5, 17, 154959) It is taken by way of penance, purification, protest.
('85', 82, 5, 18, 155013) If I am at fault, I must do penance.
('85', 82, 5, 19, 155050) My non violence rebels against the organized violence that surrounds me.
('85', 82, 5, 20, 155123) It takes many shapes.
('85', 82, 5, 21, 155145) Lying is as much violence as doing physical harm to a person.
('85', 82, 5, 22, 155207) I do not here refer only to the violence of the rulers.
('85', 82, 5, 23, 155263) I know this, that non violence has to be most active in the face of what may seem to be invincible violence.
('85', 82, 5, 24, 155372) But nothing is clear, nothing is certain.
('85', 82, 5, 25, 155414) What seems to me to be a call may be no call at all.
('85', 82, 5, 26, 155467) I am, therefore, testing myself, discussing the pros and cons with friends, and allowing myself to be acted upon.
('85', 82, 5, 27, 155581) I have never made fasting a fad.
('85', 82, 5, 28, 155614) I have never looked forward to it and yet it has often brought solace to the agonized soul, for real fasting puts the soul in tune with the Maker.
('85', 82, 5, 29, 155761) It puts life into one’s prayer.
('85', 82, 5, 30, 155793) All the while, I am discussing the feeling with friends.
('85', 82, 5, 31, 155850) I am praying for light and guidance, without
('85', 82, 6, 32, 155895) 1 B. G. Horniman of The Bombay Chronicle
('85', 83, 0, 1, 155936) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 83, 1, 2, 155977) which there will be no fast.
('85', 83, 1, 3, 156006) I ask for the co operation of friends throughout the world in my search for light.

('85', 86, 6, 14, 160445) 113. NOTE TO ANAND T. HINGORANI
('85', 86, 7, 15, 160477) October 23, 1944
('85', 86, 8, 16, 160494) There is no harm in sitting near me but on such occasions do ply the takli as Mahadev and Kripalani used to do.
('85', 86, 8, 17, 160606) Then you will not be stealing from God’s time.
('85', 86, 8, 18, 160653) The takli is our silent companion.
('85', 86, 8, 19, 160688) Without making any noise it keeps turning out yarn which the world needs.
('85', 86, 8, 20, 160762) While plying the takli we can see and hear everything.
('85', 86, 8, 21, 160817) I would go so far as to believe that with God’s grace, being absorbed in this sacrificial activity even your hearing may be restored to you.

('85', 88, 7, 21, 163897) In the first place I doubt very much whether Mr. Jinnah or the Hindu Sabha men will make any response as they can very easily dispose of me by saying that I have got no goods to deliver and I have got no party behind me.
('85', 88, 7, 22, 164118) Secondly—and this is more important—I fear that in a conference like this where people will be actuated by party feeling and will be afraid of criticism from their own following if they take an independent line, no solid results can be achieved and indeed what I fear is that our differences will come to the surface.
('85', 88, 7, 23, 164436) It is for this reason that I think that if you and Mr. Jinnah can appoint such a committee and that committee can submit a report, it may pave the way for a larger conference at that stage.
('85', 88, 7, 24, 164626) I am, therefore, definitely of the opinion that a conference should not be called at this stage.

('85', 90, 4, 10, 166696) 121. TALK WITH MRIDULA SARABHAI 3
('85', 90, 5, 11, 166730) SEVAGRAM, October 26, 1944 The unbearable forces of injustice, exploitation and falsehood prevailing in this country and the world stifle me.
('85', 90, 5, 12, 166872) Government subsists on falsehood, but amongst us the number of people, who subsist on this falsehood and who have made injustice and exploitation the principles of their lives, is not small.
('85', 90, 5, 13, 167063) In the presence of this, good elements of life are entirely suppressed and appear helpless.
('85', 90, 5, 14, 167155) There is nothing left like moral public opinion.
('85', 90, 5, 15, 167204) On the one hand, there is a combination of violence effected on an unprecedented scale while, on the other, I have laid a claim that non violence has strength enough to oppose any amount of well organized and banded violence, and how to achieve it is the question.
('85', 90, 5, 16, 167469) There are too good elements in India and the world, but how to awaken them?
('85', 90, 5, 17, 167545) How can it be done?
('85', 90, 5, 18, 167565) Fast is the last resort of satyagraha.
('85', 90, 5, 19, 167604) When people cannot be made to do anything it is the right of a lone satyagrahi to resort to this final measure.
('85', 90, 5, 20, 167716) If my fast comes about it is possible that it will be the complaining voice of the exploited humanity before the world.
('85', 90, 6, 21, 167836) 1 The addressee had broken down while taking a walk alone.
('85', 90, 6, 22, 167895) 2 Daughter of Mohanlal Nayyar 3 The report in Gujarati was released to the Press by Mridula Sarabhai but subsequently she withdrew it on being informed that Gandhiji intended to issue a statement on the subject, which however is not available.
('85', 90, 6, 23, 168139) While sending this translation to the Home Department, the Deputy Director of the Intelligence Bureau inter alia wrote: “These notes are of interest as they furnish some indications of the working of Gandhi’s mind.”
('85', 91, 0, 1, 168355) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 91, 1, 2, 168396) Those who can foresee the possibility of mass movement, against the prevailing falsehood, they are at liberty to do it.
('85', 91, 1, 3, 168516) But the individual or the individuals who do it must shoulder its complete responsibility.
('85', 91, 1, 4, 168607) I cannot give my blessings to it.
('85', 91, 1, 5, 168641) Today, the circumstances are not favourable for it.
('85', 91, 1, 6, 168693) Besides, the public is full of resentment, and therefore the mass satyagraha would result in violence.
('85', 91, 1, 7, 168796) Our little violence will be met by hundredfold violence by Government.
('85', 91, 1, 8, 168867) We should not expect merciful treatment from them.
('85', 91, 1, 9, 168918) This does not mean that we should be a mute spectator of it, or that we should continue to suffer it.
('85', 91, 1, 10, 169020) Those who consider the present condition as oppressive, and find the laws encouraging injustice and exploitation and depriving of one’s liberty, they can definitely resort to satyagraha.
('85', 91, 1, 11, 169207) Only that it should be done individually and it should not be devoid of politeness.
('85', 91, 1, 12, 169291) It can only be done with absolute non violence.
('85', 91, 1, 13, 169339) There are good many forces contained in it.
('85', 91, 1, 14, 169383) If a crore of people were to do individual satyagraha it would baffle Government.
('85', 91, 1, 15, 169465) Then Government would either be helpless or resort to use of guns.
('85', 91, 1, 16, 169532) You cannot sit silent after saying that individual satyagraha can be offered.
('85', 91, 1, 17, 169610) It is one’s duty to do it.
('85', 91, 1, 18, 169637) If the public has any stamina, it can oppose thus the looting going on under its nose.
('85', 91, 1, 19, 169724) Leaving aside the question of a crore of people, if all (local) people do so at one place, it is enough.
('85', 91, 1, 20, 169829) If individual satyagraha is not approved, the prevailing falsehood of the present day should be opposed in any other way.
('85', 91, 1, 21, 169951) Today our own people are depriving the public of their food grains.
('85', 91, 1, 22, 170019) If they do not do it, people will not starve.
('85', 91, 1, 23, 170065) The cultivator, who produces food, does not get it to eat in spite of its being there.
('85', 91, 1, 24, 170152) We have no political power, otherwise its remedy would have been found.
('85', 91, 1, 25, 170224) This condition is terrible.
('85', 91, 1, 26, 170252) I cannot tolerate our people behaving thus, and collecting vast fortunes at the cost of people’s starvation.
('85', 91, 1, 27, 170361) If we can rid our people of falsehood and roguery, Government’s falsehood cannot work.
('85', 91, 1, 28, 170448) Let us remove the corruption prevailing everywhere.
('85', 91, 1, 29, 170500) It is already there in the Government, but it has increased to a very great extent among those middlemen who live on brokerage.
('85', 91, 1, 30, 170628) If these people improve by themselves, others would do so.
('85', 91, 1, 31, 170687) Today the chain of violence is made up thus.
('85', 91, 1, 32, 170732) Against this we have to work non violently.
('85', 91, 1, 33, 170776) Fast is the last weapon of non violence.
('85', 91, 1, 34, 170817) Corruption—It is both in the Government and other quarters.

('85', 93, 3, 6, 173793) 122. DISCUSSION WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF HINDUSTANI TALIMI SANGH
('85', 93, 4, 7, 173857) SEVAGRAM, [Before October 27, 1944] 1
('85', 93, 5, 8, 173895) The first question that arose was one bearing on the suggestion that the word ‘basic education’ might be incorporated in the Trust Deed, so as to make it clear to all concerned that the education contemplated under the Fund 2 would be only of the basic type.
('85', 93, 5, 9, 174154) Gandhiji did not approve of it.
('85', 93, 5, 10, 174186) He did not wish to put any restraint upon the trustees.
('85', 93, 5, 11, 174242) If any unit did not want to adopt basic education, he would leave it free to follow any other system approved by the Board.
('85', 93, 5, 12, 174366) But the Talimi Sangh should have the confidence that no one will be able to find a better system than theirs.
('85', 93, 6, 13, 174476) Basic education would forge ahead through its intrinsic merit.
('85', 93, 6, 14, 174539) He knew that the reform would not come by mere argumentation.
('85', 93, 6, 15, 174601) It would come by ocular demonstration.
('85', 93, 6, 16, 174640) If they could carry their experiment to a successful end even in one village, the battle would be half won.
('85', 93, 6, 17, 174748) He was, therefore, content to go slow.
('85', 93, 6, 18, 174787) It was enough that the trustees had agreed to the money being spent for the education and welfare of women and children in the villages exclusively.
('85', 93, 6, 19, 174936) Your work is going chiefly to be among women.
('85', 93, 6, 20, 174982) I have always had a passion to serve womankind.
('85', 93, 6, 21, 175030) Ever since my arrival in India, the women have recognized in me their friend and servant.
('85', 93, 6, 22, 175120) They have come to look upon me as one of themselves.
('85', 93, 6, 23, 175173) I hold radical views about the emancipation of women from their fetters which they mistake for adornment.
('85', 93, 6, 24, 175279) If God wills it, I hope one day to place some of my conclusions before the public when my researches are completed.
('85', 93, 6, 25, 175395) My experience has confirmed me in the view that real advancement of women can come only by and through their own efforts.
('85', 93, 6, 26, 175517) I am, therefore, anxious that as many women workers as possible should be inspired to carry out the Talimi Sangh activities under the Trust.
('85', 93, 7, 27, 175658) The second suggestion put forth by the Talimi Sangh was that the age of the
('85', 93, 8, 28, 175734) 1 The report, date lined “Wardha, October 27, 1944”, mentions this discussion as having taken place “recently”.
('85', 93, 8, 29, 175846) 2 Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund
('85', 94, 0, 1, 175887) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 95
('85', 94, 1, 2, 175929) boys to be covered by the scheme should be raised from 7 to 12.
('85', 94, 2, 3, 175993) Mahatma Gandhi explained why he had agreed to the reduction of the age limit for boys from 12 to 7 years.
('85', 94, 2, 4, 176099) It had been brought to his notice that, if there were equal facilities for the education of boys and girls, the mothers would send the boys to school but not the girls, as they would be loath to spare them from domestic work.
('85', 94, 2, 5, 176325) The result would be that the boys would get a disproportionate share of the benefit and keep out the girls.
('85', 94, 2, 6, 176433) But if in any place a sufficient number of girls was not forthcoming, they could take in boys above the age of seven, on condition that they would have to make room for the girls as soon as the latter came up and that their education was paid for.
('85', 94, 2, 7, 176681) The object was not to shut out boys above seven, but to prevent them from being a burden upon the Memorial Fund.
('85', 94, 2, 8, 176794) The Talimi Sangh should not fall back upon the Fund designed for women.
('85', 94, 2, 9, 176866) All that he was concerned about was that the money of the Kasturba Fund should not be diverted to the use of boys over seven at the expense of girls.
('85', 94, 3, 10, 177016) “Is it desirable that there should be basic schools for girls exclusively if there was not enough room for both?” somebody asked.
('85', 94, 3, 11, 177146) Mahatma Gandhi said he had no objection.
('85', 94, 3, 12, 177187) Supposing crores of boys come to us for education, are we to refuse them for lack of accommodation?
('85', 94, 3, 13, 177287) I tell you I won’t.
('85', 94, 3, 14, 177307) I will let them sit under the shade of a tree, if necessary, put bamboo taklis into their hands and begin to educate them straightway through these.
('85', 94, 4, 15, 177456) As to adult education, Gandhiji observed that it had become clear to him that the scope of basic education had to be extended.
('85', 94, 4, 16, 177583) It should include the education of everybody at every stage of life.
('85', 94, 5, 17, 177652) A basic school teacher must consider himself a universal teacher.
('85', 94, 5, 18, 177718) As soon as he comes in contact with anybody, man or woman, young or old, he should say to himself: ‘Now, what can I give to this person?’
('85', 94, 6, 19, 177856) Won’t that be supererogation on his part?
('85', 94, 6, 20, 177898) Supposing I come across an old man who is dirty and ignorant.
('85', 94, 6, 21, 177960) His village is his universe.
('85', 94, 6, 22, 177989) It would be my job to teach him cleanliness, to remove his ignorance and widen his mental horizon.
('85', 94, 6, 23, 178088) I need not tell him that I am to be his teacher.
('85', 94, 6, 24, 178137) I will try to establish a living contact with his mind and win his confidence.
('85', 94, 6, 25, 178216) He may reject my
('85', 94, 7, 26, 178233) 1 Earlier, talking to a friend, Gandhiji had said he had been thinking hard during his detention over the possibilities of the new education.
('85', 94, 7, 27, 178375) His mind had become restive.
('85', 94, 7, 28, 178404) He said: “We must not rest content with our present achievements, we must penetrate the homes of the children, we must educate their parents; basic education must become literally education for life.”
('85', 95, 0, 1, 178605) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 95, 1, 2, 178646) advances.
('85', 95, 1, 3, 178656) I won’t accept defeat, but continue my effort till I succeed in making friends with him.
('85', 95, 1, 4, 178745) Once that is achieved, the rest must follow.
('85', 95, 1, 5, 178790) Again, I must have my eye on the children right from their birth.
('85', 95, 1, 6, 178856) I will go a step further and say that the work of the educationist begins even before that.
('85', 95, 1, 7, 178948) For instance, if a woman becomes pregnant, Ashadevi will go to her and tell her: ‘I am a mother as you will be.
('85', 95, 1, 8, 179060) I can tell you from my experience what you should do to ensure the health of your unborn baby and your own.’ She will tell the husband what his duty towards his wife is and about his share in the care of their expected baby.
('85', 95, 1, 9, 179285) Thus the basic school teacher will cover the entire span of life.
('85', 95, 1, 10, 179351) Naturally, his activity will cover adult education.
('85', 95, 1, 11, 179403) Some work for adult education is being done in many places.
('85', 95, 1, 12, 179463) It is mostly concentrated among mill hands and the like in big cities.
('85', 95, 1, 13, 179534) No one has really touched the village.
('85', 95, 1, 14, 179573) Mere three Rs and lectures on politics won’t satisfy me.
('85', 95, 1, 15, 179630) Adult education of my conception must make men and women better citizens all round.
('85', 95, 1, 16, 179714) To work out the syllabus and to organize the work of adult education is a more difficult task than preparation of the seven years’ course for children.
('85', 95, 1, 17, 179866) The common central feature of both will be the imparting of education through village crafts.
('85', 95, 1, 18, 179960) Agriculture will play an important part in adult education under the basic scheme.
('85', 95, 1, 19, 180043) Literary instruction must be there.Much information will be given orally.
('85', 95, 1, 20, 180117) There will be books more for the teachers than the taught.
('85', 95, 1, 21, 180176) We must teach the majority how to behave towards the minority and vice versa.
('85', 95, 1, 22, 180254) The right type of adult education should teach good neighbourliness and cut at the very root of untouchability and communal problem.
('85', 95, 1, 23, 180387) The particular industry which is to serve as the medium of instruction will be determined by local conditions in each place.
('85', 95, 1, 24, 180512) For instance, people in a village might tell you that they are interested in agriculture, but they are not interested in the spinning wheel.
('85', 95, 1, 25, 180653) In that case, you will choose the former as the medium of instruction.
('85', 95, 1, 26, 180724) You could make a beginning by taking a census of its cattle.
('85', 95, 1, 27, 180785) For instance, I find that almost everyone in Sevagram has a bullock and a bullock cart.
('85', 95, 1, 28, 180873) It seems wasteful.
('85', 95, 1, 29, 180892) The villagers should be taught co operation.
('85', 95, 1, 30, 180937) Again, we must inculcate in them the right principles of relationship between men and women.
('85', 95, 1, 31, 181030) Men get almost double the women’s wages for identical work.
('85', 95, 1, 32, 181090) Sometimes men sit lazily at home and smoke while the women toil the whole day.
('85', 95, 1, 33, 181169) People should be
('85', 96, 0, 1, 181186) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 97
('85', 96, 1, 2, 181228) made to realize that this is doubly wrong and ought to go.
('85', 96, 1, 3, 181287) If you agree with me that the scope of basic education should be extended, you might have to change your constitution.

('85', 103, 0, 1, 191558) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 103, 1, 2, 191600) 136. STATEMENT ON PROPOSED FAST 1
('85', 103, 2, 3, 191634) October 29, 1944
('85', 103, 3, 4, 191651) My heart is heavily grieved by the injustice, exploitation and falsehood prevailing and increasing, day by day, in the world.
('85', 103, 3, 5, 191777) The best remedy for it is to awaken the good elements in the whole world.
('85', 103, 3, 6, 191851) Collective civil disobedience is the way for it, but it is not possible today.
('85', 103, 3, 7, 191930) It is very likely that such collective activity will result in violence.
('85', 103, 3, 8, 192003) If we are able to avoid unofficial falsehood and injustice, Government falsehood and injustice will be no more.
('85', 103, 3, 9, 192115) I feel I must do penance by fasting.
('85', 103, 3, 10, 192152) I am asked not to go on fast.
('85', 103, 3, 11, 192182) I do not know when and for what duration it will come but let me say that the way to avoid the fast is in the people’s hands.
('85', 103, 3, 12, 192308) I desire destruction of exploitation, injustice and falsehood.
('85', 103, 3, 13, 192371) If they are destroyed my fast will be unnecessary.
('85', 103, 3, 14, 192422) As a satyagrahi I cannot be a silent spectator of all these things.
('85', 103, 3, 15, 192490) Revolution or collective civil disobedience is not possible and hence I must move on my wheels of non violence through the fast.
('85', 103, 3, 16, 192619) I have expressed my views to someone today.
('85', 103, 3, 17, 192663) I express them to the whole country.
('85', 103, 3, 18, 192700) People can give their contribution in the work which I intend to do.
('85', 103, 3, 19, 192769) I cannot see people starve.
('85', 103, 3, 20, 192797) Their rights are snatched by others.
('85', 103, 3, 21, 192834) Nobody must do this.
('85', 103, 3, 22, 192855) We must avoid falsehood and badmashi.
('85', 103, 3, 23, 192893) We can improve those working as middlemen and thus lessen the burden upon the people.
('85', 103, 3, 24, 192979) Activities of exploitation are in full swing and have become unbearable.
('85', 103, 3, 25, 193052) Government stands firm and is maintaining its position on falsehood.
('85', 103, 3, 26, 193121) But injustice and the policy of exploitation among the people too cannot be ignored 2.
('85', 103, 4, 27, 193208) The Bombay Chronicle, 30 10 1944
('85', 103, 5, 28, 193241) 1 According to the source this is the purport of what Gandhiji said during his discussions with different individuals.
('85', 103, 5, 29, 193360) 2 For a statement issued from Sevagram regarding Gandhiji’s contemplated fast, vide Appendix “A Statement”, 29 10 1944.

('85', 105, 6, 16, 195326) 140. INTERVIEW TO N. G. RANGA 1
('85', 105, 7, 17, 195358) October 29, 1944
('85', 105, 8, 18, 195375) RANGA, You say that the earth rightly belongs or should belong to the peasant 2. By this, do you mean only that the peasant ought to gain control over the land he cultivates or that he should also gain effective voice and power in the society and over the State in which he is obliged to live?
('85', 105, 8, 19, 195669) If the kisans are to have only land and not effective political power, their position will be just as bad as in Soviet Russia where political power has been monopolized by the proletarian dictatorship while peasants were first allowed to gain some holdings and later were deprived of those
('85', 105, 9, 20, 195959) 1 The report of this and the other interview with N. G. Ranga on November 28, 1944, was released to the Press by Pyarelal with the following note: “Soon after his release from prison Prof.
('85', 105, 9, 21, 196148) Ranga saw Gandhiji at Sevagram.
('85', 105, 9, 22, 196180) He had two interviews with him on 29th October, 1944 and 28th November, 1944. It was understood on both sides that the interviews were not for publication.
('85', 105, 9, 23, 196336) As, however, parts of those interviews have already appeared in the Press, I am, under Gandhiji’s instructions, releasing to the Press my full notes of the talks.” At the first interview Prof.

('85', 129, 3, 4, 234001) DEAR SIR TEJ BAHADUR This is written in a hurry.
('85', 129, 4, 5, 234050) I suggest not a tentative public statement but a personal letter to a few representatives asking whether they favour the idea of calling a conference.
('85', 129, 4, 6, 234201) I have in mind not a centre but a board composed of representatives of the two States regulating matters of common concern and enforcing the treaty obligations.
('85', 129, 4, 7, 234362) The conference will meet to consider the causes of the failure of the talks, to find whose fault it was and to suggest an independent solution, if any.
('85', 129, 4, 8, 234514) It will inform and educate public opinion.
('85', 129, 4, 9, 234557) Thus there is no fear of failure unless the conference does not come to a unanimous decision or one tantamount to it.
('85', 129, 5, 10, 234675) You must keep well.

('85', 138, 10, 13, 247766) 197. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR HINDUSTANI PRACHAR SABHA
('85', 138, 11, 14, 247817) [On or before November 7, 1944] 2
('85', 138, 12, 15, 247851) The objective of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha is to popularize Hindustani rapidly.
('85', 138, 12, 16, 247934) For this it is essential that those who are learning Hindustani acquire familiarity with the Devanagari and Persian scripts.
('85', 138, 12, 17, 248059) It is therefore the duty of this Sabha to get the right textbooks published and arrange examinati198ons in order to be able to certify that one knows both the scripts and can read and write Hindustani.
('85', 138, 12, 18, 248261) The Working Committee should lay down details regarding the curriculum and the examinations.

('85', 141, 9, 22, 252695) 204. TALK WITH GULZARILAL NANDA 1
('85', 141, 10, 23, 252729) [Before November 9, 1944] If everyone stuck to his dharma and did his duty why should I have to fast?
('85', 141, 10, 24, 252831) And how would God permit it?
('85', 141, 10, 25, 252860) But if people become unsettled and remain inactive the fast will not be stopped.
('85', 141, 10, 26, 252941) So long as I can work otherwise, there is no possibility of my resorting to a fast.
('85', 141, 10, 27, 253025) When there is no work for me or no work which can be taken from me, then alone will God ask me to go on a fast.
('85', 141, 11, 28, 253137) 1 Gulzarilal Nanda, Secretary of the Ahmedabad Textile Labour Association, had conveyed Gandhiji’s words to the Association’s organ, Majoor Sandesh, in his letter from Wardha dated November 9, 1944.

('85', 143, 11, 16, 255754) 208. NOTE TO ANAND KAUSALYAYAN 1
('85', 143, 12, 17, 255787) November 9, 1944 1. Obviously it is obligatory for a member of the Sabha to fulfil at any rate the condition laid down by you.
('85', 143, 12, 18, 255914) The objective of the Sabha is clearly stated in its constitution.
('85', 143, 12, 19, 255980) I do wish, however, that all Indians learn both the scripts and speak a language which could be understood by both Hindus and Muslims.
('85', 143, 12, 20, 256115) 2. The Hindi style and the Urdu style are like the Ganga and the Yamuna.
('85', 143, 12, 21, 256188) Hindustani is like the Saraswati.
('85', 143, 12, 22, 256222) It is concealed and yet not concealed.
('85', 143, 12, 23, 256261) The Sabha should endeavour to make it clearly discernible.
('85', 143, 13, 24, 256320) 1 Secretary, Hindustani Prachar Sabha, Wardha.
('85', 143, 13, 25, 256367) This note was in reply to the following questions: (1) It appears that, in 1942, when the Hindustani Prachar Sabha was formed, you intended and directed your efforts that persons enrolling themselves as members
('85', 144, 0, 1, 256578) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 145
('85', 144, 1, 2, 256621) 3. Hindustani Prachar Sabha will be complementary of both and will seek help from both.
('85', 144, 1, 3, 256709) But its work will be distinct from theirs, which could also be regarded as the same.
('85', 144, 1, 4, 256794) If the Sabha tried to undo the work of these two organizations, its own objective would be defeated.
('85', 144, 1, 5, 256895) How can you have Saraswati without the confluence [of the three]?
('85', 144, 1, 6, 256961) 4. The work of the Sabha will be, and should be, uniform all over the country.
('85', 144, 1, 7, 257040) The procedure may be modified here and there to suit the differing needs of the provinces.
('85', 144, 1, 8, 257131) 5. The new movement of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha should not create difficulties in the work of Rashtrabhasha Prachar Samiti, if the two co ordinate their activities.
('85', 144, 3, 9, 257300) M. K. GANDHI
('85', 144, 4, 10, 257313) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.
('85', 144, 4, 11, 257356) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('85', 144, 6, 12, 257375) of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha must learn both the scripts of the Rashtrabhasha.
('85', 144, 6, 13, 257457) Do you, even today, expect that thing only from the members, or do you want that everybody, both old and young in the country, must learn both the scripts?
('85', 144, 6, 14, 257613) (2) Regarding the plan of work of Hindustani Prachar Sabha, some people understand that the Sabha aims at propagating both Hindi and Urdu but there are others who say that it aims at propagating neither Hindi nor Urdu but Hindustani.
('85', 144, 6, 15, 257847) In 1942, you were of opinion that the Saraswati in the shape of Hindustani had not yet made its appearance.
('85', 144, 6, 16, 257955) Is the situation different at present?
('85', 144, 6, 17, 257994) What is it that the Sabha will propagate if Hindustani has not yet made its appearance?
('85', 144, 6, 18, 258082) (3) Under the auspices of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan a number of institutions are working for the propagation of Hindi and the Devanagari script, and the Anjuman Taraqqi e Urdu for that of Urdu and the Persian script.
('85', 144, 6, 19, 258300) Will the Hindustani Prachar Sabha be merely co ordinating the activities of these two institutions or will it be complementary of the two?
('85', 144, 6, 20, 258439) Or will it be a third body pursuing its own programme undoing the work of these two?
('85', 144, 6, 21, 258524) (4) Will the policy and programme of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha with respect to South India and the non Hindi provinces be the same as in the other provinces—that is, will the propagation of both the scripts be obligatory?
('85', 144, 6, 22, 258749) (5) Will the new policy of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha create difficulties in continuing the propagation of Rashtrabhasha as it is being carried on in South India and the other non Hindi provinces for the last so many years?

('85', 147, 6, 17, 262236) 214. LETTER TO COWASJI JEHANGIR
('85', 147, 7, 18, 262268) SEVAGRAM, November 10, 1944
('85', 147, 8, 19, 262296) DEAR SIR COWASJI, Somebody had conveyed to me the news of your dear son’s passing away.
('85', 147, 8, 20, 262384) I had thought I would write to you a letter of condolence but being burdened with work it slipped from my memory.
('85', 147, 8, 21, 262498) Last night I remembered it when I happened to read the news again in Vallabhbhai’s letter to Dahyabhai.
('85', 147, 8, 22, 262602) And now I write this.

('85', 147, 8, 24, 262661) There must be hundreds like me sharing your grief.
('85', 147, 8, 25, 262712) May they all lighten your burden and may God grant you peace.
('85', 147, 9, 26, 262774) Yours, M. K. GANDHI

('85', 148, 6, 18, 263643) 216. SPEECH AT HINDUSTANI TALIMI SANGH MEETING
('85', 148, 7, 19, 263690) November 10, 1944
('85', 148, 8, 20, 263708) Speaking to members of the Hindustani Talimi Sangh who are meeting here, Mahatma Gandhi said that the Sangh should now take up the entire span of national education as its field and work out a programme of national education for life in all its stages through manual activity and handicrafts.
('85', 148, 8, 21, 264001) He pointed out that the future programme of national education thus became only an extension of the present programme of basic education upwards and downwards.
('85', 148, 8, 22, 264161) The Hindu, 12 11 1944
('85', 148, 9, 23, 264183) 1 Raihana Tyabji
('85', 149, 0, 1, 264200) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 149, 1, 2, 264242) 217. A NOTE November 11, 1944 (1) I have read Shri Wadia’s letter of 31 10 ’44. I have no recollection whatsoever of having made the remark attributed to me about Shri Agnibhoj.
('85', 149, 1, 3, 264420) Indeed I had nothing to do with such appointments.
('85', 149, 1, 4, 264471) I was not then nor am I now a member of the Working Committee.
('85', 149, 1, 5, 264534) (2) There was no question of my refusal to have a Harijan on the executive of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('85', 149, 1, 6, 264637) As a matter of fact there are Harijans on the Central Board as well as its branches.
('85', 149, 1, 7, 264722) But I am opposed on principle to such appointments for the Sangh is formed of a body of caste Hindu penitents who are vowed to eradicate untouchability.
('85', 149, 1, 8, 264875) It is therefore a debtors’ association.
('85', 149, 1, 9, 264915) Harijans are creditors.
('85', 149, 1, 10, 264939) I expressed this opinion to a body of Harijans who recently interviewed me.
('85', 149, 2, 11, 265015) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('85', 149, 2, 12, 265045) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('85', 149, 3, 13, 265064) 218. LETTER TO K. R. R. SASTRY November 11, 1944
('85', 149, 4, 14, 265113) DEAR PROF.
('85', 149, 4, 15, 265124) SASTRY 2, I thank you for your kind letter.
('85', 149, 4, 16, 265168) (A) My experience does not bear out the truth of your proposition.
('85', 149, 4, 17, 265235) I do not claim to be a saint.
('85', 149, 4, 18, 265265) But I do not regard politics as inconsistent with the strictest moral code.
('85', 149, 4, 19, 265341) Politics I hold to be a noble art which every good citizen must cultivate ...
('85', 149, 4, 20, 265419) 3 not in...
('85', 149, 4, 21, 265431) 4 the game that professional politicians play.
('85', 149, 4, 22, 265478) (B) is answered in (A) (C) Only posterity can judge.
('85', 149, 4, 23, 265531) Obviously I can’t.
('85', 149, 4, 24, 265550) (D) I am sorry I cannot subscribe to your opinion.
('85', 149, 4, 25, 265601) Mine is a new experiment.
('85', 149, 4, 26, 265627) I plead for patience in coming to a judgement.
('85', 149, 4, 27, 265674) As to your constructive suggestions, you will perhaps forgive me if I do not argue about them.
('85', 149, 5, 28, 265769) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('85', 159, 8, 16, 275514) For the present your personal expenses will be met by the Ashram.
('85', 159, 8, 17, 275580) Whether or not you can devote some time to the work at the Ashram is something to be looked into.

('85', 159, 8, 19, 275714) Don’t be agitated over such matters, but have faith in God.
('85', 159, 8, 20, 275774) “One step enough for me.”

('85', 161, 8, 17, 277907) 244. LETTER TO DURLAB SINGH
('85', 161, 9, 18, 277935) SEVAGRAM, November 14, 1944
('85', 161, 10, 19, 277963) DEAR SARDAR DURLAB SINGH 2, This is my answer to your questions: 3
('85', 161, 11, 20, 278030) (1) My association with Rajaji in his formula 4 could not affect the Sikh position in the slightest degree, even if Quaid e Azam Jinnah accepted it.
('85', 161, 11, 21, 278179) The Lahore Resolution 5 of the Congress referred to by you stands.
('85', 161, 11, 22, 278246) The result of Quaid e Azam Jinnah’s acceptance would have been that both of us would have gone to the Sikhs and others
('85', 161, 12, 23, 278365) 1 Pant, Ruler of Aundh 2 General Secretary, Central Sikh Youth League 3 For extracts from the addressee’s letter, vide Appendix “Letter from Durlabh Singh”, 12 11 1944. 4 Vide Appendix “C. Rajagopalachari’s Formula”, before 5 8 1942. 5 Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee”, 1 1 1930.
('85', 162, 0, 1, 278648) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 163
('85', 162, 1, 2, 278691) interested to secure their acceptance.
('85', 162, 1, 3, 278730) I had made this clear in my letter 1 to Masterjee.
('85', 162, 1, 4, 278781) (2) I cannot understand the Akali indignation.
('85', 162, 1, 5, 278828) My meeting a deputation was unnecessary in view of my absolute assurance.
('85', 162, 1, 6, 278902) If Masterjee had wanted to bring his friends to me, in spite of my assurance, I would have gladly seen them as I did other friends who sought clarification from me.
('85', 162, 1, 7, 279067) (3) Maulana Saheb explained the implications of the Jagat Narain Lal’s Resolution 2 which please see.
('85', 162, 1, 8, 279169) But supposing that it is inconsistent with the Rajaji Formula and the Congress accepts the latter, there is nothing to prevent the Congress from rescinding the Resolution.
('85', 162, 1, 9, 279341) (4) How could I favour a contrary opinion when I have always given the closest collaboration to Sikh friends?
('85', 162, 1, 10, 279451) Those Sikhs, who do not accept the Congress creed, naturally refrain, like many others, from joining the Congress.
('85', 162, 1, 11, 279566) (5) I know nothing about the Sikandar 3 Baldev Singh Pact, much less about the Congress High Command’s association with it.
('85', 162, 1, 12, 279690) Nor do I know the details of the Azad Punjab scheme.
('85', 162, 1, 13, 279743) I could never be guilty of blessing anything which is con trary to the national interest.
('85', 162, 1, 14, 279833) You can certainly have the assurance that the interests of the nationalist Sikhs, as also of all nationalists, are safe in my hands, also, I presume, in the Congress hands, though as you know I have no authority to speak on behalf of the Congress.
('85', 162, 1, 15, 280081) There are many inventions about me going the round.
('85', 162, 1, 16, 280133) I would warn friends against giving credence to any of them without reference to me.
('85', 162, 2, 17, 280218) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('85', 162, 3, 18, 280248) The Indian Annual Register, 1944, Vol. II .

('85', 170, 4, 12, 289321) 262. NOTE TO ANAND T. HINGORANI
('85', 170, 5, 13, 289353) November 16, 1944
('85', 170, 6, 14, 289371) Weeping and laughing come from the heart.
('85', 170, 6, 15, 289413) When grieved one weeps.
('85', 170, 6, 16, 289437) One must turn that grief into joy and laugh.
('85', 170, 6, 17, 289482) Hence the need for Ramanama.
('85', 170, 6, 18, 289511) Surrender all to Him and there is only joy.
('85', 170, 6, 19, 289555) Why grieve over the loss of hearing?
('85', 170, 6, 20, 289592) You are saved from hearing a lot of drivel.
('85', 170, 6, 21, 289636) What is relevant you get through the written word.
('85', 170, 6, 22, 289687) Moreover I believe that if there is joy within, the ears will of themselves regain the power of hearing.

('85', 178, 4, 5, 299570) 278. LETTER TO OMKARNATH THAKUR
('85', 178, 5, 6, 299602) SEVAGRAM, November 18, 1944
('85', 178, 6, 7, 299630) BHAI OMKARNATH, I read your statement fully.
('85', 178, 6, 8, 299675) Till this point I wrote in Hindi either inadvertently or because I was possessed by Hindi.
('85', 178, 6, 9, 299766) Why is your statement in English?
('85', 178, 6, 10, 299800) Your language too does not follow the English usage and hence sounds out of tune.
('85', 178, 6, 11, 299882) Very few among us have a perfect command over English.
('85', 178, 6, 12, 299937) And why must we?
('85', 178, 6, 13, 299954) When we cannot do without it we may scribble some kind of English to express our thoughts.
('85', 178, 6, 14, 300045) You want to place your thoughts before the Indian people.
('85', 178, 6, 15, 300103) They should therefore be either in Gujarati (your mother tongue) or Hindi (the national language).
('85', 178, 6, 16, 300202) This was only a point to note.
('85', 178, 6, 17, 300233) What have you to do with a charter?
('85', 178, 6, 18, 300269) Your own merit deserves to be your writ.
('85', 178, 6, 19, 300310) Certainly, you don’t need State patronage.
('85', 178, 6, 20, 300353) I think the [institutions at] Santiniketan are run without a licence and yet command global reputation.
('85', 178, 6, 21, 300457) Did Vishnu Digambar 1 ever obtain a licence?
('85', 178, 6, 22, 300502) And now the third point.
('85', 178, 6, 23, 300527) Your statement is contrary to your new resolve.
('85', 178, 6, 24, 300575) It smacks of Pakistan.
('85', 178, 6, 25, 300598) Music till now is untouched [by it].
('85', 178, 6, 26, 300635) Please don’t let it be defiled by bringing in Pakistan.
('85', 178, 6, 27, 300691) What more can you expect from a man on his death bed except an exchange of notes?

('85', 181, 1, 2, 303288) 282. LETTER TO SURYAKANT PARIKH 1
('85', 181, 2, 3, 303322) SEVAGRAM, November 19, 1944 2
('85', 181, 3, 4, 303352) SURYAKANT PARIKH, The sincerity of your letter is unmistakable.
('85', 181, 3, 5, 303416) The leaders who are in jail are doing their duty by being there.
('85', 181, 3, 6, 303481) A satyagrahi in prison never rots.
('85', 181, 3, 7, 303516) He serves his cause by his imprisonment, nor can anyone say with certainty that he could have served the cause better if he had remained outside.
('85', 181, 3, 8, 303662) But it is the duty of those who are outside not to forget those who are in prison.
('85', 181, 3, 9, 303745) They must labour to get them out.
('85', 181, 3, 10, 303779) If we had the requisite strength, many of our leaders should not be today in jail.
('85', 181, 3, 11, 303862) In its absence, we must strive with whatever measure of strength we may possess.
('85', 181, 3, 12, 303943) I, therefore, like the idea of students abstaining from going to school on 9th, provided they devote the whole day to self purification and service.
('85', 181, 3, 13, 304092) There should be strictest adherence to truth and ahimsa in whatever they do.
('85', 181, 3, 14, 304169) Mass civil disobedience is today in abeyance; rather, it was never started but the fight for independence shall go on so long as independence is not attained.
('85', 181, 3, 15, 304328) Whatever your decision let the bounds of propriety be not transgressed and let the decision be taken after due consultation with your teachers and school management.
('85', 181, 3, 16, 304494) Do not forget that yours is not a Government school.
('85', 181, 3, 17, 304547) You must also remember what I have said in another place about the duties of students.
('85', 181, 4, 18, 304634) Blessings from BAPU SURYAKANT C/O JIVANLAL DIWAN AHMEDABAD The Hitavada, 21 1 1945

('85', 182, 0, 1, 305230) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 183
('85', 182, 1, 2, 305273) 283. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA TEACHERS’ TRAINING CAMP 1
('85', 182, 2, 3, 305324) SEVAGRAM, November 19, 1944
('85', 182, 3, 4, 305352) At the request of Shrimati Ashadevi, Gandhiji delivered a short address to them on the 19th instant, to explain the meaning of New Education.
('85', 182, 3, 5, 305494) He described in a few words how the Basic Education scheme was born.
('85', 182, 3, 6, 305563) In 1937 when the Congress took up power for a short term, as it afterwards turned out, in seven out of the eleven Provinces they were confronted with the question of popular education.
('85', 182, 3, 7, 305748) His advice was sought.
('85', 182, 3, 8, 305771) Like many others, he had been dissatisfied with the present system of education.
('85', 182, 3, 9, 305852) He felt that if education was to be linked with the living needs of the masses inhabiting the villages of India, it ought to be imparted through a basic craft.
('85', 182, 3, 10, 306012) He had no practical experience of agriculture.
('85', 182, 3, 11, 306059) But he was saturated with the idea of the charkha which he had identified with village life.
('85', 182, 3, 12, 306152) He, therefore, suggested that it should be used as a medium for the children’s education.
('85', 182, 3, 13, 306242) The idea appealed to Shri Aryanayakum, Shrimati Ashadevi and Dr. Zakir Husain and through their effort the Hindustani Talimi Sangh was founded.
('85', 182, 4, 14, 306386) Originally this New Education was intended to cover only the first seven years of a child’s education, viz., from the seventh to the fourteenth year.
('85', 182, 4, 15, 306536) The experiment had already completed six years and was now entering upon the seventh.
('85', 182, 4, 16, 306622) As a result of further thought, he had come to the conclusion that this education should cover the whole of life from the moment of conception to the moment of death.
('85', 182, 5, 17, 306789) Referring to the prayer which had been recited at the beginning of the proceedings, he observed: There are several things in this prayer which are worthy of your note but I want to draw your attention to that particular portion of it which pledged the reciter to adherence to Truth in speech and action under all circumstances and at all times.
('85', 182, 5, 18, 307134) One mantra means: “Lead me from untruth to Truth, from darkness to Light, from death to Immortality.” Similarly the Islamic prayer, which has just been recited is an outpouring of the soul for Light and for being guided on to the straight path of Truth and Righteousness.
('85', 182, 5, 19, 307406) This quest for Truth is the Alpha and Omega of all education.
('85', 182, 5, 20, 307468) After finishing your training here you will go back to your respective Provinces to propagate this New Education.
('85', 182, 5, 21, 307582) You will keep this ideal of devotion to Truth before you.
('85', 182, 5, 22, 307640) Your work will be that of pioneers.
('85', 182, 5, 23, 307676) There will be no one to help or guide you with his previous experience.
('85', 182, 5, 24, 307748) You shall have to grope your way all by yourselves.
('85', 182, 5, 25, 307800) It is, therefore, not an easy task that you have before you.
('85', 182, 5, 26, 307861) Then this New
('85', 182, 6, 27, 307875) 1 Organized by the Hindustani Talimi Sangh and attended by about 50 students, the camp was inaugurated by Gandhiji in the afternoon.
('85', 182, 6, 28, 308008) This is the authorized version of Gandhiji’s speech, presumably in Hindi.
('85', 183, 0, 1, 308082) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 183, 1, 2, 308124) Education will not help you to get big jobs carrying high salaries and emoluments.
('85', 183, 1, 3, 308207) But yours will be the privilege to go among and serve the villagers in their villages.
('85', 183, 1, 4, 308294) Palatial buildings and costly equipment can, therefore, have no place in your scheme of work.
('85', 183, 1, 5, 308388) The school of my conception is one where classes are held in the open under the shade of a tree.
('85', 183, 1, 6, 308485) I know that it cannot be realized at present.
('85', 183, 1, 7, 308531) Some shelter will be necessary, perhaps always for protection against the sun, wind and rain.
('85', 183, 1, 8, 308625) True education can only be given under conditions of utmost simplicity.
('85', 183, 2, 9, 308697) Pointing to the building in which they were assembled, he continued: All the buildings here in the Talimi Sangh are built of local material and with the help of local artisans.
('85', 183, 2, 10, 308874) We have thereby established a living link between ourselves and the people.
('85', 183, 2, 11, 308950) That by itself is an education for the people and constitutes the foundation of our future educational work.
('85', 183, 2, 12, 309059) If you thoroughly assimilate this ideal of simplicity and its importance in the New Education, you will have justified your training here.
('85', 183, 2, 13, 309198) You will then appreciate your work.
('85', 183, 2, 14, 309234) That work consists of cleaning up.
('85', 183, 2, 15, 309269) Cleanliness of the mind and body is the first step in education.
('85', 183, 2, 16, 309334) Prayer does for the purification of the mind what the bucket and the broom do for the cleaning up of your physical surroundings.
('85', 183, 2, 17, 309463) That is why we always commence our proceedings with prayer.
('85', 183, 2, 18, 309523) No matter whether the prayer we recite is the Hindu prayer or the Muslim or the Parsi, its function is essentially the same, namely, purification of the heart.
('85', 183, 2, 19, 309683) God has innumerable names but the most beautiful and suitable in my opinion is Truth.
('85', 183, 2, 20, 309769) Let Truth, therefore, rule every action of our life, be it ever so insignificant.
('85', 183, 2, 21, 309851) Let every morsel of food that we eat be sanctified with His name and consecrated to His service.
('85', 183, 2, 22, 309948) If we eat only to sustain the body as an instrument of His service not only will it make our bodies and minds healthy and clean, the inner cleanliness will be reflected in our surroundings also.
('85', 183, 2, 23, 310143) We must learn to make our latrines as clean as our kitchens.
('85', 183, 2, 24, 310204) As with the individual so with society.
('85', 183, 2, 25, 310244) A village is but a group of individuals and the world, as I see it, is one vast village and mankind one family.
('85', 183, 2, 26, 310356) The various functions in the human body have their parallel in the corporate life of society.
('85', 183, 2, 27, 310450) What I have said about the inner and outer cleanliness of the individual, therefore, applies to the whole society.
('85', 183, 2, 28, 310565) In the mighty world, man, considered as an animal, occupies but an insignificant place.
('85', 183, 2, 29, 310653) Physically, he is a contemptible worm.
('85', 183, 2, 30, 310692) But God has endowed him with intellect and the faculty of discrimination between good and evil.
('85', 183, 2, 31, 310788) If we use this faculty to know
('85', 184, 0, 1, 310819) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 185
('85', 184, 1, 2, 310862) God we become a power for good.
('85', 184, 1, 3, 310894) Abuse of that talent converts us into an instrument of evil, so that we become like a scourge and a plague and fill this earth with strife and bloodshed and unhappiness and misery.
('85', 184, 1, 4, 311075) The struggle between the forces of good and evil is ceaseless and eternal.
('85', 184, 1, 5, 311150) The former have truth and ahimsa as weapons against the letter’s falsehood, violence and brute force.
('85', 184, 1, 6, 311252) There is nothing more potent in the universe than God’s name.
('85', 184, 1, 7, 311314) If we enthrone Him in our hearts and keep Him there always, we shall know no fear and lay for ourselves rich treasure in life.
('85', 184, 1, 8, 311441) The Hindu, 5 12 1944

('85', 207, 0, 1, 339963) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 207, 1, 2, 340005) 330. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('85', 207, 2, 3, 340035) SEVAGRAM, November 27, 1944 At present, the Hindustani prachar work is being carried on in Gujarat by Shri Amritlal Nanavati.
('85', 207, 2, 4, 340161) This work is in accordance with the scheme prepared by Kakasaheb in consultation with me.
('85', 207, 2, 5, 340251) Hindi prachar work is being conducted by the Rashtrabhasha Prachar Samiti, Wardha, appointed by the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan.
('85', 207, 2, 6, 340375) Both these activities are supposed to be undertaken for spreading the national language.
('85', 207, 2, 7, 340464) I regard myself as the founder of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('85', 207, 2, 8, 340528) In 1925, the resolution about Hindustani was passed at the Cawnpore session of the Indian National Congress.
('85', 207, 2, 9, 340637) But no attempt was made to act upon the resolution.
('85', 207, 2, 10, 340689) The Hindustani Prachar Sabha was, therefore, established in Wardha on the 2nd May, 1942. The Sabha has defined Hindustani as follows:
('85', 207, 3, 11, 340823) Hindustani is that language which the Hindus, Muslims and all other people of villages and towns in Northern India speak, understandand use for mutual intercourse, which is written and read in both the Nagari and the Persian scripts, and the literary forms of which are recognized today as Hindi and Urdu.
('85', 207, 4, 12, 341129) But before the work of the Sabha could be started properly, many people of the country, including the founders of the Sabha, were thrust into jails on account of the August Resolution 3 of the Congress.
('85', 207, 4, 13, 341332) Shri Nanavati was not in jail, and he felt that he should start the Hindustani prachar work.
('85', 207, 4, 14, 341425) In my opinion he has served the country by doing this work.
('85', 207, 4, 15, 341485) Hindi and Urdu are the two literary styles of the same national language.
('85', 207, 4, 16, 341559) These two styles are, at present, diverging from each other.
('85', 207, 4, 17, 341620) From the point of view of Rashtrabhasha—Hindustani—it is necessary to bring these two styles nearer to each other.
('85', 207, 4, 18, 341735) Without the knowledge of both these styles and the scripts this is impossible to achieve.
('85', 207, 5, 19, 341825) 1 This was issued on January 10, 1945, by Shriman Narayan, Honorary General Secretary, All India Hindustani Prachar Sabha, in order to remove misunderstandings about the object and work of the Sabha.
('85', 207, 5, 20, 342025) The Gujarati original appeared in Gujarat Samachar, 2 12 1944. 2 Gujarat Samachar has this paragraph in Hindi.
('85', 207, 5, 21, 342136) 3 Vide Appendix “Resolution Passed by All India Congress Committee”, 8 8 1942.
('85', 208, 0, 1, 342215) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 209
('85', 208, 1, 2, 342258) The venom of Hindu Muslim differences has entered the sphere of language as well.
('85', 208, 1, 3, 342340) I have been possessed with the idea of Hindu Muslim unity ever since my childhood.
('85', 208, 1, 4, 342423) In order to eliminate this poison of disunity in the domain of language, it is necessary to learn both the styles and the scripts.
('85', 208, 1, 5, 342554) If the Congress desires to conduct its work without English—and this must be done—it is the duty of each Congressman to learn both the styles and the scripts.
('85', 208, 1, 6, 342713) This will result in the happy fusion of Hindi and Urdu, and the language that will thus evolve will be the natural Hindustani.
('85', 208, 1, 7, 342840) A question is asked whether the enthusiasm for learning both the styles and the scripts should be among both the Hindus and Muslims or only in one of them.
('85', 208, 1, 8, 342996) A misunderstanding lurks behind this question.
('85', 208, 1, 9, 343043) Those who make progress in the knowledge of languages will stand to gain: those who do not will be the losers.
('85', 208, 1, 10, 343154) Moreover, he who cherishes unity will take special pains to know both the styles and the scripts.
('85', 208, 1, 11, 343252) It should also be remembered that, in provinces like the Punjab, the Hindus, Muslims and all others know only Urdu.
('85', 208, 1, 12, 343368) To know at least this much is the duty of every patriot.
('85', 208, 1, 13, 343425) In a vast country like India, the more languages we strive to learn the better equipped shall we become for national service.
('85', 208, 1, 14, 343551) Should both the scripts and the styles be learnt by national workers and Congressmen only or by all?
('85', 208, 1, 15, 343652) My answer to this question is that all Indians should become Congressmen, and thus everybody should learn both the styles and the scripts.
('85', 208, 1, 16, 343791) In fact, the very question is irrelevant, because only a very limited number of men and women have so far developed this hobby of learning the national language.
('85', 208, 1, 17, 343953) We cannot go into raptures over the fact that a few thousands or a few lakhs of people appear at the Rashtrabhasha examinations.
('85', 208, 1, 18, 344082) Even the number of persons in the non Hindi and non Urdu areas who desire to learn only Hindi or Urdu is not sufficient to satisfy our ambition.
('85', 208, 1, 19, 344227) Is it not enough that those who desire to learn Urdu should do so through the Anjuman 1 and those who desire to learn Hindi should do so through the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan?
('85', 208, 1, 20, 344400) Not at all.
('85', 208, 1, 21, 344412) It was precisely because of this that the Congress passed the resolution on Hindustani and the need of establishing the Hindustani Prachar Sabha was felt.
('85', 208, 1, 22, 344567) The scopes of both the institutions (Sammelan and Anjuman) are restricted, and from my point of view, narrow as well.
('85', 208, 1, 23, 344685) It is my cherished desire that both these sister institutions should co operate with each other.
('85', 208, 1, 24, 344782) When that auspicious
('85', 208, 2, 25, 344803) 1 Anjuman Taraqui e Urdu
('85', 209, 0, 1, 344828) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('85', 209, 1, 2, 344870) day will really dawn, the work of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha will be deemed to be over.
('85', 209, 1, 3, 344960) So long as this situation does not arise, the Hindustani Prachar Sabha should continue to perform its duty.
('85', 209, 1, 4, 345068) I do hope that these two sister associations will not only tolerate but also welcome this third sister institution which seeks to establish unity between them.
('85', 209, 1, 5, 345228) In Gujarat many workers who are at present engaged in Hindi and Hindustani prachar work are my colleagues.
('85', 209, 1, 6, 345335) Some of them have sought my guidance.
('85', 209, 1, 7, 345373) This statement is my guidance to them.
('85', 209, 1, 8, 345412) If those who are working for the Wardha Samiti of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan agree with my views on Hindustani prachar, they should take up this work as well.
('85', 209, 1, 9, 345571) They can certainly teach and coach for the Sammelan examinations those students who desire to learn only the Hindi style and the Devanagari script.
('85', 209, 1, 10, 345719) But they themselves should popularize both the styles and the scripts and should also try to persuade as many persons as they can to do the same.
('85', 209, 1, 11, 345865) So far as language is connected with the welfare of the nation, I regard Hindustani prachar work to be most essential.
('85', 209, 1, 12, 345984) There should never develop any conflict between the two activities (of Hindi and Hindustani).
('85', 209, 1, 13, 346078) Now a question arises as to what should be done by those who have so far learnt or may learn in future only Hindi or only Urdu.Such persons should learn the other style or script and sit for the Hindustani examinations which are to be conducted in both the scripts.
('85', 209, 1, 14, 346344) Those who have already learnt one style and script will find it very easy to answer the question papers.
('85', 209, 1, 15, 346449) The Hindu, 15 1 1945

('85', 213, 7, 18, 351016) LILI, By all means have a mosquito net.

('85', 219, 2, 6, 358346) In this sense uttering Ramanama, reading the Gita, and so on, are part of nature cure.

('85', 220, 1, 2, 359716) 351. INTERVIEW TO N. G. RANGA
('85', 220, 2, 3, 359746) November 28, 1944
('85', 220, 3, 4, 359764) At the second interview 1 Prof.
('85', 220, 3, 5, 359796) Ranga placed before Gandhiji two alternative proposals for the re organization of the Kisan Sabhas and their co ordination with the Congress organization.
('85', 220, 3, 6, 359951) They were:
('85', 220, 4, 7, 359962) (1) To include in the kisan councils that may be formed one third representation from corresponding Congress Committees.
('85', 220, 4, 8, 360083) This would secure for them the co operation and the advice of the Congress.
('85', 220, 5, 9, 360159) (2) (a) To adopt Congress membership as a basic membership for the kisan organization.
('85', 220, 6, 10, 360246) (b) To constitute kisan councils out of rural delegates to the Congress Committees elected as per the present constitution.
('85', 220, 6, 11, 360370) Such kisan councils would be part of the Congress Committees while retaining their separate Corporate existence for dealing with the problems relating to the kisans.
('85', 220, 7, 12, 360536) (c) In addition to Congress members some non Congress but not anti Congress members also might be taken on the kisan councils to provide a suitable representation.
('85', 220, 8, 13, 360700) He felt that the first formula would be more acceptable than the second to most Kisan Sabhaites.
('85', 220, 8, 14, 360797) The final clause in the second formula too had the same object in view, namely, to make it acceptable to them.
('85', 220, 8, 15, 360908) GANDHIJI: But this is a variation upon what you suggested last time.
('85', 220, 8, 16, 360977) Then you suggested that the Kisan Sabha will have no member who is not a member of the Congress also.
('85', 220, 9, 17, 361079) RANGA : We want to have in our organization some non Congress kisans also who are not anti Congress but for various reasons could not afford to join the Congress.
('85', 220, 9, 18, 361242) GANDHIJI: Why do you want that?
('85', 220, 9, 19, 361274) You said that you did not want anything in opposition to the Congress.
('85', 220, 9, 20, 361345) So, if you have for your members only Congressmen, the kisan organization will deal with matters relating to the rights of kisans as against landlords and employers.
('85', 220, 9, 21, 361511) It won’t deal with political questions.
('85', 220, 9, 22, 361551) I thought that I could reconcile myself to it.
('85', 220, 9, 23, 361598) I said I approached it with hesitation while it was for you to dispel my doubts.
('85', 220, 9, 24, 361679) So you better stick to your original proposal.
('85', 220, 10, 25, 361726) RANGA : It has been forcibly brought home to us that the Congress people feel nervous about this double membership.
('85', 220, 10, 26, 361842) So I thought the Kisan Sabha had better remain as a distinct body.
('85', 220, 10, 27, 361909) Our workers are used to that idea.
('85', 220, 10, 28, 361944) I have been able to
('85', 220, 11, 29, 361964) 1 For the earlier interview, vide “Interview to N.G. Ranga”, 29 10 1944.
('85', 221, 0, 1, 362037) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 222
('85', 221, 1, 2, 362079) persuade them that so far as politics is concerned we must accept Congress leadership.
('85', 221, 1, 3, 362166) The idea is that after the Congress elections are over the rural delegates will form themselves into a kisan council.
('85', 221, 1, 4, 362284) This kisan council will deal with matters relating to the kisans and in politics accept the lead of the Congress.
('85', 221, 1, 5, 362398) GANDHIJI: My suggestion is this.
('85', 221, 1, 6, 362431) You have your own organization where you register all the kisans.
('85', 221, 1, 7, 362497) As soon as the kisan becomes your member, he becomes also a Congress member.
('85', 221, 1, 8, 362574) Matters particularly bearing on the kisans and their relationship with the landlords, etc., are then tackled by your organization while political matters will be tackled by the Congress.
('85', 221, 2, 9, 362761) RANGA: In that case may we retain one anna for the kisan council out of the Congress membership fee of four annas?
('85', 221, 2, 10, 362876) GANDHIJI: You can do that subject to Congress approval.
('85', 221, 2, 11, 362932) This would mean that the Congress allows a gratuity of one anna to you for doing this special work.
('85', 221, 2, 12, 363032) If I were at the head of Congress affairs I would certainly allow it.
('85', 221, 3, 13, 363102) RANGA : In the mean time may we start with one anna membership from now on the clear understanding that those who are now enrolled are to become members of the Congress as soon as the Congress organization again begins to function?
('85', 221, 3, 14, 363334) Or we can take five annas from each member now and out of it keep four annas in trust for the Congress.
('85', 221, 3, 15, 363438) GANDHIJI: I am afraid you cannot do it today.
('85', 221, 3, 16, 363484) You must do it openly or not at all.
('85', 221, 3, 17, 363521) Do not collect the four annas Congress membership fee in advance.
('85', 221, 3, 18, 363587) I will suggest a better plan which I recommended to Shrimati Rama Devi.
('85', 221, 3, 19, 363659) Have a register of workers only.
('85', 221, 3, 20, 363692) Don’t have Congress members just now.
('85', 221, 4, 21, 363730) RANGA: Can’t we have something like a Congress Seva Sangh, an ad hoc body of Congress workers but not Congress members, to carry out Congress work?
('85', 221, 4, 22, 363878) GANDHIJI: Yes, you may do that.
('85', 221, 4, 23, 363910) But seeing that ours is a non violent body their work will only be to carry on the fifteen fold constructive programme.
('85', 221, 4, 24, 364030) That will avoid tussle with the Communists also.
('85', 221, 4, 25, 364079) Today you are not working for power but as Congress servants.
('85', 221, 4, 26, 364141) If you carry on your work silently and unostentatiously you become irresistible.
('85', 221, 4, 27, 364222) No one will come in unless he wants to work with you.
('85', 221, 4, 28, 364276) There will be no eloquence or Press publicity to attract power seekers.
('85', 221, 5, 29, 364348) RANGA: Eloquence by itself, I admit, is no good but has it not its use when coupled with solid public work?
('85', 221, 5, 30, 364456) GANDHIJI: Work by itself is eloquence.
('85', 221, 5, 31, 364495) Here there are workers in Khadi Vidyalaya, Hindustani Talimi Sangh and the Gram Seva Sangh, working themselves to death.
('85', 221, 5, 32, 364616) They make no speeches.
('85', 221, 5, 33, 364639) They speak to the villagers through their activity.
('85', 222, 0, 1, 364691) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 223
('85', 222, 1, 2, 364734) RANGA: As regards the Communists they have done a lot of harm so far as kisan work is concerned and as a result have become very unpopular.
('85', 222, 1, 3, 364874) There are two kisan organizations in Andhra, one Congress minded, the other Communist.
('85', 222, 1, 4, 364961) So far as we are concerned we keep the Communists out of our organization.
('85', 222, 1, 5, 365036) GANDHIJI: You won’t be able to keep anybody out of primary membership by merely making rules.
('85', 222, 1, 6, 365130) But you can keep out trouble if you work on the lines I have indicated.
('85', 222, 1, 7, 365202) The Hindu, 23 1 1945

('85', 229, 3, 5, 374822) Maybe, I should proceed in the same direction.
('85', 229, 3, 6, 374869) In support of my action I quote the fasts in the past that were universally praised.
