('85', 229, 3, 8, 375047) It is my firm conviction that even from a purely modern point of view fasting has an important place.
('85', 229, 3, 9, 375149) It is as much necessary for the atman that takes on a body as for the body itself.
('85', 229, 3, 10, 375232) If in the process the body drops that should be no reason at all for grieving.

('85', 232, 0, 1, 379106) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 233
('85', 232, 1, 2, 379149) 371. ADDRESS TO A.I.S.A. TRUSTEES
('85', 232, 2, 3, 379183) SEVAGRAM, December 1, 1944 1
('85', 232, 3, 4, 379212) I am sorry to say that I am physically not so fit and fresh as I had expected to be and that I have decided to take complete rest for four weeks commencing from the 4th December in order that I may be able threafter to take up the work more energetically.
('85', 232, 3, 5, 379468) However, I warn the members not to take pity on me and spare me in the deliberations.
('85', 232, 3, 6, 379554) Shri Jajuji, the General Secretary of the Sangh, has discussed with me 2 the future policy of the Sangh in all its aspects for seven days devoting one hour daily to it The gist of those discussions has been sent to the members of the Board and other prominent khadi workers in the form of a circular letter.
('85', 232, 3, 7, 379862) Replies thereto have been received from a number of members and they are all before the Board for their consideration.
('85', 232, 3, 8, 379981) The chief thing that I want the members to consider is that so far the Sangh work was directed from the Central Office, but henceforth the work is to be decentralized and any province or district which wants to be autonomous is to be allowed to do so.
('85', 232, 3, 9, 380233) Workers must be prepared to go to organize such autonomous centres with the prestige and moral support of the Sangh.
('85', 232, 3, 10, 380350) The worker will be paid a maintenance for five years on an annually diminishing scale.
('85', 232, 3, 11, 380437) He should work there according to the fundamental principles and policy laid down by the Sangh.
('85', 232, 3, 12, 380533) It is not possible otherwise to decentralize the work in seven lakhs of villages.
('85', 232, 3, 13, 380615) There are two schools of thought current in the world.
('85', 232, 3, 14, 380670) One wants to divide the world into cities and the other into villages.
('85', 232, 3, 15, 380741) The village civilization and the city civilization are totally different things.
('85', 232, 3, 16, 380822) One depends on machinery and industrialization, the other rests on handicraft.
('85', 232, 3, 17, 380901) We have given preference to the latter.
('85', 232, 3, 18, 380941) After all, this industrialization and large scale production are only of comparatively recent growth.
('85', 232, 3, 19, 381043) We do not know how far it has contributed to our development and happiness, but we know this much that it has brought in its wake the recent world wars.
('85', 232, 3, 20, 381196) This second world war is not still over and even before it comes to an end we are hearing of a third world war.
('85', 232, 4, 21, 381308) 1 From Charkha Sanghka Navasamskaran 2 Between October 7 and 14
('85', 233, 0, 1, 381372) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 234
('85', 233, 1, 2, 381414) Our country was never so unhappy and miserable as it is at present.
('85', 233, 1, 3, 381482) In the cities people may be getting big profits and good wages, but all that has become possible by sucking the blood of villagers.
('85', 233, 1, 4, 381614) We do not want to collect lakhs and crores.
('85', 233, 1, 5, 381658) We do not always want to depend on money for our work.
('85', 233, 1, 6, 381713) If we are prepared to sacrifice our lives for the cause, money is nothing.
('85', 233, 1, 7, 381788) We must have faith and we must be true to ourselves.
('85', 233, 1, 8, 381841) If we have these, we shall be able to decentralize our capital of thirty lakhs in the villages to create national wealth amounting to three hundred crores.
('85', 233, 1, 9, 381997) To do that, the main thing that is necessary is to make the village self sufficient and self reliant.
('85', 233, 1, 10, 382099) But mind you, my idea of self sufficiency is not a narrow one.
('85', 233, 1, 11, 382162) There is no scope for selfishness or arrogance in my self sufficiency.
('85', 233, 1, 12, 382233) I am not preaching isolation.
('85', 233, 1, 13, 382263) We have to be humble as dust for a cause.
('85', 233, 1, 14, 382305) We have to mix with people even as sugar mixes itself with milk.
('85', 233, 1, 15, 382370) Though the villagers will be self sufficient so far as it is possible, they will devote their time also to their intellectual development for the creation of the consciousness for the contemplated non violent society of the future.
('85', 233, 1, 16, 382602) Cloth stands second to food as necessity.
('85', 233, 1, 17, 382644) If every village begins to produce its own cloth, its strength will greatly be enhanced.
('85', 233, 1, 18, 382733) But to achieve that we do not want to close down the textile factories by legislation.
('85', 233, 1, 19, 382820) We want to achieve our purpose by revolutionizing the psychology of the people.
('85', 233, 1, 20, 382900) By decentralization we want to produce cloth wherever cotton is grown.
('85', 233, 1, 21, 382971) But what of the city people who have taken to khadi now?
('85', 233, 1, 22, 383028) I would ask them to spin their own yarn and to find out for themselves weavers to weave that yarn into cloth.
('85', 233, 1, 23, 383138) It is absurd that the cloth should come from Manchester for the poor, who produce cloth for Bombay people.
('85', 233, 1, 24, 383245) It is also not proper to compel the poor to accept part of their wages in the form of khadi.
('85', 233, 1, 25, 383338) They should be so educated that they may Spin voluntarily and intelligently and may use with love and pride the cloth produced by them.
('85', 233, 1, 26, 383474) If the people of Bombay want to wear khadi they should spin for themselves or get their children and other dependents to spin.
('85', 233, 1, 27, 383601) If people pledged to khadi, spin for themselves, the practice will be contagious.
('85', 233, 1, 28, 383683) Even if we are able to produce khadi worth ten crores instead of one crore as at present our object of reaching the whole of India will not be achieved.
('85', 234, 0, 1, 383836) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 235
('85', 234, 1, 2, 383879) Gandhiji then read out the resolution 1 which he wanted the Board to consider and adopt.
('85', 234, 1, 3, 383968) Whilst explaining its implications he said: The workers of all our five constructive programme institutions (Charkha Sangh, Gram Udyog Sangh, Hindustani Talimi Sangh, Harijan Sevak Sangh, Goseva Sangh) should possess such knowledge that the politics of the whole country may be guided by them.
('85', 234, 1, 4, 384262) Today we are all the while thinking that our work will be able to make headway only when Rajaji becomes the Prime Minister of Madras.
('85', 234, 1, 5, 384396) But that is not proper.
('85', 234, 1, 6, 384420) In our present politics we are looking with longing eyes to the Viceroy’s Secretariat but if we do our work properly the Viceroy will have to come to us.
('85', 234, 1, 7, 384574) He will see our work and realize that it is not possible to keep such people in subjection or to rule over them.
('85', 234, 1, 8, 384687) When seven lakhs of villages will take up this work in the new spirit we shall not remain a subject nation.
('85', 234, 1, 9, 384795) Each one of our villages will be independent and self reliant.
('85', 234, 1, 10, 384858) That is true swaraj and that is true democracy.
('85', 234, 1, 11, 384906) I do not worry when we shall be able to attain our goal, but if we are sure of our path and if we have faith that it is the only true one, we should go on striving for it incessantly and uninterruptedly.
('85', 234, 1, 12, 385110) The Bombay Chronicle, 7 12 1944
('85', 234, 2, 13, 385142) 372. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('85', 234, 3, 14, 385170) SEVAGRAM, December 1, 1944 That ‘man proposes and God disposes’ constantly proves true in my case, as I expect it does in every case whether we realize it or not.
('85', 234, 3, 15, 385333) I was contemplating a food fast for reasons I hold to be entirely spiritual.
('85', 234, 3, 16, 385410) But for the time being, it is being replaced by a day to day work fast.
('85', 234, 3, 17, 385482) I had hoped that I had recovered sufficiently to be able to go through the routine work without interruption.
('85', 234, 3, 18, 385592) But nature’s warning has been sounding in my ears during the last ten days.
('85', 234, 3, 19, 385668) I was feeling fatigued.
('85', 234, 3, 20, 385692) Even after the noonday siesta, the brain seemed tired.
('85', 234, 3, 21, 385747) There was a complete disinclination to speak or write.
('85', 234, 3, 22, 385802) But I continued hoping that I would be all right without having to discontinue mental activity.
('85', 234, 3, 23, 385898) But nature would have her way.
('85', 234, 3, 24, 385929) Rajaji who saw me after a month detected a marked change in my face, and he said, ‘You must stop all
('85', 234, 4, 25, 386030) 1 For the draft resolution, vide “Speech at A.I.S.A. Meeting II”, 2 9 1944 and for the resolution passed, vide Appendix “Resolution Passed by A.I.S.A.”, on or before 3 12 1944.
('85', 235, 0, 1, 386207) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 236
('85', 235, 1, 2, 386249) this ceaseless mental activity if you want to avoid a disaster.’ I seized the suggestion.
('85', 235, 1, 3, 386339) He even went so far as to say that I should not mind disappointing invited workers of the Charkha Sangh, although I was looking forward eagerly to meeting them and discussing with them my plan for a new orientation of khadi work.
('85', 235, 1, 4, 386569) But I would not listen.
('85', 235, 1, 5, 386593) So I am going through these meetings in the best manner I can in the hope that no crisis will overtake me during the remaining two days of these meetings.
('85', 235, 1, 6, 386748) From the 4th to the 31st of this month, I have decided rigidly to discontinue all public activities, all interviews for public or private purposes and all correspondence of any nature whatsoever.
('85', 235, 1, 7, 386944) I shall read no newspapers during the period.
('85', 235, 1, 8, 386990) This abstention will be subject to exception for unforeseen circumstances of a grave nature.
('85', 235, 1, 9, 387083) I shall not deny myself the pleasure of reading non political literature in which I am interested.
('85', 235, 1, 10, 387182) This also I shall read without in any way unduly taxing the brain.
('85', 235, 1, 11, 387249) I have asked friends who were expecting to see me during the month to indulgently postpone their visits for the time being.
('85', 235, 1, 12, 387373) Let readers not be alarmed at what is only a precautionary measure.
('85', 235, 1, 13, 387441) Dr. Sushila Nayyar assures me that there is nothing physically wrong with me except that my old friends, the hookworms and the amoebae, have not left me.
('85', 235, 1, 14, 387595) I am able to take daily walks without the slightest strain and they will be continued.
('85', 235, 1, 15, 387682) I had hoped to make one or two public statements in connection with a lot of misrepresentations of my views and doings about the communal question and some other public questions.
('85', 235, 1, 16, 387862) I must forbear for the time being.
('85', 235, 1, 17, 387897) But I must repeat the warning I have given before, that nothing that is not authoritatively stated by me should be accepted by the public.
('85', 235, 1, 18, 388036) There are things which I have seen in the Press which I can only say I am incapable of having countenanced directly or indirectly.
('85', 235, 1, 19, 388167) There are some vital questions addressed to me by correspondents.
('85', 235, 1, 20, 388233) They will forgive me for my inability to deal with them for the moment.
('85', 235, 1, 21, 388305) If, after a month, they still feel the necessity, they will please repeat their letters and if all goes well, I shall gladly reply.
('85', 235, 1, 22, 388437) Starvation of millions, black markets, and what I cannot but describe as gambling, will continue to worry me as they do now.
('85', 235, 1, 23, 388562) I can but entreat my numerous co workers to do what they can to ease the situation, which can be done, I am perfectly sure, if those concerned will make up their minds that the claims of the famishing millions are the first charge on their care and attention.
('85', 235, 1, 24, 388822) The Hindu, 3 12 1944

('85', 237, 2, 3, 390113) SEVAGRAM, December 2, 1944
('85', 237, 3, 4, 390140) AKBAR, I have made arrangements for a watch for you.
('85', 237, 3, 5, 390193) You will get it soon.
('85', 237, 3, 6, 390215) I have read all your letters.
('85', 237, 3, 7, 390245) You have been doing fine work.
('85', 237, 3, 8, 390276) God will bless you with success.
('85', 237, 3, 9, 390309) You will soon get lots of drugs, but they will not be very helpful.
('85', 237, 3, 10, 390377) So long as water, fire and earth are available, drugs are not necessary.
('85', 237, 3, 11, 390450) Give the people boiled water to drink.
('85', 237, 3, 12, 390489) This will cure most of the complaints.
('85', 237, 3, 13, 390528) Use soda [bicarb] if you have it.
('85', 237, 3, 14, 390562) Water containing soda will stop diarrhoea.
('85', 237, 3, 15, 390605) Food should be stopped.
('85', 237, 3, 16, 390629) Persuade the people patiently to stop eating.
('85', 237, 3, 17, 390675) You may even let them die who do not listen to you.
('85', 237, 3, 18, 390727) Search for village medicinal herbs.
('85', 237, 3, 19, 390763) You must have neem trees there.
('85', 237, 3, 20, 390795) If you persuade the people to chew its leaves and see that they fast, the fever will probably disappear.
('85', 237, 3, 21, 390900) Boil neem leaves in water and wash the blisters with that.
('85', 237, 3, 22, 390959) The water should be bearably hot.
('85', 237, 3, 23, 390993) Cover the blisters with a mud pack of clean earth.
('85', 237, 3, 24, 391044) Get clean cloth for bandaging the blisters.
('85', 237, 3, 25, 391088) If you can get tamarind you can give a solution of it in place of water mixed with lemon juice.
('85', 237, 3, 26, 391184) Revive people’s knowledge of nature cure remedies.
('85', 237, 3, 27, 391235) Local medicinal drugs should be made available.
('85', 237, 3, 28, 391283) Give rice water instead of milk.
('85', 237, 3, 29, 391316) If you mix jaggery with it, it will provide more energy.
('85', 237, 3, 30, 391373) Teach people the rules of hygiene.
('85', 237, 3, 31, 391408) If food is stopped to people suffering from fever or diarrhoea and they are put on boiled water, more than fifty per cent of the cases will recover.
('85', 237, 3, 32, 391557) I have no doubt in my mind about this at all.
('85', 237, 3, 33, 391603) Fifty per cent is a conservative guess.
('85', 237, 3, 34, 391643) For guinea worm, try fomentation with hot water and tie up the thing as it comes out.
('85', 237, 3, 35, 391729) Try also a poultice of onions.
('85', 237, 3, 36, 391760) You must have received the suggestions sent by Kishorelalbhai and Sushilabehn.

('85', 237, 3, 38, 391884) Let Devibehn send whatever she wishes.
('85', 237, 3, 39, 391923) If cows, buffaloes or goats are offered, accept them.

('85', 237, 3, 42, 392078) These things should be served hot after boiling them.

('85', 252, 11, 21, 413285) For us such festivals are for meditation and introspection.

('85', 252, 11, 23, 413423) We should know that

('85', 253, 0, 1, 413623) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 254
('85', 253, 1, 2, 413665) God is one, whether we call Him Ishwara or Khuda, and that His commands are the same for all.
('85', 253, 1, 3, 413759) We should not harm others for what we regard as Truth or right.
('85', 253, 1, 4, 413823) We should be prepared to die for Truth and when the call comes give our life for it and sanctify it with our blood.
('85', 253, 1, 5, 413939) This in my view is the essence of all religions.
('85', 253, 1, 6, 413988) On this day we should ponder upon this and remember that Jesus mounted the Cross for what he considered to be the Truth.

('85', 253, 3, 8, 414188) 410. LETTER TO BENARSIDAS CHATURVEDI
('85', 253, 4, 9, 414225) SEVAGRAM, December 27, 1944
('85', 253, 5, 10, 414253) BHAI BENARSIDAS, It is natural to feel sad at Father’s passing away but if we reflect for a moment we shall realize that it is futile to grieve over the inevitable.

('85', 253, 7, 17, 414747) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 2575
('85', 254, 0, 1, 414788) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 255
('85', 254, 1, 2, 414831) 411. A THOUGHT FOR THE DAY 1
('85', 254, 2, 3, 414860) November 20, 1944 Innumerable are the names of God; but if a choice were to be made of one, it would be Sat or Satya, that is, Truth.
('85', 254, 2, 4, 414994) Hence verily Truth is God.
('85', 254, 2, 5, 415021) November 21, 1944 Realization of Truth is not at all possible without ahimsa.
('85', 254, 2, 6, 415099) That is why it has been said that ahimsa is the supreme dharma.
('85', 254, 2, 7, 415163) November 22, 1944 The quest of truth and the observance of non violence are impossible without brahmacharya, non stealing, non possession, fearlessness, equal respect for all religions, removal of untouchability and the like.
('85', 254, 2, 8, 415389) November 23, 1944 Brahmacharya here mean control over the sense organs—in thought, word and deed.
('85', 254, 2, 9, 415487) One who, while remaining bodily chaste, is impure at heart shall not be deemed a true brahmachari.
('85', 254, 2, 10, 415586) November 24, 1944 Non stealing does not mean mere abstention from theft.
('85', 254, 2, 11, 415659) To keep or take what one does not need is also stealing.
('85', 254, 2, 12, 415716) And of course stealing is fraught with violence.
('85', 254, 2, 13, 415765) November 25, 1944 Non possession means that we should not hoard anything that we do not need today.
('85', 254, 2, 14, 415865) November 26,1944 Fearlessness should connote absence of all kinds of fear—fear of death, fear of bodily injury, fear of hunger, fear of insult, fear of public disapprobation, fear of ghosts and evil spirits, fear of anyone’s anger.
('85', 254, 2, 15, 416097) Freedom from all these and such other fears constitutes fearlessness.
('85', 254, 2, 16, 416167) November 27,1944 Let us respect other religions even as we respect our own.
('85', 254, 3, 17, 416243) 1 At the request of Anand T. Hingorani Gandhiji on November 20, 1944, started the practice of writing ‘a thought’ for each day and continued it for about two years.
('85', 254, 3, 18, 416408) Those written during the period covered by this volume are given here as a single item under the last date, namely, December 31, 1944. The thoughts were originally written in Hindi.

('85', 255, 1, 2, 416632) tolerance thereof is not enough.
('85', 255, 1, 3, 416665) November 28, 1944 Removal of untouchability means not merely touching the Harijans, but also looking upon them as our own kith and kin; in other words, treating them in the same way as we would our own brothers and sisters.
('85', 255, 1, 4, 416889) None is high, none low.
('85', 255, 1, 5, 416913) November 29, 1944 Yogah Chittavrittinirodhah—This is the first aphorism of Patanjali’s Yoga Darshan 1. Yoga is controlling the activities of the mind.
('85', 255, 1, 6, 417064) Restraining the surging passions, suppressing them, that is yoga.
('85', 255, 1, 7, 417130) November 30, 1944 How can one is whose mind passions keep surging ever realize truth?
('85', 255, 1, 8, 417216) The upsurge of passions in the mind is like a tempest in the ocean.
('85', 255, 1, 9, 417284) The helmsman who holds fast to the helm in a storm remains safe.
('85', 255, 1, 10, 417349) Likewise, he triumphs who relies upon Ramanama when the mind is restless.
('85', 255, 1, 11, 417423) December 1, 1944 The bhajan “Take Thou a Lesson from the Tree” 2 is worth laying to one’s heart.
('85', 255, 1, 12, 417520) The tree bears the heat of the sun, yet provides cool shade to us.
('85', 255, 1, 13, 417587) What do we do?
('85', 255, 1, 14, 417602) December 2, 1944 Let us always beware of false knowledge.
('85', 255, 1, 15, 417660) That which keeps or turns us away from Truth is false knowledge.
('85', 255, 1, 16, 417725) December 3, 1944 For the realization of Truth it is necessary to read the lives of the saints and reflect upon them.
('85', 255, 1, 17, 417842) December 4, 1944 Against whom shall we harbour enmity when God Himself says that He dwells in all living beings?
('85', 255, 1, 18, 417955) (Translation of today’s bhajan.) December 5, 1944 The great lesson that we learn from the life of Mirabai is that she renounced her all—even her husband—for the sake of God.
('85', 255, 1, 19, 418129) December 6, 1944 What can a person not accomplish by faith?

('85', 256, 1, 2, 418341) December 8, 1944 He who concentrates on any one thing with singleness of purpose, will ultimately acquire the capacity to do everything.
('85', 256, 1, 3, 418478) December 9, 1944 True happiness does not come from without; it comes from within.
('85', 256, 1, 4, 418560) December 10, 1944 He who loses his individuality loses all.
('85', 256, 1, 5, 418620) December 11, 1944 The straight path is as difficult as it is simple.
('85', 256, 1, 6, 418689) Were it not so, all would follow the straight path.
('85', 256, 1, 7, 418741) December 12, 1944 “Compassion is the essence of religion,” so Tulsidas has said.
('85', 256, 1, 8, 418822) And he adds: “Abandon not compassion as long as you live.” Suppliants for compassion ourselves, all of us, how shall we take compassion, and on whom?
('85', 256, 1, 9, 418972) December 13, 1944 A sister said: “I used to pray, but have now given it up.” I asked: “Why?” She replied: “Because I used to deceive myself.” The reply is of course correct.
('85', 256, 1, 10, 419146) But let her give up deceiving.
('85', 256, 1, 11, 419177) Why give up praying?
('85', 256, 1, 12, 419198) December 14, 1944 Yesterday’s bhajan was very melodious and worth pondering over.
('85', 256, 1, 13, 419280) It says in essence: God dwells neither in the temple, nor in the mosque.
('85', 256, 1, 14, 419353) Neither within, nor without.
('85', 256, 1, 15, 419382) If at all He is anywhere, it is in the hunger and the thirst of the humble folk.
('85', 256, 1, 16, 419463) Let us spin daily in order to sate their hunger and quench their thirst, or, with Ramanama on our lips, engage ourselves in some such labour for their sake.
('85', 256, 1, 17, 419620) December 15, 1944 Why is it that even ordinarily we do not escape untruth be it out of fear or even shame?
('85', 256, 1, 18, 419727) Would it not be better to adopt silence instead, or, shedding fear of one another, speak frankly what is in our mind?
('85', 256, 1, 19, 419845) December 16, 1944 Even a little untruth ruins a man, as a drop of poison ruins milk.
('85', 256, 1, 20, 419930) December 17, 1944 We are loath to devote time to things that matter, but hanker after worthless things and find pleasure in them!!!
('85', 256, 1, 21, 420062) December 18, 1944 “Man is not God; call him not that.

('85', 257, 0, 1, 420144) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 258

('85', 257, 1, 3, 420291) But if you have not enthroned God in your heart, you have achieved nothing.
('85', 257, 1, 4, 420367) December 20, 1944 We all desire mukti 1 but, perhaps, we do not know precisely what it means.
('85', 257, 1, 5, 420461) Deliverance from the cycle of birth and death is one of its several meanings.
('85', 257, 1, 6, 420539) December 21, 1944 The poet saint Narsinh says: “A man of God seeks not deliverance from birth and death; he asks to be born again and again.” Viewed from this angle, mukti takes on a somewhat different form.
('85', 257, 1, 7, 420747) December 22, 1944 Extreme non attachment is salvation, according to the Gita, and we find the same meaning given in the first verse of the Ishopanishad.
('85', 257, 1, 8, 420900) December 23, 1944 How to develop non attachment?
('85', 257, 1, 9, 420949) This can be done by regarding joy and sorrow, friend and foe, mine and thine, as all alike.
('85', 257, 1, 10, 421041) Thus another name for non attachment is equanimity.
('85', 257, 1, 11, 421093) December 24, 1944 As drops add up to make the ocean, we can be friendly and become an ocean of friendliness.
('85', 257, 1, 12, 421202) The world would be transformed if everyone in the world lived in a spirit of mutual amity.
('85', 257, 1, 13, 421293) December 25, 1944 Today is Christmas Day.
('85', 257, 1, 14, 421335) For us who believe in the equality of all religions, the birth of Jesus Christ is as worthy of veneration as that of Rama, Krishna, etc.

('85', 258, 1, 3, 421938) December 29, 1944 Numerous are our ailments; numerous, too, are physicians and their treatments.
('85', 258, 1, 4, 422035) But we would be spared much bother if we regarded all diseases as one and Rama as the one and only Physician who can eradicate them.
('85', 258, 1, 5, 422168) December 30, 1944 How strange that we run after physicians who are mortals themselves but forget Rama, the immortal, eternal and never failing Physician!
('85', 258, 1, 6, 422322) December 31, 1944 Stranger still it is that, knowing that we, too, are mortal and that a doctor’s treatment can at best but prolong our life for a few more days, we still run from pillar to post to seek it.

('85', 275, 1, 2, 446340) 446. TRIBUTE TO ROMAIN ROLLAND 1
('85', 275, 2, 3, 446373) WARDHA, January 10, 1945 Having been once bitten, I am too shy to believe in Romain Rolland’s reported death.
('85', 275, 2, 4, 446483) But it seems that this report is true.
('85', 275, 2, 5, 446522) And yet for me as for many millions, Romain Rolland is not dead.
('85', 275, 2, 6, 446587) He truly lives through his famous writings and perhaps more so through his many and nameless deeds.
('85', 275, 2, 7, 446687) He lived for truth and non violence as he saw and believed them from time to time.
('85', 275, 2, 8, 446770) He responded to all suffering.
('85', 275, 2, 9, 446801) He revolted against the wanton human butchery called war.
('85', 275, 2, 10, 446859) The Hitavada, 12 1 1945

('85', 275, 8, 20, 447152) 448. FOREWORD TO “TUKARAM KI RASHTRAGATHA”
('85', 275, 9, 21, 447195) SEVAGRAM, January 10, 1945 Dr. Indubhushan Bhingare had published earlier the first edition of Sant Tukaram ki Rashtragatha.
('85', 275, 9, 22, 447320) The present edition is the revised one.
('85', 275, 9, 23, 447360) My knowledge of Marathi is very slight.
('85', 275, 9, 24, 447400) I like Tukaram very much.
('85', 275, 9, 25, 447426) But I could read only a few of his abhangas without effort.I therefore passed on Dr. Bhingare’s selection to Kundarji Diwan who took great pains to go through the whole thing.
('85', 275, 10, 26, 447602) 1 Romain Rolland died on December 30, 1944, in Vezelay, France.
('85', 275, 10, 27, 447666) 2 Vide the following item.

('85', 276, 1, 2, 447736) The Gatha needed a fitting picture.
('85', 276, 1, 3, 447772) Dr. Bhingare had selected a cheap one.
('85', 276, 1, 4, 447811) It hurt me very much.
('85', 276, 1, 5, 447833) I sent it to Shri Nandalal Bose, the renowned Santiniketan artist.
('85', 276, 1, 6, 447900) He has been kind enough to send me four pictures of Tukaram to go with the abhangas.
('85', 276, 1, 7, 447985) I sent the one that I thought the best among them to Bhingare and it will be published in this edition.
('85', 276, 1, 8, 448089) I hope this edition will command the respect of people.

('85', 276, 3, 12, 448220) 449. A FOREWORD
('85', 276, 4, 13, 448236) January 10, 1945 The Ishavasya gripped me during my Harijan tour of Travancore.
('85', 276, 4, 14, 448316) All my speeches invariably included the first verse of this Upanishad: “All that is pervaded by God.
('85', 276, 4, 15, 448417) It all belongs to Him, therefore nothing belongs to you.
('85', 276, 4, 16, 448474) But in a way it is yours too.
('85', 276, 4, 17, 448504) But why get caught in the argument?
('85', 276, 4, 18, 448540) Renounce all, and all is yours.
('85', 276, 4, 19, 448572) Nothing will remain in your hands if you regard anything as yours.” This was the note with which I concluded my Travancore tour and I felt that I had come by a treasure.
('85', 276, 4, 20, 448742) I told Vinoba and requested him to give me a simple Hindi rendering of the Ishavasya.
('85', 276, 4, 21, 448828) As is his wont he granted my request.
('85', 276, 4, 22, 448866) The result is this translation.
('85', 276, 4, 23, 448898) M. K. GANDHI
('85', 276, 5, 24, 448911) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.
('85', 276, 5, 25, 448954) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('85', 276, 6, 26, 448973) 450. LETTER TO AMTUSSALAAM
('85', 276, 7, 27, 449000) SEVAGRAM, January 10, 1945
('85', 276, 8, 28, 449027) DAUGHTER A. S., I have read your letter to Sushilabehn.
('85', 276, 8, 29, 449083) If you must come here, come when you find the time.
('85', 276, 8, 30, 449135) Your falling ill is not good and is contrary to our pact.
('85', 276, 8, 31, 449193) Dying is not an ideal.
('85', 276, 8, 32, 449216) Indulging in such things is false attachment.
('85', 276, 8, 33, 449262) You must free yourself from that.
('85', 276, 8, 34, 449296) Do preside over the meeting if you wish.
('85', 276, 8, 35, 449337) But your giving a lecture on the basis of a note sent from here is pointless.
('85', 276, 8, 36, 449415) You should give to the meeting what you have digested.
('85', 276, 8, 37, 449470) If the officer has sent you the money without attaching any
('85', 277, 0, 1, 449530) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 278
('85', 277, 1, 2, 449572) conditions, I see no harm in your accepting it 1. It is different that having gone into the matter further I may suggest something else.
('85', 277, 1, 3, 449709) Your worrying about my health shows that you know neither God nor me.
('85', 277, 1, 4, 449779) If you knew God, you would realize that you, I and everyone else are solely in His hands.
('85', 277, 1, 5, 449869) If you knew me, you would know that I take every possible precaution.
('85', 277, 1, 6, 449939) There are lapses nonetheless, but what can one do about it.
('85', 277, 1, 7, 449999) However, I am maintaining good health.
('85', 277, 1, 8, 450038) Under any circumstances you need not worry.
('85', 277, 1, 9, 450082) I repeat you may come any time you wish.
('85', 277, 1, 10, 450123) You have nothing to do with the 26th of January.
('85', 277, 1, 11, 450172) You are all the time doing that work.

('85', 278, 1, 2, 450924) 452. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
('85', 278, 2, 3, 450950) [Before January 11, 1945] 1
('85', 278, 3, 4, 450978) [QUESTION]: If it is possible to meet the Working Committee, will you try to persuade the Working Committee to accept this plan 2?
('85', 278, 3, 5, 451109) [ANSWER]: Yes.
('85', 278, 4, 6, 451124) Q. What are your arguments in favour of this plan?
('85', 278, 4, 7, 451175) A. After my talks with Jinnah, Jinnah told many people that Gandhi had not even mentioned Interim Government.
('85', 278, 4, 8, 451285) Bhulabhai’s effort is a reply to this.
('85', 278, 4, 9, 451324) But if the intentions of the League are not genuine, nothing will come out of it.
('85', 278, 5, 10, 451406) Q. What happens if the Viceroy uses his veto over the head of the Congress and the League?
('85', 278, 5, 11, 451497) A. In that case there will be an agreement between Bhulabhai and Liaquat Ali that the Government will resign.
('85', 278, 6, 12, 451607) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book I, p.

('85', 278, 9, 19, 451892) I am sending Ramjibhai’s letter on to him.
('85', 278, 9, 20, 451935) It seems good.

('85', 280, 1, 2, 453267) 456. SPEECH AT HINDUSTANI TALIMI SANGH CONFERENCE 1
('85', 280, 2, 3, 453319) SEVAGRAM, January 11, 1945 2
('85', 280, 3, 4, 453348) ZAKIR SAHEB, ARYANAYAKUMJI, SHRIMATI ASHADEVI AND BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I had hoped to speak a few words while opening this Conference, but God had willed otherwise.
('85', 280, 3, 5, 453514) I had to observe silence because of a cough, and other things.
('85', 280, 3, 6, 453577) Therefore I have written down what I wanted to say.
('85', 280, 3, 7, 453629) Although we have been working for Nayee Talim all these years, we have so far been, as it were, sailing in an inland sea which is comparatively safer.
('85', 280, 3, 8, 453780) We are now leaving the shoals and heading for the open sea.
('85', 280, 3, 9, 453840) So far our course was mapped out.
('85', 280, 3, 10, 453874) We have now before us uncharted waters, with the Pole Star as our only guide and protection.
('85', 280, 3, 11, 453967) That Pole Star is village handicrafts.
('85', 280, 3, 12, 454006) Our sphere of work now is not confined to Nayee Talim of children from seven to fourteen years; it is to cover the whole of life from the moment of conception to the moment of death.
('85', 280, 3, 13, 454189) This means that our work has increased tremendously.
('85', 280, 3, 14, 454242) Yet workers remain the same.
('85', 280, 3, 15, 454271) But that should not worry us.
('85', 280, 3, 16, 454301) Our guide and companion is Truth which is God.
('85', 280, 3, 17, 454348) He will never betray us.
('85', 280, 3, 18, 454373) But Truth will be our help only if we stand by it regardless of everything.
('85', 280, 3, 19, 454449) There can be in it no room for hypocrisy, camouflage, pride, attachment or anger.
('85', 280, 3, 20, 454531) We have to become teachers of villagers; that is to say, we have to become their servants in the true sense.
('85', 280, 3, 21, 454640) Our reward if any, has to come from within and not from without.
('85', 280, 3, 22, 454705) It should make no difference to us whether in our quest for Truth we have any human company or not.
('85', 280, 3, 23, 454805) Nor does Nayee Talim depend on outside financial help.
('85', 280, 3, 24, 454860) It must proceed on its own way, whatever critics might say.
('85', 280, 3, 25, 454920) I know that true education must be self supporting.
('85', 280, 3, 26, 454972) There is nothing to feel ashamed of in this.
('85', 280, 3, 27, 455017) It may be a novel idea if we can make good our claim and demonstrate that ours is the only method for the true development of the mind.
('85', 280, 3, 28, 455153) Those who scoff at Nayee Talim today will become its ardent admirers in the end and Nayee Talim will find universal acceptance.
('85', 280, 4, 29, 455281) 1 The four day conference, attended by more than 200 educationists, was held under the presidentship of Zakir Husain, who read out Gandhiji’s speech.
('85', 280, 4, 30, 455431) 2 From The Hindu, 11 1 1945
('85', 281, 0, 1, 455459) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 282
('85', 281, 1, 2, 455501) Seven lakhs of our villages, which are today the symbol of our poverty in every sense, ought to become prosperous in the real sense.
('85', 281, 1, 3, 455634) This prosperity will not come from outside; it will grow from within the villages as a result of the labour of every villager.
('85', 281, 1, 4, 455761) Whether this is a mere dream or a practical reality, this is the goal of Nayee Talim and nothing short of it.
('85', 281, 1, 5, 455871) May the God of Truth help us to realize it.
('85', 281, 1, 6, 455915) I have gone through the balance sheet of the Talimi Sangh.
('85', 281, 1, 7, 455974) It shows that whatever we have spent has been spent with due care and consideration.
('85', 281, 1, 8, 456059) It is a brief document.
('85', 281, 1, 9, 456083) I hope everyone will go through it carefully.
('85', 281, 1, 10, 456129) The question of language as such does not fall within the scope of Nayee Talim but the question of the medium of instruction does and that must always be the mother tongue.
('85', 281, 1, 11, 456302) This point cannot be over emphasized.
('85', 281, 1, 12, 456340) Equally important is the question of a national or all India language.
('85', 281, 1, 13, 456411) It can never be English.
('85', 281, 1, 14, 456436) English is undoubtedly the language of the rulers and of international commerce.
('85', 281, 1, 15, 456517) But Hindi Hindustani alone can be our national language.
('85', 281, 1, 16, 456574) At present ithas two forms.
('85', 281, 1, 17, 456602) In order to understand both the forms of the national language, viz., Hindi and Urdu, and for their natural synthesis we must learn the Devanagari and Persian scripts.
('85', 281, 1, 18, 456770) I find this lacking even in my immediate surroundings.
('85', 281, 1, 19, 456825) All our sign boards 1 must be written in both the scripts and there should be none amongst us who cannot easily read and write either.
('85', 281, 1, 20, 456960) I want to draw your attention also to another thing.
('85', 281, 1, 21, 457013) I consider the Sevagram centre to be an ideal centre for conducting the central experiment in Nayee Talim, as it is here that the Charkha Sangh is carrying out its main experiments.
('85', 281, 1, 22, 457195) Wardha is the centre for the other village industries.
('85', 281, 1, 23, 457250) Experiments for the improvement of cattle, which is service of the cow in the true sense, are also being conducted here.
('85', 281, 1, 24, 457371) Sevagram does not stand alone; there are nearly 20 villages lying about it in close proximity.
('85', 281, 1, 25, 457466) Therefore if experiments in Nayee Talim in its most natural form can be carried out anywhere, it is here.
('85', 281, 1, 26, 457572) The various institutions mentioned above are not rival organizations; they are complementary and are calculated to supplement one another’s efforts.
('85', 281, 1, 27, 457721) That is the hallmark of a revolution of love.
('85', 281, 1, 28, 457767) [From Hindi]
('85', 281, 2, 29, 457780) Samagra Nayee Talim
('85', 281, 3, 30, 457800) 1 From The Hindu, 13 1 1945; the source however has ‘teaching’.
('85', 282, 0, 1, 457864) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 283
('85', 282, 1, 2, 457907) 457. A LETTER 1
('85', 282, 2, 3, 457923) [Before January 12, 1945] 2
('85', 282, 3, 4, 457951) I have no partiality for any militant programme for 26th January.
('85', 282, 3, 5, 458017) According to my idea, the constructive programme is the programme.
('85', 282, 3, 6, 458084) Therefore, it should be prosecuted with redoubled zeal.
('85', 282, 3, 7, 458140) Flag salutation with the reading of the independence pledge 3 has become an inseparable item.
('85', 282, 3, 8, 458234) It should, therefore, be retained.
('85', 282, 3, 9, 458269) But I would avoid mass gatherings and processions.
('85', 282, 3, 10, 458320) My advice should be followed only if it appeals to the head and the heart.
('85', 282, 3, 11, 458395) However, if the significance of the constructive programme has been properly understood, I am sure my advice will not fail to find a ready response.
('85', 282, 3, 12, 458544) The Hindu, 15 1 1954

('85', 286, 7, 12, 464129) SEVAGRAM, January 14, 1945

('85', 286, 8, 14, 464226) It has caused me great pain.
('85', 286, 8, 15, 464255) Though your Association’s work is humanitarian on your own showing, it touches hardly the fringe.
('85', 286, 8, 16, 464353) The problem is medical only in a very small measure.
('85', 286, 8, 17, 464406) The deterioration will continue in spite of your medical effort.

('85', 286, 8, 21, 464671) Outsiders will bring little relief, money will bring less.
('85', 286, 8, 22, 464730) Give the people milk and other food, their dwellings and their boats and I am positive that no medicine will be needed.
('85', 286, 8, 23, 464850) Your report makes me more and more eager to rush to Bengal and make common cause with the starving dumb masses.
('85', 286, 8, 24, 464962) But I know I cannot rush.
('85', 286, 8, 25, 464988) I do not want a palace like jail.
('85', 286, 8, 26, 465022) I want to be with the people and touch their decaying bones.

('85', 288, 7, 8, 466341) BHAI JAJUJI, I know that if a true worker goes to any village he will become self supporting within a short time.

('85', 288, 7, 10, 466521) We shall provide him no paraphernalia because the villagers themselves will supply the things.

('85', 288, 7, 12, 466693) He will of course carry a knife with him.
('85', 288, 7, 13, 466735) If nothing else he will at least teach the children.
('85', 288, 7, 14, 466788) They will make taklis from bamboo and spin.
('85', 288, 7, 15, 466832) If no cotton is grown in the village he will choose another occupation.
('85', 288, 7, 16, 466904) But we shall start with a village where cotton is grown.

('85', 288, 7, 18, 467009) Ask me more questions if you want.

('85', 295, 1, 2, 476447) programme.
('85', 295, 2, 3, 476458) P. M. What should the students do to strengthen the Congress?
('85', 295, 3, 4, 476520) G. The students must identify themselves with the aims and ideals of the National Congress and, by being part and parcel of it, they must continue to struggle against the foreign rule.
('85', 295, 4, 5, 476705) P.M. Should the students’ organizations have a separate identity or should they align themselves with the different political parties?
('85', 295, 5, 6, 476840) G. Students should do in this case what they think proper and advantageous for their organization and if experience proves otherwise, they must give up party affiliations.
('85', 295, 5, 7, 477012) Students should not indulge in unnecessary abuse of students belonging to a different ideology.
('85', 295, 5, 8, 477108) However, they must strengthen the Indian National Congress and prepare it for the final fight for freedom by doing silent service.
('85', 295, 5, 9, 477239) The Hindu, 19 1 1945

('85', 295, 7, 11, 477300) January 17, 1945
('85', 295, 8, 12, 477317) T. V. KUNHIKRISHNAN: You know the Communists took an attitude of hostility to the political activities of students in 1942 and afterwards.
('85', 295, 8, 13, 477456) The Indian Students’ Congress embodies to some extent the faith and aspirations of students who are opposed to the attitude of the Communist section.
('85', 295, 8, 14, 477606) Here are some of our questions: Have we the right to exclude Communists and oppose their attitude and tactics?
('85', 295, 8, 15, 477717) Please do not tell us that this is a minor provincial question.
('85', 295, 8, 16, 477781) We want your guidance in this matter.
('85', 295, 8, 17, 477819) GANDHIJI: I dislike the idea of excluding anybody because of his label.
('85', 295, 8, 18, 477891) But use your independent judgment.
('85', 295, 9, 19, 477926) T. V. K. Are we right in building up a new all India organization for students?
('85', 295, 9, 20, 478006) G. You [are] 2, if it fits in with the Congress idea 3.
('85', 295, 10, 21, 478062) T. V. K. What particular item of the Constructive Programme do you think can best be done by students?
('85', 295, 10, 22, 478165) G. So many items to choose from.

('85', 298, 1, 2, 481072) 489. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('85', 298, 2, 3, 481104) January 18, 1945 I have read the whole thing.
('85', 298, 2, 4, 481150) You have poured out your heart in it, which was the right thing to do.
('85', 298, 2, 5, 481221) You are still unsteady.
('85', 298, 2, 6, 481245) For the unsteadiness to go you must remain in the institution and give yourself wholly to it.
('85', 298, 2, 7, 481339) So it should be the same to you whether it is Jajuji or Chimanlal or I. You should obey the head whoever he be.
('85', 298, 2, 8, 481451) Therein lies your training.
('85', 298, 2, 9, 481479) If, however, that is not possible for you, I shall not mind if you two live together away from the Ashram.
('85', 298, 2, 10, 481586) I doubt, though, whether you will then be able to observe brahmacharya.
('85', 298, 2, 11, 481658) But what even if you cannot?
('85', 298, 2, 12, 481687) It will be no crime.
('85', 298, 2, 13, 481708) You two are married and should be free to do as you like.
('85', 298, 2, 14, 481766) Whatever you do, you should do together and with deliberation and determination.
('85', 298, 2, 15, 481847) Even while remaining in the institution you will continue to serve the people.
('85', 298, 2, 16, 481926) In fact you will then do it better.
('85', 298, 2, 17, 481962) But even here you must do as you think best.
('85', 298, 2, 18, 482007) If you wish me to guide you, you will of course have my guidance whenever you ask it.
('85', 298, 2, 19, 482093) If you can be more specific about the difficulties you mention, I may perhaps be able to solve them.
('85', 298, 2, 20, 482194) The irregularity you mention cannot be tolerated.
('85', 298, 2, 21, 482244) Give me the details.
('85', 298, 2, 22, 482265) If something is unavoidable we shall put up with it, but we will do that with our eyes open.
('85', 298, 2, 23, 482358) I can understand about Nanavati.
('85', 298, 2, 24, 482391) He is ill, but he is a tried worker.
('85', 298, 2, 25, 482428) I believe that one should not eat for the pleasure of the palate.
('85', 298, 2, 26, 482494) Chimanlal is an old timer.
('85', 298, 2, 27, 482521) Well or ill he has stuck on.
('85', 298, 2, 28, 482550) He goes on working silently.
('85', 298, 2, 29, 482579) You should have regard for his services.
('85', 298, 2, 30, 482620) The secret of good life is strictness with oneself and generosity to co workers.
('85', 298, 2, 31, 482701) Why need you keep anything private?
('85', 298, 2, 32, 482737) Blessings from BAPU
('85', 298, 3, 33, 482757) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 5814. Courtesy: Munnalal G. Shah

('85', 299, 3, 4, 482932) VASUMATI, I have your letter.
('85', 299, 3, 5, 482962) I had your previous letters too.

('85', 299, 3, 12, 483159) It is all the better that you have not carried with you a lot of medicines.
('85', 299, 3, 13, 483235) A number of ailments disappear with very slight treatment.
('85', 299, 3, 14, 483294) It is superstition to insist on drugs.
('85', 299, 3, 15, 483333) Local herbs are a different matter.
('85', 299, 3, 16, 483369) For stomach ache one should fast, drink hot water and take hot water fomentation.
('85', 299, 3, 17, 483451) If there are loose motions fasting is imperative.
('85', 299, 3, 18, 483501) If the patient insists he may be given a pinch of soda bi carb or powdered neem leaves.
('85', 299, 3, 19, 483589) If anybody has a headache, he should have a mud pack on the head and drink lots of water and so on.
('85', 299, 3, 20, 483689) This is just to point the way.
('85', 299, 3, 21, 483720) Have patience, think for yourself, repeat Ramanama and persuade others to do so.

('85', 301, 1, 2, 485864) 494. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('85', 301, 2, 3, 485896) January 19, 1945 It was good you wrote.
('85', 301, 2, 4, 485936) You could have said all that in one paragraph.
('85', 301, 2, 5, 485983) Brevity is an art.
('85', 301, 2, 6, 486002) If you cultivate that art you will have a means of achieving steadiness of mind.
('85', 301, 2, 7, 486083) Of course, if you cannot be brief, you have to say what you must, even if you are long winded.
('85', 301, 2, 8, 486178) I understand about privacy.
('85', 301, 2, 9, 486206) 1 The reason you give does not appeal to me.
('85', 301, 2, 10, 486251) Let critics say what they like.
('85', 301, 2, 11, 486283) I shall, however, respect your wish so long as it remains your wish.
('85', 301, 2, 12, 486352) I do not wish that you should hide Chimanlal’s defects as long as you see any in him.
('85', 301, 2, 13, 486438) I only expressed my opinion.
('85', 301, 2, 14, 486467) It may perhaps be of some help.
('85', 301, 2, 15, 486499) The same about Nanavati.
('85', 301, 2, 16, 486524) What you say surprises me.
('85', 301, 2, 17, 486551) I would ask him further if he were here.
('85', 301, 2, 18, 486592) I do think he will come back.
('85', 301, 2, 19, 486622) It would be good if you addressed brief notes to those who make mistakes or shirk work.
('85', 301, 2, 20, 486710) I only wish to help.
('85', 301, 2, 21, 486731) But would it not make it difficult to improve things if I did not mention what you wrote, did not know the names nor what lapses had occurred?
('85', 301, 2, 22, 486874) You should have definite work.
('85', 301, 2, 23, 486905) I assume you have.
('85', 301, 2, 24, 486924) But if that is not so, I am willing to give you whatever help you ask for.
('85', 301, 2, 25, 486999) You should welcome any new suggestions I make.
('85', 301, 2, 26, 487046) They may seem new, but in fact they are not new.
('85', 301, 2, 27, 487095) They are at the very root of our way of life.
('85', 301, 2, 28, 487141) If I am not to make such suggestions, my presence here is useless.
('85', 301, 2, 29, 487208) How many of the suggestions I make can be implemented is of course another matter and that is for you to decide.
('85', 301, 2, 30, 487321) I was indeed very happy to read about brahmacharya.
('85', 301, 2, 31, 487373) 2 I believe it applies to both of you.
('85', 301, 2, 32, 487412) What you say is news to me and I rejoice at it.
('85', 301, 3, 33, 487460) Blessings from BAPU

('85', 304, 5, 12, 491170) 500. LETTER TO JEHANGIR PATEL January 20, 1945 DEAR JEHANGIRJI, Bapu had your letter of 11th inst.
('85', 304, 5, 13, 491269) He is glad you enjoyed the charming scenery and climate of Ooty.
('85', 304, 5, 14, 491334) Thanks for the honey and the eucalyptus which you have sent.
('85', 304, 5, 15, 491395) The parcel was received yesterday.
('85', 304, 5, 16, 491430) Bapu was very sorry to hear about the demise of Zabair’s wife.
('85', 304, 5, 17, 491493) He hopes Zubair will take the bereavement bravely.
('85', 304, 5, 18, 491544) So called adversities are sent to us to test our faith.
('85', 304, 5, 19, 491600) Is not life itself a discipline and a probation ?

('85', 327, 11, 21, 521366) 547. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('85', 327, 12, 22, 521396) SEVAGRAM January 26, 1945 With the independence of India is bound up freedom for the whole of exploited humanity in the world—for even exploiters i.e.,
('85', 328, 0, 1, 521548) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 329
('85', 328, 1, 2, 521591) imperialist England and other imperialisms.
('85', 328, 2, 3, 521635) Referring to an incident that occurred that morning in front of the Ashram, when the police attempted to interfere with the normal village cleaning programme of the workers, Gandhiji said that it had been repeatedly announced that there was to be no militant programme on the Independence Day and after that it was not possible for anyone to offer civil resistance.
('85', 328, 2, 4, 522001) Members of the various institutions in Sevagram worked under his guidance.
('85', 328, 2, 5, 522076) Gandhiji said he had placed the Constructive Programme before the country years ago and it was the only way of attaining swaraj, i.e., full freedom through truth and non violence.
('85', 328, 2, 6, 522256) While he did not want a militant programme he had also said that if anyone interfered with the execution of constructive work, he expected the people to die rather than turn back.
('85', 328, 2, 7, 522436) One such occasion arose that morning when a batch 1
('85', 328, 3, 8, 522488) proceeding mutely with pickaxes, shovels, broomsticks and baskets was stopped.
('85', 328, 3, 9, 522567) They were not carrying fighting weapons and yet the police would allow them to proceed only if they broke up file.
('85', 328, 3, 10, 522682) In such circumstances, non violence would be sheer cowardice if they yielded and bent before authority.
('85', 328, 3, 11, 522786) Their hymn for that evening was exceptionally appropriate, Gandhiji continuing said, and its central theme was, that true happiness lay only in the womb of unhappiness.
('85', 328, 3, 12, 522955) For the hearers it meant that true happiness, i.e., swaraj, came only through unhappiness, i.e., self suffering.
('85', 328, 3, 13, 523068) The volunteers did right in refusing to break up file and at the same time not breaking through the police cordon.
('85', 328, 3, 14, 523183) Though the police had fire arms they were rendered useless through the dignified and yet firm attitude of the volunteers.
('85', 328, 3, 15, 523305) 2 They were neither to invite firing nor avoid it and for them real authority was the dictate of their hearts which Gandhiji would call God or Truth.
('85', 328, 3, 16, 523455) For me, true independence is convertible with God.
('85', 328, 3, 17, 523506) Tilak has given a mantra that “Swaraj is our birthright”.
('85', 328, 3, 18, 523564) It is a simple one.
('85', 328, 3, 19, 523584) I will only add that the way to realize the mantra is through truth andnon violence and I claim that that way is possible only if millions work the Constructive Programme.
('85', 328, 3, 20, 523756) Concluding, Gandhiji warned the volunteers not to gloat over their success, for, if they did so, that very pride would prove their destruction.
('85', 328, 3, 21, 523900) Humility, he said, should be their touchstone.
('85', 328, 3, 22, 523947) The Hindu, 29 1 1945
('85', 328, 4, 23, 523968) 1 250 members of various institutions in Sevagram 2 After two hours the police withdrew and the cleaning programme was completed.

('85', 339, 1, 2, 538731) 567. DISCUSSION WITH ANUGRAHA NARAYAN SINHA
('85', 339, 2, 3, 538775) WARDHA, January 31, 1945
('85', 339, 3, 4, 538800) Mr. Sinha 1 discussed with Mahatma Gandhi the qualifications of constructive workers whether they choose to work among the labour or among the students.
('85', 339, 3, 5, 538953) The following appear to be the minimum qualifications for such workers: (1) Spinning of certain quantity of yarn regularly each month.
('85', 339, 3, 6, 539088) (2) Giving preference to such articles for personal consumption as are locally manufactured on the basis of cottage industries.
('85', 339, 3, 7, 539216) (3) To have full and active faith in non violence and truth as understood by Mahatmaji.
('85', 339, 3, 8, 539304) Mahatmaji, it is understood, told Mr. Sinha that the above test was good and it could easily be made stiffer.

('85', 339, 6, 11, 539476) [January 1945] 3
('85', 339, 7, 12, 539493) BHULABHAI DESAI, I understand that the steps would be somewhat as follows : The League agrees with us as to the composition of the interim Government at the Centre.
('85', 339, 7, 13, 539658) (The agreed nominees will be responsible to the elected legislature.)The League agrees that if the proposal is accepted by the G[overnor] G[eneral] the first step to be taken by the new Government will be to release the Working Committee.
('85', 339, 7, 14, 539897) On this being done, the G. G. will be requested to accept the composition agreed upon (with the addition of members representing the elected parties or elements).
('85', 339, 7, 15, 540060) On the G.G. agreeing, an interim Government would be formed and when the Working Committee is thereafter released, you will be good enough to tell them that this step was taken with your approval.
('85', 339, 8, 16, 540257) 1 Ex Finance Minister of Bihar 2 (1877 1946); Leader of the Congress Party in the Central Assembly; President, Bombay Provincial Congress Committee; Member, Congress Working Committee.

('85', 342, 1, 2, 543704) 572. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH February 1, 1945
('85', 342, 2, 3, 543753) MUNNALAL, You tried to be brief but failed.
('85', 342, 2, 4, 543797) I am sure you have omitted something.
('85', 342, 2, 5, 543835) To be brief means that you should say everything you want to in as few words as possible.
('85', 342, 2, 6, 543925) I will show you how to do this when I have the time and the opportunity to do so.
('85', 342, 2, 7, 544007) It was not in anger that I wrote what I did about Burhanpur.
('85', 342, 2, 8, 544068) I was not happy about you or Kanchan going there.
('85', 342, 2, 9, 544118) But knowing your limitation, I agreed unreservedly.
('85', 342, 2, 10, 544170) After you had gone there, I saw from your letters that your going there had been fruitful.
('85', 342, 2, 11, 544261) You made your family happy and you could also improve things to some extent.
('85', 342, 2, 12, 544338) Besides, there is certainly work to do in the town.
('85', 342, 2, 13, 544390) Hence, in order to see you become steady and have the proper environment, I also suggested your taking up work there.
('85', 342, 2, 14, 544508) My intention of course is that you should stay on here and learn through experience.
('85', 342, 2, 15, 544593) But evenfor doing that, you must have equipoise and you must live in conformity with social norms.
('85', 342, 2, 16, 544692) If you do not do that, you will not mature.
('85', 342, 2, 17, 544736) I, therefore, included that also in my suggestions.
('85', 342, 2, 18, 544788) You may forgive Gopalrao and others, but you must know their mistake.
('85', 342, 2, 19, 544858) I saw sarcasm in Pandurang’s letter.
('85', 342, 2, 20, 544895) I did not like the letter.
('85', 342, 2, 21, 544922) Their explanation for all this lies chiefly in what you two, perhaps four, namely, you and Kanchan, Chimanlal and Shakaribehn, are by nature.
('85', 342, 2, 22, 545064) These two women cannot be considered different from other women.
('85', 342, 2, 23, 545129) Perhaps you do not know how many of my plans came to nothing because of Ba’s limitations.
('85', 342, 2, 24, 545219) I exercised as much strictness as I could.
('85', 342, 2, 25, 545262) But the limitation would always show itself.
('85', 342, 2, 26, 545307) You may be sure it will be the same in this case.
('85', 342, 2, 27, 545357) I have explained the rule to you.
('85', 342, 2, 28, 545391) If, after understanding it, you come to the conclusion that you two should run the Ashram, I would consent to your doing so.
('85', 342, 2, 29, 545516) Even if you run it in a way different from the way it is run at present, I would let you do so.
('85', 342, 2, 30, 545612) Or if you decide that the Ashram should be disbanded, I would consent to that too.
('85', 342, 2, 31, 545695) The correct and best thing would be that all four of you should wake up now while carrying on your present work, and do the best you can.
('85', 342, 2, 32, 545833) You may seek from me whatever help I can give you.
('85', 342, 2, 33, 545884) If Chimanlal also did not understand about Prahlad, ask me when I have free time and when both are present; I will tell you.

('85', 372, 3, 9, 584895) 635. SPEECH AT SEVAGRAM
('85', 372, 4, 10, 584919) February 10, 1945
('85', 372, 5, 11, 584937) Mahatma Gandhi addressed a few words to the gathering.
('85', 372, 5, 12, 584992) 3 He told them he had accidentally seen the address which they had presented to Shri Kanu Gandhi, the organizer of the camp.
('85', 372, 5, 13, 585117) They had said some very nice things in it, but if, as it often happened, it all began and ended with the presentation of the address, without their carrying back with them something of enduring value from the camp, theirs would be merely love’s labour lost.
('85', 372, 5, 14, 585375) He expected them to develop what they had gained during their month of training a hundredfold and become true gramsevaks, servants of the villagers in deed as well as in name.
('85', 372, 5, 15, 585551) They had been selected for training out of a large number of applicants.
('85', 372, 5, 16, 585624) It was for them to vindicate their selection by going back as messengers and torch bearers of samagra gramseva to their respective provinces.
('85', 372, 5, 17, 585766) They should go to villages as scavengers and sweep them and clean them and serve the villagers as their humble servants.
('85', 372, 5, 18, 585887) They should teach those who wished to learn spinning and other village handicrafts in the best way they could.
('85', 372, 5, 19, 585998) They should never feel helpless in the absence of outside help.
('85', 372, 5, 20, 586062) In their work, if they had really assimilated the spirit of the teaching that had been imparted to them, it ought to develop their intellect and heart no less than their bodies.
('85', 372, 5, 21, 586240) Therefore it should develop their character.
('85', 372, 5, 22, 586285) Their success would depend more on the purity of their hearts than on their skill and knowledge.
('85', 372, 5, 23, 586382) If they lacked moral purity they would prove a blight instead of a blessing to the villagers among whom they might settle.
('85', 372, 6, 24, 586505) 1 T. N. Jagadisan, leprosy relief worker of Madras, and Dr. M. R. G. Cochrane of Vellore met Gandhiji and presented to him a proposal for organizing under the Kasturba Memorial Fund rural leprosy work for the benefit of women and children.
('85', 372, 6, 25, 586745) Since Gandhiji was observing silence he wrote out his reply.
('85', 372, 6, 26, 586806) 2 Vide also “Remark in Visitor’s Book”, 12 12 1944. 3 On the death anniversary, according to the Indian calendar, of Kasturba Gandhi, a twenty four hour spinning yajna was organized in which Gandhiji participated.
('85', 372, 6, 27, 587020) Kanu Gandhi’s Samagra Gramseva Shibir also concluded on this day.
('85', 373, 0, 1, 587086) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 374
('85', 373, 1, 2, 587127) He was glad to note, Gandhiji went on, that though they came from different provinces, they had all been able to take and flourish on the same diet.
('85', 373, 1, 3, 587276) It should lead to a better realization of our oneness as a nation.
('85', 373, 1, 4, 587343) Customs, dress, food and language were bound to be to a certain extent different in different provinces, but the essential unity underneath this apparent diversity had to be fully grasped and a working uniform standard evolved if they were to realize their destiny as a nation.
('85', 373, 2, 5, 587621) Lastly, Mahatma Gandhi exhorted them all to learn Hindustani and acquire proficiency in both the Urdu and the Hindi scripts.
('85', 373, 2, 6, 587746) Hindustani meant not a highflown Sanskritized Hindi or Persianized Urdu, but a simple dialect which both Hindus and Muslims spoke in the villages of the North.
('85', 373, 2, 7, 587906) The villagers did not understandhighflown Hindi or Urdu.
('85', 373, 2, 8, 587963) Their language was either simple and plain Hindustani or a provincial dialect irrespective of their caste or creed.
('85', 373, 2, 9, 588079) Highflown and sophisticated style in Hindi and Urdu were the disease of cities, bred of mutual distrust.
('85', 373, 2, 10, 588184) So long as that state lasted it was incumbent on them to learn both the Hindi and Urdu scripts.
('85', 373, 2, 11, 588280) The third party was there no doubt to accentuate and exploit their differences, but, if they really felt that Hindus and Muslims were kith and kin, blood brethren, no one on earth could divide them or keep them divided.
('85', 373, 2, 12, 588500) There was a popular saying that it needed two to start a quarrel.
('85', 373, 2, 13, 588566) He was there to tell them that true ahimsa did not need to wait for a gesture from the other side.
('85', 373, 2, 14, 588665) If they understood their own part of the duty and acted accordingly, success would assuredly be theirs.
('85', 373, 2, 15, 588769) The Hindu, 14 2 1945

('85', 381, 8, 22, 601035) February 15, 1945
('85', 381, 9, 23, 601053) Referring to the amount of one crore and twenty four lakhs that had been collected, Gandhiji remarked that though he was impatient to speed up the work, he was not going to allow the Fund to be squandered away or loosely handled.
('85', 381, 9, 24, 601283) It had been collected in the name of an illiterate and simple hearted woman.
('85', 381, 9, 25, 601360) He had his detractors, not so Ba.
('85', 381, 9, 26, 601394) Therefore, the work done in her memory must be cent per cent honest.
('85', 381, 10, 27, 601463) 1 The addressee in her letter dated February 5, 1945, had mentioned that her husband, Ram Narayan Chaudhary, had in 1942 advised a student that sabotage activities would be in conformity with non violence and had now discovered, after Gandhiji’s clarification of the matter, that he was mistaken.
('85', 381, 10, 28, 601760) He was anxious to atone for the mistake.
('85', 381, 10, 29, 601801) 2 Gandhiji Addressed the Secretaries of the Provincial Committees of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund.
('85', 382, 0, 1, 601914) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 383
('85', 382, 1, 2, 601957) did not care for numbers of workers.
('85', 382, 1, 3, 601994) If he could find even two capable men or women in the meeting he would begin work with their help and expand it as more suitable workers came forward.
('85', 382, 1, 4, 602145) So far as he was concerned he would like to exclude men altogether from the various Provincial Committees formed under the Trust and fill them with women.
('85', 382, 1, 5, 602300) But he would not have them unless they were at least as capable if not better than men.
('85', 382, 1, 6, 602388) Otherwise he would be exploiting them.
('85', 382, 1, 7, 602427) He had never done so.
('85', 382, 1, 8, 602449) One crore and twenty four lakhs was a mere drop in the ocean when distributed among seven lakhs of India’s villages.
('85', 382, 1, 9, 602566) India was spending more than a crore a day on the war, but one crore and twenty four lakhs for the service of women and children appeared a big sum in the eyes of everybody.
('85', 382, 1, 10, 602740) That gave only a measure of the topsyturvydom to which they had got used.
('85', 382, 1, 11, 602814) Referring to the way in which the money was to be spent, Gandhiji divided it into three heads.
('85', 382, 1, 12, 602909) The first in order was medical relief for women and children in the villages.
('85', 382, 1, 13, 602987) From the schemes that had come everybody seemed to think in terms of maternity homes and free hospitals for women and children.
('85', 382, 1, 14, 603115) He recognized the need of this kind of work but he frankly confessed that he had yet to feel his way to it.
('85', 382, 1, 15, 603223) What kind of medical institutions they were to have and what system of medicine they were to adopt was a ticklish question.
('85', 382, 1, 16, 603347) It was taxing his mind and he requested them all to give their serious attention to it.
('85', 382, 1, 17, 603435) So far as he was concerned, “prevention is better than cure” was his motto.
('85', 382, 1, 18, 603511) If he had his way he would make sanitation and hygiene work the principal activity under this head.
('85', 382, 1, 19, 603611) It did not matter if in doing so they had to exclude a certain class of hard and difficult cases.
('85', 382, 1, 20, 603709) Some of the patients might even die.
('85', 382, 1, 21, 603746) He could steel his heart to lose them.
('85', 382, 1, 22, 603785) But it broke his heart to see even one healthyman fall sick.Our village folk must be taught to look after their health.
('85', 382, 1, 23, 603905) The root causes were poverty and ignorance.
('85', 382, 1, 24, 603949) In order of importance these two came first.
('85', 382, 1, 25, 603994) Education was to be along the lines of Nayee Talim.
('85', 382, 1, 26, 604046) As a matter of fact, everything else was included in and was an essential part of Nayee Talim as he conceived its scope.
('85', 382, 1, 27, 604167) They had to better their economic condition through khadi and village industries.
('85', 382, 1, 28, 604249) Today, the sole occupation of woman amongst us was supposed to be to bear children, cook for her husband and otherwise drudge for the household.
('85', 382, 1, 29, 604394) This was a shame.
('85', 382, 1, 30, 604412) Not only was woman condemned to domestic slavery, but when she went out as a labourer to earn wages, though she worked harder than the man, she was paid less.
('85', 382, 1, 31, 604571) Children were forced to go to work at an early age.
('85', 382, 1, 32, 604623) Some of them worked often as much as the men but were paid even less than women.
('85', 382, 1, 33, 604704) This state of affairs must be put an end to.
('85', 382, 1, 34, 604749) He had received no scheme for this kind of work so far.
('85', 382, 1, 35, 604805) The children in the villages began to earn at an early age.
('85', 382, 1, 36, 604865) Their parents could not afford to send them to school and spend on their education like the city folk.
('85', 382, 1, 37, 604968) Their education should fit them for some useful industry or other and it should help to put them on their legs.
('85', 382, 1, 38, 605080) The work outlined by him was original and difficult.
('85', 382, 1, 39, 605133) There were very few men fit to carry it out.
('85', 382, 1, 40, 605178) Many of them even lacked the desire to train themselves for it.
('85', 382, 1, 41, 605242) Such men should not come on the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund Committees and if they were on them already they should resign and make way for others.

('85', 383, 1, 2, 605442) At the end, he invited questions but appealed to the audience to spare.
('85', 383, 1, 3, 605514) him as far as possible.

('85', 383, 2, 8, 605718) A friend asked what should be considered the maximum population of a village.
('85', 383, 2, 9, 605796) Gandhiji replied that for the present he would set the outside limit at 2,000. This was subject to adjustments later on.
('85', 383, 2, 10, 605917) He knew an overwhelming majority of villages in India had a population between 500 and 1,000 or even less.
('85', 383, 2, 11, 606024) He would like them to begin with the smallest village and then work upwards.

('85', 384, 0, 1, 608158) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 385

('85', 384, 2, 3, 608219) A. That is exactly our object and it is for that purpose that you are all here.
('85', 384, 2, 4, 608299) But everything must be done in a way befitting the memory of her in whose name the Fund has been collected.
('85', 384, 3, 5, 608407) Q. What is to be done in a province like Sind where it is too unsafe for any woman to venture out and work in the villages?
('85', 384, 4, 6, 608531) A. So long as women do not come forward, it goes without saying that men have to work in their place.
('85', 384, 4, 7, 608633) But I have no doubt that you should be able to find women to go to work in the villages.

('85', 384, 4, 11, 608983) I know of a young missionary girl who went all alone in the midst of Negroes inthe wilds of Africa.
('85', 384, 4, 12, 609083) Yet she was not afraid and no one ever cast an evil eye on her.

('85', 384, 4, 16, 609292) No one dared to touch her.

('85', 384, 5, 18, 609498) Q. If we take up work just in one village the pressure of the surrounding area would swamp our work.

('85', 388, 1, 2, 615560) 662. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('85', 388, 2, 3, 615588) WARDHA, February 17, 1945 I have delayed giving my opinion on the Bihar Government’s challenge to Congress workers 1 in the hope that the storm was an isolated mistake and that it will correct itself.
('85', 388, 2, 4, 615789) I find I was mistaken.On top of the happenings in Bihar comes news that Shri Purushottamdas Tandon has been rearrested.
('85', 388, 2, 5, 615909) The workers in Bihar are well known, and of them one is an ex Prime Minister and another is ex Finance Minister.
('85', 388, 2, 6, 616022) Tandonji is the Speaker of the U. P. Assembly.
('85', 388, 2, 7, 616069) Now comes news that Shri Gopabandhu Chowdhury of Orissa, equally well known too, has been rearrested.
('85', 388, 2, 8, 616171) This is one picture.
('85', 388, 2, 9, 616192) The other is, the Viceroy holds talks with Sjt.
('85', 388, 2, 10, 616240) Bhulabhai Desai.
('85', 388, 2, 11, 616257) The air is thick with rumours of big changes.
('85', 388, 2, 12, 616303) The rumour hardly squares with the news I have summarized and which the public knows already.
('85', 388, 2, 13, 616397) Congressmen in Bihar were busy devising concerted measures to give effect to the fifteen point constructive programme sketched by me and in a manner suggested by me when the principal men were arrested though the programme has no political fIavour, using the term politics in its understood sense.
('85', 388, 2, 14, 616695) I have not hesitated to say that the universal adoption in practice in India of the programme must lead to the attainment of complete independence without either civil non violent disobedience or even a parliamentary programme.
('85', 388, 2, 15, 616923) There would then be no necessity for either.
('85', 388, 2, 16, 616968) The British would not find it worth while to stay in India to rule.
('85', 388, 2, 17, 617036) They would stay, if they do, as full citizens.
('85', 388, 2, 18, 617083) In the language of 1942, as rulers they would quit India; for their soldiers would be without occupation, their huge industries without use.
('85', 388, 2, 19, 617224) That day may not come, but it should be the non violent soldier’s dream which he must try daily to realize and if in its pursuit he is thwarted, he has his non violent resistance to fall back upon, otherwise called civil disobedience and non co operation.
('85', 388, 2, 20, 617480) Mass civil disobedience is nobody’s responsibility except, as yet, mine.
('85', 388, 2, 21, 617553) It was not offered in 1942. Nobody who has not permeated the masses can
('85', 388, 3, 22, 617625) 1 On January 28, 1945, the Bihar Government interned Srikrishna Sinha, ex Premier, Bihar, Anugraha Narayan Sinha, ex Finance Minister, Prof.
('85', 388, 3, 23, 617766) Abdul Bari, Dy.
('85', 388, 3, 24, 617782) Speaker, Bihar Legislative Assembly, Murli Manohar Prasad, Editor, Searchlight, and Prajapati Mishra on the charge of open preparation for another struggle.
('85', 389, 0, 1, 617939) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 390
('85', 389, 1, 2, 617980) shoulder it.
('85', 389, 1, 3, 617993) Indeed, the masses simply will not move.
('85', 389, 1, 4, 618034) That is my conviction based on the experience I have gained.
('85', 389, 1, 5, 618095) Hitherto the action in Bihar is defended on the ground of an alleged speech by Shri Prajapati Mishra.
('85', 389, 1, 6, 618197) The text of that speech has been suppressed.
('85', 389, 1, 7, 618242) There is no question of his or any Congressman making exciting speeches in the prosecution of the constructive programme or about non violent resistance or much less about resorting to violence or even approving of it.
('85', 389, 1, 8, 618461) That there is no plan under the present conditions to offer any form of mass civil disobedience has been clearly stated by me and I know that Congressmen all over the country are acting on the advice I have offered.
('85', 389, 1, 9, 618677) But abstention even from referring to the theoretical possibility of resistance and the like cannot be forced or even made a condition of prosecuting theconstructive programme.
('85', 389, 1, 10, 618854) It has undoubtedly independence— political, social and economic—as its aim.
('85', 389, 1, 11, 618930) It is a moral non violent revolution in all the departments of life of a big nation, at the end of which caste and untouchability and such other superstitions must vanish, differences between Hindu and Muslim must become things of the past, enmity against Englishmen or Europeans must be wholly forgotten and Princes and capitalists must live as perfect friends with the whole mass of India as the real and legal trustees of the people for all the wealth they may possess.
('85', 389, 1, 12, 619403) Is there anything wrong in the attempt?
('85', 389, 1, 13, 619443) What are Government protestations about Indian independence if they will not tolerate the movement I have sketched except on conditions impossible of acceptance?
('85', 389, 1, 14, 619605) Are they not satisfied with the extraordinary power they possess?
('85', 389, 1, 15, 619671) Must they keep without trial the best known as well as the least known Indians in their custody, lest the latter should preach independence from one end of the country to the other and non violent acts in pursuit thereof?
('85', 389, 1, 16, 619893) Must they rearrest released persons the moment they speak and act as free men, if their speech or act does not please the authority?
('85', 389, 1, 17, 620026) Another painful experience I am undergoing which I must share with the public is the number of reports of assault and torture resorted to for purposes of extorting confessions from prisoners.
('85', 389, 1, 18, 620218) Some cases are already before the public, such as the notable one at Kolhapur.

('85', 389, 1, 20, 620387) One particular case I have in mind related to a young lad who, on my advice, gave himself up to the police because he had been wanted.
('85', 389, 1, 21, 620522) If some of the reports that one hears are not well
('85', 389, 2, 22, 620573) 1 It was alleged that Kashibai Hanbar was stripped and tortured by a police officer of Kolhapur State to extract information about her son who was declared a political absconder.

('85', 390, 1, 2, 620795) founded, I am satisfied several others are perfectly genuine.
('85', 390, 1, 3, 620857) Is it not time this practice of torture and ill treatment of people held in captivity is firmly discountenanced and put an end to by the powers that be?
('85', 390, 1, 4, 621010) In August 1942, instead of needlessly precipitating a quarrel with the people, if the authority had listened to the pleading of the Congress, India would have enjoyed independence and the war would have already ended with honour for the Allies and happiness for the suppressed peoples of the earth.
('85', 390, 1, 5, 621309) That is my retrospection.
('85', 390, 1, 6, 621335) If things go on as they are doing in India, the victory that the Allies will have will be only so called, because they will also have India and other nations in the same plight bleeding at their feet.

('85', 396, 8, 15, 631288) Gandhiji told the deputation that whatever might be the case with other provinces, he was firmly of opinion that in the Frontier Province Congressmen should form an alternative Ministry if the no confidence motion was successful.

('85', 396, 8, 17, 631615) He would have asked them—and all Congressmen—to withdraw from the Assembly and resort to total non co operation if they had made greater progress in non violence than he judged they had.
('85', 396, 8, 18, 631802) As things stood, such a course was fraught with grave risk.
('85', 396, 8, 19, 631862) There was no atmosphere for it.
('85', 396, 8, 20, 631894) They could, therefore, go ahead with the no confidence motion and form a Congress Ministry.
