('85', 411, 1, 2, 656250) 696. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('85', 411, 2, 3, 656280) SEVAGRAM, February 22, 1945 This day marks the end of a solar year since Ba’s departure from the earth.
('85', 411, 2, 4, 656384) According to the lunar calendar, the anniversary fell on Mahashivaratri Day.
('85', 411, 2, 5, 656461) 1 This is no occasion for mourning.
('85', 411, 2, 6, 656497) On the contrary, it should be celebrated with the same joy as a day of birth.
('85', 411, 2, 7, 656575) I do not make much distinction between birth and death.
('85', 411, 2, 8, 656631) The atman has neither birth nor death.
('85', 411, 2, 9, 656670) We loved Ba’s atman which is immortal.
('85', 411, 2, 10, 656709) We spend days like this outwardly in religious rites.
('85', 411, 2, 11, 656763) We had 24 hours’ non stop spinning.
('85', 411, 2, 12, 656799) To me it was a religious observance.
('85', 411, 2, 13, 656836) At Balvant Sinha’s suggestion, we also have had the reading of the Ramayana which lasted throughout the day.
('85', 411, 2, 14, 656945) In the morning we recited the Gita.
('85', 411, 2, 15, 656981) But these outward acts do not satisfy us.
('85', 411, 2, 16, 657023) We should go through these rites with full consciousness and understanding and invoke God.
('85', 411, 2, 17, 657114) God is not somewhere up above or down below.
('85', 411, 2, 18, 657159) He is in our hearts.
('85', 411, 2, 19, 657180) In fact He is everywhere.
('85', 411, 2, 20, 657206) When scientists say that they can create a vacuum, what they mean is that a vessel can be emptied of air but something still remains.
('85', 411, 2, 21, 657340) Physical scientists have discovered thatthere is something subtler than air.
('85', 411, 2, 22, 657417) Those with religious leanings realize that God is everywhere and is witness to all our acts.
('85', 411, 2, 23, 657510) Yesterday, I said that we must first wipe out our sins.
('85', 411, 2, 24, 657566) There was a marriage celebration yesterday.
('85', 411, 2, 25, 657610) Five minutes before [the function] I went to inspect the latrine.
('85', 411, 2, 26, 657676) It smelled.
('85', 411, 2, 27, 657688) I found excreta uncovered.
('85', 411, 2, 28, 657715) Is this not a sign of our outer sin?
('85', 411, 2, 29, 657752) We are guilty of a great error in keeping the latrine thus.
('85', 411, 2, 30, 657812) We might have committed other sins as well.
('85', 411, 2, 31, 657856) We have, therefore, to see that our latrines and kitchens are absolutely clean.
('85', 411, 2, 32, 657936) We have to see that the kitchen runs smoothly; we must ask why we hurt one another, why the flies and mosquitoes breed.
('85', 411, 2, 33, 658056) All these are indicative of our sin.
('85', 411, 2, 34, 658093) I have not yet succeeded in finding out the cause of their growth but that does not absolve us of our sin.
('85', 411, 2, 35, 658200) On this sacred day we plied the charkha and observed many other religious ceremonies.
('85', 411, 2, 36, 658286) Now the test, whether we deserve to undertake it or not, lies in the fact whether we observe cleanliness or not.
('85', 411, 2, 37, 658399) You may not call it a sin, only a shortcoming.
('85', 411, 2, 38, 658446) But to me the two are the same.
('85', 411, 2, 39, 658478) We are punished for these sins not in the life to come but in this very life.
('85', 411, 2, 40, 658556) Viewed thus, life becomes simple and full of joy.
('85', 411, 3, 41, 658606) 1 Vide “Speech at Sevagram”, 10 2 1945.
('85', 412, 0, 1, 658646) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 413
('85', 412, 1, 2, 658689) I had a letter from Kanti.
('85', 412, 1, 3, 658716) He has mentioned what two learned persons said to him.
('85', 412, 1, 4, 658771) One of them said that he did not consider spinning to be a religious duty.
('85', 412, 1, 5, 658846) If he span, it was because it had become a convention to do so.
('85', 412, 1, 6, 658910) It is obvious that spinning in imitation of others cannot be termed a religious act.
('85', 412, 1, 7, 658995) Such spinning will not win us swaraj.
('85', 412, 1, 8, 659033) We will win it only if we understand its science and appreciate its potentiality.
('85', 412, 1, 9, 659115) Spinners who spin imitatively and therefore mechanically should not be found, of all places, in the Ashram.
('85', 412, 1, 10, 659223) Everyone here does not ply the charkha and I put up with it.
('85', 412, 1, 11, 659284) I cannot forbid those who spin just because others do.
('85', 412, 1, 12, 659339) But I may as well tell them that this is not going to help them achieve their aim.
('85', 412, 1, 13, 659422) The other learned person said that he did not believe in prayer.
('85', 412, 1, 14, 659487) It is not his fault.
('85', 412, 1, 15, 659508) The blame lies with us, for we, who believe in prayer, do not make our prayers manifest in our lives and actions.
('85', 412, 1, 16, 659622) He has warned that those who have gathered round me are not all genuine believers and that I am doomed to despair.
('85', 412, 1, 17, 659737) But I do not find any particular signs of despair in me.
('85', 412, 1, 18, 659794) I do my duty and speak of it to others.
('85', 412, 1, 19, 659834) But if they do not care to act on it, it does not affect me.
('85', 412, 1, 20, 659895) This learned friend gives discourses on the Gita, attends the prayer but he does so only because it is a convention.
('85', 412, 1, 21, 660012) If one’s mind wanders during prayer and does not lose itself in meditation, it is clear that one does not fully participate in prayer not withstanding the physical presence.
('85', 412, 1, 22, 660186) There is in that case a conflict between the body and the mind in which the mind is the winner.
('85', 412, 1, 23, 660282) What I mean to say is that if we consider this to be a sacred day then we must with all our heart do all we can in the name of an old woman who, though unlettered, was an embodiment of purity.
('85', 412, 1, 24, 660475) Let all our actions be sincere.
('85', 412, 1, 25, 660507) [From Hindi]

('85', 417, 1, 2, 665372) 707. A NOTE
('85', 417, 2, 3, 665384) February 24, 1945 With women men should behave as they would with men.
('85', 417, 2, 4, 665455) Two men would not deliberately embrace or kiss each other, or sleep together.
('85', 417, 2, 5, 665533) But if there is a reason, one man would touch another, sit by his side, or sit on the same seat.
('85', 417, 2, 6, 665630) We must behave with women in the same manner.
('85', 417, 2, 7, 665676) We must forget the distinction of sex as far as possible.
('85', 417, 2, 8, 665734) There is distinction between men and women but it should have no place in our normal dealings.
('85', 417, 2, 9, 665829) The consciousness of this distinction arises either in the case of carnal desire or outside it in that of a genuine desire for progeny.
('85', 417, 2, 10, 665965) Let us forget this second category.
('85', 417, 2, 11, 666001) Probably one in a million may be resorting to intercourse for purposes of procreation.
('85', 417, 2, 12, 666088) I have not come across any such person so far.
('85', 417, 2, 13, 666135) I do not consider association with women or keeping away from them in conformity with the conventional restraints of brahmacharya asrealbrahmacharya.
('85', 417, 2, 14, 666285) My relationships are covered by this explanation.
('85', 417, 2, 15, 666335) Whatever you may hear to the contrary must be rejected offhand.
('85', 417, 2, 16, 666399) Think of this instead of being curious about my relation ships.
('85', 417, 3, 17, 666463) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 5850

('85', 422, 8, 20, 672666) There was nothing in the speech to alarm the Government.
('85', 422, 8, 21, 672723) 2 In discussing the constructive programme such a speech should be considered irrelevant or inopportune.
('85', 422, 8, 22, 672828) But what was to be done about it?
('85', 422, 8, 23, 672862) It is a different matter if the Government wants to ban even constructive work.

('85', 423, 0, 1, 673119) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 424
('85', 423, 1, 2, 673160) 719. ANSWERS TO T. B. SAPRU’S QUESTIONS
('85', 423, 2, 3, 673200) AS AT SEVAGRAM, February 26, 1945 1
('85', 423, 3, 4, 673236) Q. In your letter 2 of September 14, 1944, to Mr. Jinnah, you said as follows: “You, ask for my conception of the basis for a provisional interim government.
('85', 423, 3, 5, 673394) I would have told you if I had any scheme in mind.” Did you never discuss even the outlines of any scheme during the course of your conversations?
('85', 423, 4, 6, 673541) A. What I told Quaid e Azam was the exact truth.
('85', 423, 4, 7, 673590) I had no idea of what he meant, for he never told me what he had in mind.
('85', 423, 4, 8, 673664) Therefore I can answer your question by saying we never discussed the outlines of any scheme of interim government except what I have said.
('85', 423, 5, 9, 673804) Q. In answering the first question, please refer to Mr. Jinnah’s letter of September 14, in which he said, “You, being the sponsor of this Gandhiji Rajaji formula, should give me some rough idea and picture of it so that I may understand what this part of the formula means.” Did you give any reply to this?
('85', 423, 5, 10, 674112) If so, what?
('85', 423, 5, 11, 674125) If not, why not?
('85', 423, 6, 12, 674142) A. The foregoing answer deals with your second question.
('85', 423, 7, 13, 674199) Q. In his letter of September 17, Mr. Jinnah says that “the word (Pakistan) has now become synonymous with the Lahore Resolution 3”.
('85', 423, 7, 14, 674332) Did you ask him whether in accordance with the Lahore Resolution of the All India Muslim League, a scheme of Constitution, in accordance with the basic principles providing for the assumption finally by the respective regions of all powers such as Defence, External Affairs, Communications, Customs and such other matters as may be necessary, had been prepared?
('85', 423, 7, 15, 674694) Was your attention drawn to any such scheme by Mr. Jinnah?
('85', 423, 8, 16, 674753) Quaid e Azam’s position unfortunately was that while he could come as far as seeing me and trying to convince me of his position, he, the President of the League, could not discuss details with me, a mere individual.
('85', 423, 8, 17, 674970) But so far as I could gather from our conversations, he had no prepared scheme.
('85', 423, 8, 18, 675050) As the correspondence shows, he had referred me to two books both of which I read, but neither of which could help me to understand Quaid e Azam’s exactposition.
('85', 423, 8, 19, 675212) One thing he insisted upon was that if I first accepted the Pakistan of his conception, he could then discuss other things with me even though I was but an individual.
('85', 423, 9, 20, 675380) 1 From Gandhi Sapru Papers 2 Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 14 9 1944. 3 Vide “Resolution passed by All India Muslim League”, 23 3 1940.
('85', 424, 0, 1, 675517) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 425
('85', 424, 1, 2, 675560) Q. Is it true that the real breakdown between you and Mr. Jinnah came about on the question of Central authority or Government?
('85', 424, 1, 3, 675688) Please refer in this connection to Mr. Jinnah’s letter of September 25, 1 clause (d), in which he says, “If these vital matters (suggested in the quotation from your letter with which clause ‘d’ begins) are to be administered by some central authority, you do not indicate what sort of authority or machinery will be set up to administer these matters, and how and to whom again that authority will be responsible.” Did you, at any stage, indicate to him that you wanted a Central Government or a Central Legislature to deal with a limited number of subjects, such as Foreign Affairs, Defence, Internal Communications, Customs, Commerce and the like?
('85', 424, 2, 4, 676339) A. It can be said that the breakdown took place because we could not come to an agreement of the two nation theory of Quaid e Azam’s.
('85', 424, 2, 5, 676473) As the correspondence will show I wanted to avoid a Central Government.
('85', 424, 2, 6, 676545) I suggested an authority acceptable to both the parties, but he would insist first on complete partition as between two nations and then an agreement between them as on foreign affairs, etc.
('85', 424, 2, 7, 676736) He would not agree to anything simultaneous.
('85', 424, 3, 8, 676781) Q. In that very clause (clause ‘d’), Mr. Jinnah says, “According to the Lahore Resolution, as I have already explained to you, all these matters, which are the life blood of any State, cannot be delegated to any Central authority or Government.” Then he says that “the matter of security of the two States and the natural and mutual obligations that may arise out of physical contiguity will be for the constitution making body of Pakistan and that of Hindustan, or [any] other party concerned, to deal with on the footing of their being two independent States.” Did you understand Mr. Jinnah’s position to be that he intended that Pakistan and Hindustan should be completely independent sovereign States with no connection between them except by a treaty?
('85', 424, 3, 9, 677538) If so, did he tell you what was to happen if either party broke the treaty and what was the authority which could enforce the provisions of such a treaty?
('85', 424, 3, 10, 677693) A. Of course, he wanted two independent sovereign States with no connection between them except by a treaty.
('85', 424, 3, 11, 677802) If any party broke the treaty, the consequence would be what has happened throughout the world up till now, i e., war.
('85', 424, 3, 12, 677921) Therefore I did not ask and he did nottell me as to what would happen if either party broke the treaty.
('85', 424, 4, 13, 678025) Q. As regards the C. R. Formula 2, can you explain why Mr. Jinnah was opposed to clause (2) of that formula, which demanded a plebiscite of all the inhabitants on the basis of adult suffrage or other practical franchise?
('85', 424, 4, 14, 678246) Did you understand him to say that in the areas demarcated for Pakistan the minorities shall be given a chance of expressing their choice of staying in Pakistan or not being separated from the rest of the country?
('85', 424, 5, 15, 678460) 1 Vide “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 25 9 1944. 2 Vide Appendix “C. Rajagopalachari’s Formula”, before 5 8 1942.
('85', 425, 0, 1, 678571) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 426
('85', 425, 1, 2, 678612) A. Quaid e Azam would not have the plebiscite of the Muslims because he thought the League represented the Muslims of India and that the other communities should have no voice as to Pakistan which was Muslims’ exclusive right wherever they were in a majority.
('85', 425, 2, 3, 678872) Q. Please refer to your proposals contained in the letter of the 24th of September in which you said “there shall be a treaty of separation which should also provide for the efficient and satisfactory administration of Foreign Affairs, Defence, Internal Communications, Customs, Commerce and the like, which must necessarily continue to be the matter of common interest between the contracting parties.” Please explain how that treaty would provide for the efficient and satisfactory administration of these matters, and whether you contemplated any machinery which could give effect to the decisions embodied in that treaty.
('85', 425, 2, 4, 679498) If so, what is the nature of that machinery which you had in mind?
('85', 425, 3, 5, 679565) A. I suggested a board composed of representatives of both the States.
('85', 425, 3, 6, 679636) It was to be an arbitration board with administrative powers.
('85', 425, 3, 7, 679698) For the due carrying out of its decisions, it would largely or solely depend upon the goodwill of the parties or States.
('85', 425, 3, 8, 679819) But I should not object to a machinery jointly devised by the two States.
('85', 425, 4, 9, 679893) Q. Have you any objection to the provinces or States enjoying the fullest autonomy with residuary powers vested in them?
('85', 425, 5, 10, 680014) A. None whatsoever.
('85', 425, 6, 11, 680034) Q. How do you reconcile Mr. Jagat Narain Lal’s Resolution 1 of the All India Congress Committee with the line that you took in regard to the division of India in the course of your conversations and correspondence with Mr. Jinnah?
('85', 425, 7, 12, 680265) A. I depended first upon the decisive interpretation given by the President, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, and secondly on my own, meaning that the Jagat Narain Lal Resolution should be read together with the others bearing on the question.
('85', 425, 7, 13, 680501) For these latter were not cancelled by the Jagat Narain Lal Resolution.
('85', 425, 8, 14, 680573) Q. Please refer to Appendix ‘C’ of the pamphlet known as Gandhi Jinmah Talks, and send to the Committee a short memorandum explaining any points in that summary which you may consider necessary.
('85', 425, 8, 15, 680768) In this connection please refer to your Press statement 2 dated September 28, 1944, in the course of which you stated as follows: “In that respect the Lahore Resolution is quite sound.
('85', 425, 8, 16, 680953) Where there is an obvious Muslim majority, they should be allowed to constitute a separate State by themselves, and that has been fully conceded in the Rajaji Formula or my formula.
('85', 425, 8, 17, 681135) But if it means utterly independent sovereignty so that there is to be nothing in common between the two, I hold it is an impossible proposition.
('85', 425, 8, 18, 681281) That means war to
('85', 425, 9, 19, 681299) 1 Vide 5th footnote of “Note to Jagdish K. Munshi”, on or before 12 8 1944. 2 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 28 9 1944.
('85', 426, 0, 1, 681419) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 427
('85', 426, 1, 2, 681462) the knife.” What did you mean by saying “war to the knife”, and why did you consider that proposition to be an impossible proposition?
('85', 426, 2, 3, 681597) A. “War to the knife” is a simple English idiom.
('85', 426, 2, 4, 681646) I have never known it used in the literal sense.
('85', 426, 2, 5, 681695) It simply means a determined quarrel between parties.
('85', 426, 2, 6, 681749) I hold that if there is nothing in common between the two or nothing which does not come in conflict with each others’ culture there can be no friendly mutual agreement.
('85', 426, 3, 7, 681919) Q. In your Press statement dated September 28, 1944, you said: “I urge that apart from the two nation theory, if I could accept the principle of division of India in accordance with the demand of the League, he should accept it.
('85', 426, 3, 8, 682148) But unfortunately it was just there that we split.” Please explain this more clearly.
('85', 426, 4, 9, 682234) A. I think I am explicit enough.
('85', 426, 4, 10, 682267) I meant that apart from conceding the two nation theory, I accepted the concrete suggestion of division of India as between members of the same family and therefore reserving for partnership things of common interest.
('85', 426, 4, 11, 682485) But Quaid e Azam would have nothing short of the two nation theory and therefore complete dissolution amounting to full sovereignty in the first instance.
('85', 426, 4, 12, 682640) It was just here that we split as I have said herein before.
('85', 426, 5, 13, 682701) Q. Are you prepared to admit that the Muslims in India are a separate nation?
('85', 426, 5, 14, 682779) If so, then why do you deny the Muslims the right of having a separate independentState?
('85', 426, 5, 15, 682868) If you are not prepared to admit that the Muslims are a separate nation, then on what principle do you agree to a division of India to the limited extent to which you seem to have agreed in the course of your conversation and correspondence with Mr. Jinnah?
('85', 426, 5, 16, 683126) In this connection, please refer to your interview to the News Chronicle on September 29, 1944, 1 which is printed at page 64 of the pamphlet known as Gandhi Jinnah Talks.
('85', 426, 5, 17, 683298) A. Although I could not agree to the two nation theory, I agreed on the basis of members of a family desiring severance of the family tie in matters of conflict but not in all matters so as to become enemies one of the other as if there was nothing common between the two except enmity.
('85', 426, 6, 18, 683585) The Hindu, 10 4 1945, and Gandhi Sapru Papers; also G.N. 7570
('85', 426, 7, 19, 683647) 1 Vide “Interview to the News Chronicle”.29 9 1944

('85', 427, 1, 2, 683739) 720. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA HINDUSTANI PRACHAR SABHA CONFERENCE I 1
('85', 427, 2, 3, 683804) WARDHA, February 26, 1945
('85', 427, 3, 4, 683830) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I am glad to see you all assembled here at the invitation of Principal Shriman Narayan.
('85', 427, 3, 5, 683940) Dr. Abdul Haq was to have arrived here today, but he is now expected tomorrow.
('85', 427, 3, 6, 684019) This association and I wish to have his help.
('85', 427, 3, 7, 684065) Likewise Sjt.
('85', 427, 3, 8, 684079) Tandon was to come and I was feeling very happy.
('85', 427, 3, 9, 684128) Shriman Narayanji had wired to him also.
('85', 427, 3, 10, 684169) I am sorry that he is unable to come, being ill.
('85', 427, 3, 11, 684218) Let us hope that he will recover from his illness soon.
('85', 427, 3, 12, 684274) The task confronting you is, in one way, small, in another way big.
('85', 427, 3, 13, 684342) It is small because it requires only very small effort, and yet it promises great consequences.
('85', 427, 3, 14, 684438) Dr. Tarachand tells us that what is known by various names today was originally one language spoken in the North by both Hindus and Muslims.
('85', 427, 3, 15, 684579) It is a sad thing that those who were once one have become divided.
('85', 427, 3, 16, 684647) Their language, too, has either been split or is being split, into Urdu and Hindi.
('85', 427, 3, 17, 684730) As a result of the efforts of Sjt.
('85', 427, 3, 18, 684765) Tandon the Congress at Kanpur 2 gave the name ‘Hindustani’ to the language which is spoken by both the communities and decided on two scripts, Devanagari and Urdu.
('85', 427, 3, 19, 684929) But the Congress could not implement the resolution.
('85', 427, 3, 20, 684982) In 1942, the Hindustani Prachar Sabha took up this work at the instance of the late Shri Jamnalal Bajaj but he passed away soon after.
('85', 427, 3, 21, 685117) In 1942, Congress leaders and others were arrested; I was among them.
('85', 427, 3, 22, 685187) I was released later on medical grounds.
('85', 427, 3, 23, 685228) Even during my illness I followed the progress of the work that was being done by Sjt.
('85', 427, 3, 24, 685315) Nanavati to propagate Hindustani.
('85', 427, 3, 25, 685349) It gave me joy to find that it held out the prospect of success.
('85', 427, 3, 26, 685414) I see no reason why what was at one time the common language of both Hindus and Mussalmans should not again become one.
('85', 427, 3, 27, 685534) In Northern India, we are the descendants of those Hindus and Muslims who spoke and wrote the same language.
('85', 427, 3, 28, 685643) It should not require even half the labour to revive that old common language than it would to create two different languages, Urdu and Hindi.
('85', 427, 3, 29, 685786) Village folk in Northern India, whether Hindus or Mussalmans, even today speak the same tongue and some even write the same language.
('85', 427, 3, 30, 685920) It is for you to decide what should be done to bring our labours to a successful completion.
('85', 427, 3, 31, 686013) The function of the Hindustani
('85', 427, 4, 32, 686044) 1 Gandhiji presided over the conference and since he was observing silence, his speech was read out by Shriman Narayan.
('85', 427, 4, 33, 686164) 2 In December 1925
('85', 428, 0, 1, 686183) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 429
('85', 428, 1, 2, 686226) Prachar Sabha is to implement your decisions.
('85', 428, 1, 3, 686272) I am sorry that, for reasons of health, I observe silence for the whole day so far as possible.
('85', 428, 1, 4, 686368) During the last three months I had to break my silence during day time only perhaps on three occasions.
('85', 428, 1, 5, 686472) Today, it being Monday, I am observing my weekly silence.
('85', 428, 1, 6, 686530) I hope that it will not interfere with our work.
('85', 428, 1, 7, 686579) I now leave the conference in your hands.
('85', 428, 1, 8, 686621) Shriman Narayan will conduct the rest of the proceedings.

('85', 428, 1, 10, 686738) Tomorrow our work will commence at 3 p.

('85', 431, 10, 14, 690818) 729. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA HINDUSTANI PRACHAR SABHA CONFERENCE II
('85', 431, 11, 15, 690882) WARDHA, February 27, 1945 I am sorry I cannot give you as much time as I would wish.
('85', 431, 11, 16, 690967) Please forgive me.
('85', 431, 11, 17, 690986) My silence continues for the whole day.
('85', 431, 11, 18, 691026) It is not that it cannot be broken.
('85', 431, 11, 19, 691062) But I want to continue it for as long as I can and smoothly carry on my work.
('85', 431, 11, 20, 691140) So I observe silence.
('85', 431, 11, 21, 691162) If I squandered my energy, I might collapse in a month.
('85', 431, 11, 22, 691218) My attachment to truth and non violence would not permit this.
('85', 431, 11, 23, 691281) But if necessity should arise I could spend this energy with both hands.
('85', 431, 11, 24, 691354) I could also be a miser.
('85', 431, 11, 25, 691379) These days I have adopted the latter course.
('85', 431, 11, 26, 691424) I want to explain to you what the Hindustani Prachar Sabha is.
('85', 431, 11, 27, 691487) Its aim is to make as many people as possible learn Hindi and Urdu styles and the Devanagari and the Urdu scripts.
('85', 431, 11, 28, 691602) There was a time when the people of North India spoke one common language.
('85', 431, 11, 29, 691677) We are their descendants.
('85', 431, 11, 30, 691703) Today we see that the gulf between Hindi and Urdu is widening.
('85', 431, 11, 31, 691766) Protagonists of Hindi use difficult words from Sanskrit and
('85', 431, 12, 32, 691826) 1 Omission as in the source
('85', 432, 0, 1, 691854) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 433
('85', 432, 1, 2, 691897) the Urdu enthusiasts do the same from Arabic Persian.
('85', 432, 1, 3, 691951) I know this will not continue for long.
('85', 432, 1, 4, 691991) Villagers care for their bread only.

('85', 453, 0, 1, 727822) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 454
('85', 453, 1, 2, 727863) [ENCLOSURE]
('85', 453, 2, 3, 727875) (a) that Mahatma ji’s terms are an acceptance of the claim for separation according to a reasonable in terpretation of the Muslim League resolution of 1940
('85', 453, 3, 4, 728031) Suggested changes shown in margin.
('85', 453, 3, 5, 728066) My interpretation of Mahatmaji’s letter of 24th September, 1944, to Mr. Jinnah is as follows: (a) that Mahatmaji accepts the Muslim claim for separation as contained in the Muslim League resolution of 1940. 1
('85', 453, 4, 6, 728275) (b) Mahatmaji is agreeable to the appointment of a commission consisting of representatives of the Congress and the League immediately for the delimitation of the boundaries of the separate sovereign States.
('85', 453, 4, 7, 728483) (c) Mahatmaji wants that the sovereign States will immediately enter into a treaty for the purpose of (i)safeguarding interests of minorities, (ii) establishing a machinery for the administration of subjects of common concern.
('85', 453, 4, 8, 728710) But Mahatmaji desires that the wishes of the inhabitants of the areas to be demarcated into sovereign States should be ascertained by a plebiscite.
('85', 453, 4, 9, 728858) Mahatmaji does not agree with the theory that the Hindus of the whole of India or the Muslims of the whole of India constitute two separate nations.
('85', 453, 4, 10, 729007) In my (Tarachand’s) opinion Mahatmaji has substantially accepted the Muslim demand and agreed to the establishment of two sovereign and independent States in India.
('85', 453, 4, 11, 729172) The differences between Mahatmaji and Mr. Jinnah are: (1) Mahatmaji wants before separation a plebiscite.
('85', 453, 4, 12, 729278) (2) He does not believe in the theory of religious or communal nationality.
('85', 453, 5, 13, 729354) 1Vide Appendix “Resolution Passed by All India Muslim League”, 23 3 1940.
('85', 454, 0, 1, 729428) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 455
('85', 454, 1, 2, 729471) (b) The subjects of each federation will be full nationals and no discrimina tion will be made among them in the matter of vot ing or other wise on the ground of race or creed.
('85', 454, 2, 3, 729648) (3) He desires that the machinery for administration of matters of common interest should be embodied in the treaty of separation.
('85', 454, 3, 4, 729779) I suggest that the differences between Mahatmaji and Mr. Jinnah can be eliminated provided an agreement is arrived at as follows: (1) The sovereign and independent States in the North West and East and in the rest of India should be federations.
('85', 454, 3, 5, 730025) The units of these federations will be, in the North West:
('85', 454, 4, 6, 730084) (i) Baluchistan,
('85', 454, 5, 7, 730101) (ii) North West Frontier Province,
('85', 454, 6, 8, 730136) (iii) Western and Central Punjab,
('85', 454, 7, 9, 730170) (iv) South Eastern Punjab (one or two units)
('85', 454, 8, 10, 730215) (v) Sind.
('85', 454, 8, 11, 730225) (2) These units will have certain subjects including culture, education, personal law, etc., under the control of the governments of the units.
('85', 454, 8, 12, 730369) The federal government will have the usual federal and common subjects under its control.
('85', 454, 9, 13, 730459) (3) Similarly there may be units in Bengal, if the inhabitants of Bengal so desire and the remaining India will form one federation.
('85', 454, 10, 14, 730592) (4) These two federations will by treaty establish a confederation of independent and sovereign fede rations for the administration of matters of com mon interest, e.
('85', 454, 10, 15, 730759) g., defence, customs, foreign affairs, communications.
('85', 454, 11, 16, 730814) (5) The establishment of the confederation eliminates the necessity of a plebiscite, which therefore need not be held.
('85', 454, 12, 17, 730933) (6) The subjects of each federation will be the full nationals and no discrimination will be made among them on the ground of race or creed.
('85', 454, 13, 18, 731074) (7) The establishment of federations in different regions obviates the need for any large adjustment of the present boundaries of the provinces.
('85', 454, 14, 19, 731219) (8) The provisions about the establishment of federations and confederations will be embodied in the treaty of separation.
('85', 454, 14, 20, 731342) From a photostat: G.N. 5120

('85', 459, 0, 1, 736990) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 460
('85', 459, 1, 2, 737032) APPENDICES
('85', 459, 2, 3, 737043) APPENDIX I
('85', 459, 3, 4, 737054) LETTER FROM K. M. MUNSHI 1
('85', 459, 4, 5, 737081) BOMBAY VIEW, MATHERAN, October 12, 1944
('85', 459, 5, 6, 737121) RESPECTED BAPU,
('85', 459, 6, 7, 737137) Received your letter dated the 9th.
('85', 459, 7, 8, 737173) I too believe in freedom of speech.
('85', 459, 7, 9, 737209) But the question before me on the night of 1 8 39 was to quell the dreadful riot that had just begun.
('85', 459, 7, 10, 737311) It was my duty to take promptly all the measures that were imperative to bring the situation under control.
('85', 459, 7, 11, 737419) And I had (also) to see that some three or four papers that fanned the (communal) passion did not add fuel to the fire.
('85', 459, 7, 12, 737539) I did not think I was disregarding the principle of freedom of speech in keeping a check on it when it was misused.
('85', 459, 7, 13, 737655) Even today I do Dot think so.
('85', 459, 8, 14, 737685) My Jaipur speech was the result of my study of that problem.
('85', 459, 8, 15, 737746) You will not find any contradiction in it if I put it (before you) point by point.
('85', 459, 9, 16, 737829) (1) Sanskrit is our most valuable treasure.
('85', 459, 9, 17, 737873) With its help alone we can make our languages as powerful as English and French.
('85', 459, 10, 18, 737954) (2) The power of our language which can express thought and creative endeavour belongs in general to the Sanskrit element.
('85', 459, 10, 19, 738077) And so, if we are going to evolve in India a medium for expressing our thoughts and literature there is no alternative except resorting to the use of Sanskrit words.
('85', 459, 10, 20, 738243) Today I have before me the problem of the technical terms for law, philosophy and psychology.
('85', 459, 10, 21, 738337) Where can we have the Indian medium except from Sanskrit?
('85', 459, 10, 22, 738395) I do not think I have drifted away from your stand at Nagpur (and) Indore and which I had accepted.
('85', 459, 11, 23, 738495) (3) I do not also see any opposition to the Congress policy in my address.
('85', 459, 11, 24, 738570) As I have understood, the Congress aims to make the colloquial Hindustani a common medium for the whole country.
('85', 459, 11, 25, 738683) But how can the colloquial Hindustani be the medium of thought or literature?
('85', 459, 11, 26, 738761) The moment it attempts to be (any) such thing, it has got to seek the help of Sanskrit or Perso Arabic words.
('85', 459, 11, 27, 738871) I cannot speak in that language unless I use Sanskrit words.
('85', 459, 11, 28, 738932) There is no intentional Sanskritization; nothing else is possible.
('85', 459, 12, 29, 738999) (4) If Hindustani is to be the medium in the legislatures or the colleges, there are bound to be two forms of the language: one will be Sanskritized (and) the other Persianized.
('85', 459, 13, 30, 739177) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here; vide “Letter to K. M. Munshi”, 9 10 1944.
('85', 460, 0, 1, 739256) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 461
('85', 460, 1, 2, 739299) (5) One reason why you have not liked my address may be that in one paragraph the experiment of the ‘Hindustani Samiti’ (carried on) under your guidance is criticized.
('85', 460, 1, 3, 739467) What the Samiti is attempting to do is not the propagation of ‘colloquial Hindustani’ but evolving a new style.
('85', 460, 1, 4, 739579) Among its characteristics are: (1) abandoning the tatsama forms of Sanskrit words, (2) incorporating the tatsama forms of Persian words, (3) introducing an Arabic or a Persian word in the form of an Urdu word even if a tatsama Sanskrit word has been traditionally accepted, (4) giving preference to Persian words in cases where both Sanskrit and Persian words are current.
('85', 460, 2, 5, 739952) Yours respectfully,
('85', 460, 3, 6, 739972) KANU MUNSHI
('85', 460, 4, 7, 739984) Pilgrimage to Freedom, pp.
('85', 460, 5, 8, 740011) APPENDIX II
('85', 460, 6, 9, 740023) A STATEMENT 1
('85', 460, 7, 10, 740037) SEVAGRAM,
('85', 460, 8, 11, 740047) October 29, 1944
('85', 460, 9, 12, 740064) Talks about the possibility of Gandhiji going on a fast have upset many friends and co workers.
('85', 460, 9, 13, 740160) Their love for him makes them shudder at the very thought of his undergoing the ordeal of another fast at his age and in his present state of health.
('85', 460, 9, 14, 740310) Although he is keeping fairly fit and is putting in a full day’s work his reserve of energy is low.
('85', 460, 9, 15, 740410) He is still slightly anaemic and the two intestinal parasites, hook worm and amoebae, which are lying latent at present, can get the upper hand at any moment if his general condition is run down.
('85', 460, 9, 16, 740606) Moreover, they feel that a fast on his part at this stage will add to the general demoralization and increase the popular bitterness against the Government.
('85', 460, 10, 17, 740763) Gandhiji is not perturbed by considerations of his age or his frailness.
('85', 460, 10, 18, 740836) His stand has always been that if God wants to take work from him He will spare him.
('85', 460, 10, 19, 740921) If his work is over, there is no point in prolonging his sojourn in this world.
('85', 460, 10, 20, 741001) However, friends have a right to feel that it is not wise to tempt Providence too often.
('85', 460, 11, 21, 741090) As for the risk of increase of demoralization and bitterness as a result of the fast, he does not think it likely.
('85', 460, 11, 22, 741205) A purely non violent act cannot result in such a thing.
('85', 460, 11, 23, 741261) Asked as to why he thinks he may have to fast, he said that ever since his release from prison he had an instinctive feeling that another fast lay in store for him.
('85', 460, 11, 24, 741426) Of late that feeling had taken a more concrete form.
('85', 460, 11, 25, 741479) The organized violence and slaughter of Truth all over has oppressed him deeply.
('85', 460, 11, 26, 741560) To take a few illustrations, the cause of millions dying of starvation according to him is not altogether scarcity of food.
('85', 460, 11, 27, 741684) Food is allowed to rot in godowns while people die for the want of it.
('85', 460, 11, 28, 741755) It is a sad
('85', 460, 12, 29, 741767) 1 Vide “Statement on Proposed Fast”, 29 10 1944.
('85', 461, 0, 1, 741816) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 462
('85', 461, 1, 2, 741858) tale of mismanagement and corruption.
('85', 461, 1, 3, 741896) Those who grow food have to go without it.
('85', 461, 1, 4, 741939) The Government officials, instead of being their protectors, are acting as their exploiters.
('85', 461, 1, 5, 742032) And it is not the Government officials alone who are to blame.
('85', 461, 1, 6, 742095) Our own people, middlemen, petty traders and big merchants have not hesitated to make money at the cost of human life.
('85', 461, 1, 7, 742214) It is a tragedy.
('85', 461, 1, 8, 742231) Unofficial and official exploitation go on side by side.
('85', 461, 1, 9, 742288) Without the former, the latter can have no locus standi.
('85', 461, 1, 10, 742345) From top to bottom the whole system is corrupt.
('85', 461, 1, 11, 742393) The Government connives at unofficial corruption.
('85', 461, 1, 12, 742443) That is the way in which violence works.
('85', 461, 1, 13, 742484) It organizes all the forces of evil.
('85', 461, 1, 14, 742521) As against this non violence must act by organizing all the forces of goodness.
('85', 461, 1, 15, 742601) If the nation had the control of the Government, this terrible bribery and corruption, which might if at all find its parallel in the bribery and corruption of Lord Clive’s days, would not take place.
('85', 461, 1, 16, 742802) A national government having the confidence of the people can very largely mitigate their sufferings.
('85', 461, 1, 17, 742904) But there seems to be no chance of it.
('85', 461, 1, 18, 742943) He described to what lengths he had gone to woo the Viceroy.
('85', 461, 1, 19, 743004) But the Government were blinded by the intoxication of power.
('85', 461, 1, 20, 743066) The vision of victory, which would be no victory but merely preparation for another war, had made them indifferent.
('85', 461, 1, 21, 743182) How was he to demonstrate the efficacy of non violence under the circumstances?
('85', 461, 1, 22, 743262) How could he relieve the sufferings of the dumb millions?
('85', 461, 1, 23, 743320) By conducting a mass movement?
('85', 461, 1, 24, 743351) He had already showed why it was not to be thought of.
('85', 461, 1, 25, 743406) He could not lead or bless a mass civil disobedience movement today.
('85', 461, 1, 26, 743475) Then what could he do?
('85', 461, 1, 27, 743498) He had claimed that non violence was always more than a match for violence however well organized.
('85', 461, 1, 28, 743597) How could he make that claim good?
('85', 461, 1, 29, 743632) At the beginning of the War, English friends had written to him asking how individual pacifists could fight spreading wave of violence and bloodshed.
('85', 461, 1, 30, 743782) He had suggested fasting as one of the remedies.
('85', 461, 1, 31, 743831) Some of them had laughed at the suggestion, but he stuck to it.
('85', 461, 1, 32, 743895) A time might come for him to test that remedy in his own case.
('85', 461, 1, 33, 743958) That was perhaps the only way to wake up the conscience of mankind.
('85', 461, 2, 34, 744026) Untouchability was another manifestation of violence.
('85', 461, 2, 35, 744080) He had repeated it from house tops that if untouchability lived Hinduism must perish.
('85', 461, 2, 36, 744166) The two could not go on side by side.
('85', 461, 2, 37, 744204) Though much progress was made why did it still persist?
('85', 461, 3, 38, 744260) there was the question of communal disharmony.
('85', 461, 3, 39, 744307) It was also a manifestation of violence.
('85', 461, 3, 40, 744348) He had striven against it from his early youth.
('85', 461, 4, 41, 744396) Why did his non violence appear to be impotent in the face of these various manifestations of untruth and violence?
('85', 461, 4, 42, 744512) Was he an unworthy exponent of non violence?
('85', 461, 4, 43, 744557) Should he not again crucify the flesh in order to become a better instrument?
('85', 461, 4, 44, 744635) Knowing the remedy, how could he evade it?
('85', 461, 4, 45, 744678) That the fast might fail to bring about the desired result or might end in death should not be a deterrent.
('85', 461, 5, 46, 744786) Asked about the nature of the fast, he said he did not know it himself.
('85', 461, 5, 47, 744858) He was still groping.
('85', 461, 5, 48, 744880) He was not aware as to when it would come, if at all.
('85', 461, 5, 49, 744934) All he could say was that the call was insistent.
('85', 461, 5, 50, 744984) If the fast did come, he hoped that the people would not become panicky or grief stricken.
('85', 461, 5, 51, 745075) He expected them to co operate with him in clearing the air of
('85', 462, 0, 1, 745138) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 463
('85', 462, 1, 2, 745181) violence in every shape or form.
('85', 462, 1, 3, 745214) That was the best way of ending the fast and even of preventing it.

('85', 462, 2, 6, 745340) APPENDIX III
('85', 462, 3, 7, 745353) LETTER FROM T. B. SAPRU 1
('85', 462, 4, 8, 745379) Personal October 25, 1944
('85', 462, 5, 9, 745405) MY DEAR GANDHIJI, I have just read in The Hindustan Times of the 24th of October your statement issued after the enquiry made by Mr. Horniman as to whether you are contemplating another fast to achieve communal unity.
('85', 462, 5, 10, 745623) I know I have no place as an adviser in these matters and I am most reluctant to offer advice to anyone in regard to any matter which is based on spiritual considerations.
('85', 462, 5, 11, 745795) I am approaching the whole thing from a secular point of view.
('85', 462, 5, 12, 745858) I think it would be a great mistake to undertake a fast at this time of your life.
('85', 462, 5, 13, 745941) The consequences might be disastrous.
('85', 462, 5, 14, 745979) I do not think that your fast will be helpful in the solution of the communal problem.
('85', 462, 5, 15, 746066) You may undertake a fast by way of penance, purification or protest, but the real question is as to what effect it is going to produce on the minds of those without whose agreement there can be no communal settlement.
('85', 462, 5, 16, 746284) I do not think those who are taking a different view will be at all influenced by your fast.
('85', 462, 5, 17, 746377) Indeed some of them may uncharitably suggest that you are putting undue pressure on them.
('85', 462, 5, 18, 746467) Personally speaking I think that it is very necessary that you must continue to live.
('85', 462, 5, 19, 746553) Your failure on the last occasion does not mean that you will always fail.
('85', 462, 5, 20, 746628) Your motives are pure and I think your approach to the whole question is sound, if I may respectfully say so.
('85', 462, 5, 21, 746738) What you have not been able to achieve so far, God willing, you may achieve it a few months later.
('85', 462, 5, 22, 746837) I consider it my duty to write to you as plainly as I possibly can against the step which is said to be within your contemplation.
('85', 462, 5, 23, 746968) You will forgive me if I have encroached upon your time .
('85', 462, 5, 24, 747026) With kindest regards, Yours sincerely, MAHATMA M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM WARDHA, C.P.

('85', 463, 1, 2, 747250) APPENDIX IV
('85', 463, 2, 3, 747262) (a) LETTER FROM T. B. SAPRU 1
('85', 463, 3, 4, 747292) Personal and Confidential GYAN BAGH,
('85', 463, 4, 5, 747329) HYDERABAD DECCAN,
('85', 463, 5, 6, 747347) November 4, 1944
('85', 463, 6, 7, 747364) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('85', 463, 7, 8, 747383) Your two letters of the 1st and the 3rd of November were handed over to me yesterday at the Wardha station by Devdas.
('85', 463, 7, 9, 747501) I also received your letter through Dr. Beni Prasad.
('85', 463, 8, 10, 747554) I have not issued any statement about an All Parties Conference but have written to certain friends and am awaiting their replies.
('85', 463, 8, 11, 747685) The idea seems to me to be vague and indefinite.
('85', 463, 8, 12, 747734) We must decide as to who are the persons to be invited and what will be the agenda.
('85', 463, 8, 13, 747818) It is quite clear that the gentlemen whom we invite will not come there in their representative capacity.
('85', 463, 8, 14, 747924) Your presence at the Conference will be a source of great strength and you can certainly make a statement telling us in plain language as to what led to the breakdown of the conversations at Bombay.
('85', 463, 8, 15, 748123) You say the Conference may meet to consider the causes of the failure of the talks and to find whose fault it was which led to the breakdown.
('85', 463, 8, 16, 748265) I should not advise that Conference to find whose fault it was, because once we do it will lead to interminable controversy.
('85', 463, 8, 17, 748390) If we call such a Conference and hear you I think we may consider what further steps it is necessary to take to solve the problem.
('85', 463, 8, 18, 748521) From this point of view the proposed conference will be an exploratory one and may thus ‘inform and educate public opinion’.
('85', 463, 9, 19, 748646) I am very anxious that you should on no account undertake a fast.
('85', 463, 9, 20, 748712) I know how deeply spiritual you are and I also know that in your case the call of religion means much more than in the case of 99 out of a hundred.
('85', 463, 9, 21, 748860) You will pardon me if I take a matter of fact and practical view of the thing.
('85', 463, 9, 22, 748939) I am definitely certain that although it may bring solace to your heart and you may feel that you have done the penance for what you consider to be the evils of the present day, your fast will not melt the heart of your opponents.
('85', 463, 9, 23, 749170) On the contrary I feel some of them may be uncharitable enough to attribute to you unworthy motives.
('85', 463, 9, 24, 749271) Never before in our history was it more necessary than now that you should live to guide the people of this country on tile true path of nationalism.
('85', 463, 9, 25, 749421) My own conviction is and has been for years that irrespective of what the British Government may or may not do this monster of communalism should be killed.
('85', 463, 9, 26, 749578) Whatever your critics may say I honestly believe that you are the one man in the country who does not think on communal lines and it would be a disaster for the country if it was deprived at this juncture of your guidance.
('85', 463, 10, 27, 749801) 1 Vide “Letter to T. B. Sapru”, 3 11 1944.
('85', 464, 0, 1, 749844) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 465
('85', 464, 1, 2, 749887) You are the one man who can withstand opposition, ridicule and even the attribution of unworthy motives to you.
('85', 464, 1, 3, 749999) Above all you have the courage to take the right line.
('85', 464, 1, 4, 750054) I am saying that in absolute sincerity even though I differ from you and have differed from you in regard to civil disobedience.
('85', 464, 2, 5, 750183) I have told Devdas that according to my information some changes in high quarters may be expected, but whether that information is true or not, the existing situation cannot last very long and when the time comes for practical steps to be taken towards the settlement of national differences I believe your voice will be the determining factor.
('85', 464, 2, 6, 750528) I do not want that voice to be silenced.
('85', 464, 2, 7, 750569) I am, therefore, appealing to you with all the earnestness I am capable of not to undertake such a fast.
('85', 464, 3, 8, 750674) As regards my coming to Wardha if I can get away on the evening of the 7th or the 8th and arrangements can be made for reservations from Wardha to Itarsi and from Itarsi to Allahabad I should in response to your message like to break journey at Wardha for a few hours.
('85', 464, 4, 9, 750943) With my profound regards,
('85', 464, 5, 10, 750969) Yours sincerely, MAHATMA M. K. GANDHI

('85', 464, 10, 16, 751105) The Standing Committee of the non party Conference, having considered the present situation in view of the breakdown of the Gandhi Jinnah talks on the communal issue, hereby resolves to appoint a committee which will examine the whole communal and minorities question from a constitutional and political point of view, put itself in touch with different parties and their leaders including the minorities interested in the question and present a solution within two months to the Standing Committee of the Non Party Conference.
('85', 464, 10, 17, 751633) The Standing Committee will take all reasonable steps to get that solution accepted by all parties concerned.
('85', 464, 10, 18, 751743) The Standing Committee authorises the Right Hon’ble Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru to appoint members of the Committee and announce their names in due course.

('85', 466, 1, 2, 753380) APPENDIX V
('85', 466, 2, 3, 753391) LETTER FROM DURLAB SINGH 1
('85', 466, 3, 4, 753418) LAHORE, November 12, 1944
('85', 466, 4, 5, 753444) RESPECTED BAPUJI,
('85', 466, 5, 6, 753462) The Congress had promised in its Lahore Resolution of 1929 that no constitution would be acceptable to the Congress which does not give the fullest satisfaction to the Sikhs.
('85', 466, 5, 7, 753637) You know a large number of Sikhs are perturbed over Rajaji’s proposals.
('85', 466, 5, 8, 753709) Supposing Mr. Jinnah had accepted the proposals in full, or in an amended form, what would have been the position of the Sikhs in that?
('85', 466, 6, 9, 753845) Even the Akalis feel very indignant because you did not touch the question of meeting a Sikh deputation as suggested by Master Tara Singh in his letter.
('85', 466, 6, 10, 753998) Can you please make it clear why it was not considered desirable to invite the Sikh leaders before proceeding to Mr. Jinnah for the talks?
('85', 466, 7, 11, 754137) Mr. Jagat Narain Lal’s Resolution clearly states that the Congress would be no party to the vivisection of the country.
('85', 466, 7, 12, 754257) Is it not a fact that Rajaji’s proposals run counter to that resolution?
('85', 466, 7, 13, 754330) The Sikh public is made to believe that Gandhiji does not favour the idea of the Sikhs remaining in the Congress because of their belief in the sword.
('85', 466, 8, 14, 754481) Master Tara Singh and other responsible Akali leaders have often declared in the Press and on the platform that the Sikander Baldev Singh Pact was enacted with the consent and blessings of the Congress High Command and Sardar Patel’s special representative who was present in the Punjab throughout the negotiations and that the Sardar was kept informed of all the developments.
('85', 466, 8, 15, 754859) Further, it is said that the Azad Punjab scheme was introduced with your consent and blessings.
('85', 466, 8, 16, 754955) The nationalist Sikhs regard both the schemes as anti national and opposed to the interests of the country and the community.
('85', 466, 8, 17, 755081) Can you kindly guide us in the matter?
('85', 466, 9, 18, 755120) In the end I will request you, Bapuji, to give a general assurance to the nationalist Sikhs that their interests are safe in your hands and that they will not be sacrificed at any cost.
('85', 466, 9, 19, 755306) The heart of the Sikh masses is with the Congress and nationalism and patriotism are their proud heritage.
('85', 466, 9, 20, 755413) They cannot depart from these principles, but let them have this satisfaction at least that the Congress will do no injustice to them and .
('85', 466, 9, 21, 755553) that they will have their proper place in free India.
('85', 466, 10, 22, 755607) Praying for your long life, Yours sincerely, DURLAB SINGH
('85', 466, 11, 23, 755665) The Indian Annual Register, 1944, Vol. II, pp.

('85', 467, 1, 2, 755798) APPENDIX VI
('85', 467, 2, 3, 755810) RESOLUTION PASSED BY A.I.S.A. 1
('85', 467, 3, 4, 755842) [On or before December 3, 1944]
('85', 467, 4, 5, 755874) A meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Charkha Sangh was held at Sevagram on the 1st, 2nd and 3rd December 1944, under the presidentship of Shree Gandhiji and the following decisions were taken:
('85', 467, 5, 6, 756072) The roots of the spinning wheel lie in the villages and the consummation of the ideal of the Charkha Sangh is to be completely decentralized among the villages of India to bring about an all round improvement of village life.
('85', 467, 5, 7, 756298) This meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Charkha Sangh therefore resolves that with a view to this end the following changes should be made in the policy of the Sangh:
('85', 467, 6, 8, 756470) (i) As many qualified workers as are ready and are selected by the Board should be sent to work in the villages.
('85', 467, 7, 9, 756583) (ii) The activities of the existing sale depots and production centres of khadi should be curtailed.
('85', 467, 8, 10, 756684) (iii) Necessary changes should be made in the curricula of the existing khadi training centres and their scope broadened.
('85', 467, 8, 11, 756806) New training centres should also be opened.
('85', 467, 9, 12, 756850) (iv) If in any area (not bigger than a district) the workers ask to be made self sufficient and autonomous in order to begin work on the new lines laid down by the Charkha Sangh the Sangh should, if it approves of their plans, withdraw from that area but continue to give its recognition and moral support so long as the work is carried on according to its policy.
('85', 467, 10, 13, 757215) (v) A Joint Board of the nominees of the Charkha Sangh, Gram Udyog Sangh, Harijan Sevak Sangh and Goseva Sangh should be constituted to meet from time to time and issue instructions in terms of the new policy.
('85', 467, 11, 14, 757425) The Sangh shall be represented in the Joint Board by its President, its Secretary and Shri Dhirendra Majmudar, while the other four Sanghs shall have two nominees each besides Gandhiji.
('85', 467, 11, 15, 757611) The Bombay Chronicle, 18 1 1945
('85', 467, 12, 16, 757643) 1 Vide “Resolution Passed by A.I.S.A. Trustees”, 1 12 1944.
('85', 468, 0, 1, 757703) APPENDIX VII
('85', 468, 1, 2, 757716) GUIDELINES FOR PROPOSED INTERIM GOVERNMENT 1
('85', 468, 2, 3, 757761) January 5, 1945
('85', 468, 3, 4, 757777) The following were the various steps proposed to be taken in this behalf as they emerged from their discussion and the elucidations provided by Gandhiji from time to time:
('85', 468, 4, 5, 757949) 1. The Congress and the League would agree that they would join in forming an Interim Government in the Centre (a) consisting of equal numbers of persons nominated by the Congress and the League in the Central Legislature, (b) representatives of minorities, and (c) the Commander in Chief.
('85', 468, 5, 6, 758239) 2. While the Government would be formed and would function within the framework of the existing Government of India Act, it would be clearly understood between the Congress and the League that any measure not passed by the House should not be enforced or sought to be enforced by any of the powers of the Governor General under the Constitution.
('85', 468, 5, 7, 758585) This would serve to eliminate in action the veto of the Governor General and make the nominees responsible to the elected Legislature.
('85', 468, 6, 8, 758720) 3. The European member, if one had to be included, should be the choice of the Congress and the League.
('85', 468, 7, 9, 758824) 4. It should be agreed between the Congress and the League in advance that if such Interim Government was formed” their first step would be to release the members of the Working Committee.
('85', 468, 7, 10, 759013) A firm and clear commitment of the League in regard to this would be a preliminary proof of its bona fides.
('85', 468, 8, 11, 759121) 5. Bhulabhai must make sure before committing himself to anything that the agreement he had in view had the previous approval of Jinnah and the whole thing should be clarified and reduced to writing so as not to lead to any ambiguity or misunderstanding afterwards.
('85', 468, 9, 12, 759387) 6. If such a Government was formed at the Centre, the next step would be to get the withdrawal of Governor’s rule in the Provinces and to form, as soon as possible, Provincial Governments on the lines of a coalition.
('85', 468, 10, 13, 759604) 7. At the proper moment Gandhiji would tell the Working Committee that Bhulabhai had acted with his approval.
('85', 468, 11, 14, 759714) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book 1, pp.
('85', 468, 12, 15, 759765) 1Vide “Note to Bhulabhai J. Desai”, 5 1 1945.
('85', 469, 0, 1, 759811) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 470
('85', 469, 1, 2, 759853) APPENDIX VIII
('85', 469, 2, 3, 759867) LETTER FROM P. C. JOSHI 1
('85', 469, 3, 4, 759893) BOMBAY,
('85', 469, 4, 5, 759901) February 1,1945
('85', 469, 5, 6, 759917) DEAR GANDHIJI, My last letter to you was dated 28th September, 1944. You had promised in an earlier letter that you will refer the question of our moral bona fides and your what I may call anti Communist file to your worthy colleagues.
('85', 469, 5, 7, 760153) I hope they have reached their conclusions and reported to you.
('85', 469, 5, 8, 760217) But I have not heard anything from you yet.
('85', 469, 5, 9, 760261) You perhaps do not know that your name is being used against us in the recent Congressmen’s Conferences and even otherwise by persons who pretend to know your mind, etc.
('85', 469, 5, 10, 760431) I know that most of what they attribute to you could never have been said by you.
('85', 469, 5, 11, 760513) But my own lips are sealed till my correspondence with you is concluded over the questions you asked me and they were very serious questions, doubting our elementary patriotic and moral bona fides.
('85', 469, 5, 12, 760711) I hope with the help of your Working Committee colleagues” you have reached the conclusion that we are not unworthy children of our great people.
('85', 469, 5, 13, 760857) Great things are happening in the world but our country is going to pieces.
('85', 469, 5, 14, 760933) We are anxious to write to you on the big political issues but as I wrote to you before” it will be waste of your time and mine till you are convinced about our intellectual honesty and moral integrity.
('85', 469, 5, 15, 761136) I understand from Dr. Mahmud that you think that you are the aggrieved party.
('85', 469, 5, 16, 761214) This is exactly the opposite of what we feel.
('85', 469, 5, 17, 761260) I” of course, meant no offence but only expressed my indignation at my Party being slandered and offered to go into the dock straightaway.
('85', 469, 5, 18, 761399) I do not know what else I could do.
('85', 469, 5, 19, 761435) Bhulabhai and Mrs. Naidu had promised to speed up the matter but I have not heard from them at all.
('85', 469, 5, 20, 761535) Rajaji told me that he had already told you all that he had to.
('85', 469, 5, 21, 761599) May I request you for an answer as soon as you can and to get your colleagues speed up their report to you.
('85', 469, 5, 22, 761707) I could send Mohan to pick up the answer and answer any further questions he feels himself qualified to tackle.
('85', 469, 5, 23, 761819) I am going to Bengal for three weeks today.
('85', 469, 5, 24, 761863) Could your answer be ready by the time I am back?
('85', 469, 5, 25, 761913) Mohan will be very busy in my absenceand will find it very difficult to come there in February” unless you specially want him to; but any date after 7 March will be best.
('85', 469, 6, 26, 762084) With respectful salutations, Yours sincerely,
('85', 469, 7, 27, 762130) P. C. JOSHI Correspondence between Mahatma Gandhi and P. C. Joshi, pp.
('85', 469, 8, 28, 762201) 1 Vide “Letter to P. C. Joshi”, 5 2 1945.
('85', 470, 0, 1, 762243) VOL.85 : 2 OCTOBER, 1944 3 MARCH, 1945 471
('85', 470, 1, 2, 762286) APPENDIX IX
('85', 470, 2, 3, 762298) LETTER FROM T. B. SAPRU 1
('85', 470, 3, 4, 762324) January 13, 1945
('85', 470, 4, 5, 762341) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI, I hope you are better now.
('85', 470, 4, 6, 762387) I have been reading the news about your health in the newspapers.
('85', 470, 4, 7, 762453) I have now much pleasure in sending you herewith a copy of the questionnaire framed by the committee of which I am the Chairman.
('85', 470, 4, 8, 762582) I dare say your attention has already been called to it.
('85', 470, 4, 9, 762639) I shall be extremely grateful to you if you will favour the committee with a short memorandum stating your views generally and answering the questions or such of them as you prefer to answer.
('85', 470, 4, 10, 762831) So far there has been a good response to the committee excepting in certain quarters.
('85', 470, 4, 11, 762917) Mr. Jinnah has declined to recognize the committee or to meet me as Chairman of the committee though he has no objection to meeting me in my individual capacity.
('85', 470, 4, 12, 763079) Dr. Ambedkar promised support when we first met in November last at Delhi but has withdrawn it because he has objection to the personnel of the committee.
('85', 470, 4, 13, 763234) The attitude of the Sikhs has been very encouraging so far.
('85', 470, 4, 14, 763294) I am going on the 16th of January to Lahore to see the Sikh and Hindu leaders and shall try also to meet such Muslim leaders as have no objection to meeting me.
('85', 470, 4, 15, 763455) The work of the committee is being done at great pressure.
('85', 470, 4, 16, 763514) We have already collected much material and more will be ready soon.
('85', 470, 4, 17, 763583) I do not wish to trouble you with details but I shall be extremely grateful if you will favour me with a short memorandum.
('85', 470, 4, 18, 763706) I am also sending you separately the two pamphlets already brought out, others are in the course of being printed.
('85', 470, 5, 19, 763821) With kindest regards and best wishes for your early recovery,
('85', 470, 6, 20, 763883) Yours sincerely,
('85', 470, 7, 21, 763900) Questionnaire MAHATMA M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, C. P.
('85', 470, 8, 22, 763959) Gandhi Sapru Papers.
('85', 470, 8, 23, 763980) Courtesy: National Library, Calcutta
('85', 470, 9, 24, 764017) 1Vide “Letter to T. B. Sapru”, 8 2 1945.
